QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUCTION OF ITEMS OF SIR DOUGLAS MAWSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the notice of the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment a matter that is causing great consternation in South Australia. Is the Minister aware that on 5 and 6 October there is to be an auction in Paris of items belonging to the French Antarctic explorer, Paul Emile Victor? Is the Minister further aware that amongst the items to be auctioned are articles that belonged to the Australian Antarctic explorer, Sir Douglas Mawson? Is the Minister able to inform the Senate whether the Mawson items in the auction were legally obtained or whether, as suggested to me recently in a letter, they were 'opportunistically and illegally removed' from Mawson's hut in 1957? As this is the centenary year of Mawson's birth, an event that is being celebrated throughout Australia but particularly in South Australia, is the Minister concerned that these extremely important historic relics could be lost to Australia? What action can the Government take to ensure that these items are returned to their rightful place in this country?

—I am aware of suggestions that the situation is as set out by Senator Jessop and that some items which are to be auctioned in Paris on 5 and 6 October are thought to be items that were used by Sir Douglas Mawson. Officers of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment are at this moment checking the accuracy of the reports. They are checking whether the items were obtained from Sir Douglas Mawson, how they were obtained and whether the concerns expressed correctly by Senator Jessop are ones which should be followed up. Only when those investigations are complete will the Minister and his Department be in a position to determine what is the appropriate course of action to take. It may be proper for me to make Senator Jessop's concern known to the Minister and to ensure that when the findings of the investigation are to hand they are passed on to my colleague.

—Has the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy been drawn to today's Press reports that 2,700 workers at various Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd plants around the country will lose their jobs this year? Has the Minister's attention also been drawn to the fact that import duty on steel imports is generally only 5 per cent, the maximum being only 10 per cent, and that in many cases imports from countries such as Taiwan and South Korea arrive in this country duty free? Is the Minister aware that Australian companies exporting steel products from Australia to Taiwan have to pay a duty of up to 15 per cent on the c.i.f. price, a 4 per cent labour tax and a commodity tax which ranges from 2 per cent to 100 per cent, making a total of between 22 per cent and 139 per cent when these various taxes are compounded? Is the Minister aware that Taiwanese and South Korean importers have to be licensed and that imports are controlled in those countries when they conflict with local production? In view of the attitudes of these two countries to their domestic steel industries, will the Government reconsider its foolish and short-sighted view of the strategic importance of our steel industry? I remind the Minister that without a vital and healthy steel industry out shipbuilding and vehicle manufacturing industries and other vital defence industries will be entirely dependent for their raw materials on imports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the retrenchment of a significant number of workers employed at the BHP steel works. Indeed, a series of discussions has been held between BHP and the Government over the months. BHP has made it very clear that the world recession has had an effect upon it and, in particular, upon the demands in Australia for steel. Therefore it has been in a difficult trading position. Equally, the very great rise in wages, which averaged something like 17 1/2 per cent last year, has, of course, imposed costs upon the steel industry which priced that industry out of many markets. The Government set up a Temporary Assistance Authority inquiry at the request of BHP and the report was considered. The Government has referred the whole question to the Industries Assistance Commission and there will be a thorough review of BHP.

ANSWER.PARA: It is admitted that in the world at the moment there is an enormous excess capacity for steel making. In fact, in the free world there is something like 130 million tonnes excess capacity for steel of which Japan itself would have a very considerable amount. It is true that countries, including particularly South Korea, are keenly competing in the world at prices with which Australian steel works cannot cope at the moment. All of these things are being taken into consideration. The Government has pegged imports of steel to the 1981-82 situation. The Government has also taken a very significant step with regard to aid to BHP for reconstruction for the future. Under the recent Budget companies are able to collect together and produce their accounts as a consolidated account. That means that profits and losses can be consolidated. This could mean that the profits from BHP's oil venture, which could be very substantial for the future particularly with Fortescue coming on stream, could provide a significant source of capital for redevelopment and restructuring.

The Government up to date has been very closely in touch with BHP, has been very acutely aware of the need in Australia to maintain an efficient steel works and has taken steps already which are significant in themselves. But overall the problems of BHP are the problems of Australian manufacturing industry at the moment. Wages in Australia have been forced upwards-the rise last year was 17 1/ 2 per cent-to a point so far ahead of the general trend throughout the world that Australian manufacturing and general exports are steadily pricing themselves out of world markets. The way back for Australia is to do what every other country in the free world is doing at this moment. The way back, as in Europe and other countries, is for Australia to understand that there must be a restraint on wages and costs in Australia if we are to have a cost structure which allows us to expand employment and to compete elsewhere. The whole question of the steel works in Australia will be kept under review. As to the specific details that were asked of me regarding Taiwan and South Korea, I am unable to be specific and I will refer those maters to the Minister for Trade and Resources and seek further information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry a question. Is the Government aware whether any complaints have been lodged with the Department of Primary Industry in relation of New Zealand canned apples allegedly being dumped in this country? In general terms, what sections of primary industry, if any, are now experiencing alleged dumping problems and which of these, if any, are associated with closer economic relations negotiations, particularly with regard to Tasmanian agriculture?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have not been any formal complaints laid in this area. All requests for anti-dumping action need to be lodged with the Department of Industry and Commerce which administers our anti-dumping legislation. The latest advice I have-which would be no more than a day old-is that no complaints on apples have been lodged with the Department, although the procedures for initiating anti-dumping action were recently outlined in a letter from the Department of Primary Industry to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation in response to allegations that a range of processed apple products were being dumped in Australia by New Zealand exporters. In other words, there have been allegations and as a result information with respect to the appropriate procedures has been forwarded by the Department of Primary Industry to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation, but I do not think any formal action has been taken as a result of that.

ANSWER.PARA: With the exception of a dumping and countervailing duty complaint against imports of New Zealand square-dressed structural softwood, I am not aware of any agricultural industries having lodged anti-dumping complaints. In the course of public consultations on the proposals for closer economic relations with New Zealand a number of industries, in particular horticulture and sectors of the dairy industry, have expressed concern at the prospect of New Zealand produce being dumped in Australia. The closer economic relations proposals are designed to ensure that anti-dumping and countervailing duty action, where it is justified, is effective. For horticultural products, because of the seasonal nature of production and the need for prompt action to prevent injury, a special liaison arrangement will be established between government and industry to enable the speedy determination of whether a legitimate complaint exists. The Minister for Industry and Commerce recently announced measures to speed up the investigation of anti-dumping and countervailing duty complaints with a view to ensuring that effective remedies are available to Australian industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you read a bit louder?

—Since that has come from a senator who cannot even make a speech in this House without reading it, I think he ought to go away and take a few lessons. The Government has made it clear on a number of occasions that the closer economic relations arrangements are designed to result in fair competition and the anti-dumping action, together with the safeguard action in the agreement, is designed to ensure this. If anyone would like to hear more about this, I suggest he ask me a further question.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that trust stripping as a form of tax avoidance has continued unabated notwithstanding the enactment of Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act in 1981 and amendments in the same year to section 100A of that Act? Is she aware that trust strips have for some time been more popular than Slutzkin schemes, including the bottom-of- the-harbour variant of that scheme, and probably already have cost the revenue some hundreds of millions of dollars? Will she confirm that the Australian Taxation Office is well aware, and has been for some time, of the nature and scale of trust stripping? Will she tell us how much information on this subject has been communicated by the Tax Office to the Treasurer? Has the Tax Office sought any, and if so, what, advice from the Attorney-General's Department? Why has no visible action been taken to stem this new tax avoidance tide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question calls for information on a number of matters that need reference to the Treasurer. I will see that they are referred to him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VISITS TO AUSTRALIA BY NUCLEAR ARMED SHIPS AND AIRCRAFT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware that at the recent Western Australian State conference, the Australian Labor Party passed a resolution opposing visits to Australia of ships or aircraft armed with nuclear weapons? Is the Minister further aware that the Indian Ocean is one of the busiest sea lanes in the world and the loading point for virtually all Western Australian trade? Can the Minister confirm that the Indian Ocean has been the target of a major build-up of the Soviet fleet over the past decade and that this trade is therefore vulnerable to that presence? Can the Minister say what effect the action of the Australian Labor Party in Western Australia is likely to have on the ANZUS alliance and how our principal ally, the United States of America, views the ALP's moves not to allow its vessels to enter Australian ports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Western Australian branch has in fact been discussing this matter and has opposed visits to Australia by ships or aircraft. Although I am unable to confirm--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable senators will just wait, I will give the appropriate answer. The fact is that I am unable yet to ascertain whether a resolution to that effect was passed. Nevertheless, the essential points made by Senator Crichton-Browne in his question are true. The sea lanes of the Indian Ocean, especially from the north-west, through the South-East Asian area, are among the busiest in the world and vital to Australia's interests. It is also true that in recent years the Soviet naval presence in the Indian Ocean has increased significantly. Some 20 or 30 ships of that country's navy are normally deployed in that ocean quite close to the Western Australian coast at any one time. It is true that from time to time there are also visits to Australian ports by United States naval vessels. It is important to the ANZUS alliance that that kind of cameraderie between two allies should continue. I note no dissenting remark; perhaps even the Opposition agrees. However, it might be interesting to note that, in fact, the Western Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party, according to a resolution that is being put to its conference, apparently is opposed to it.
—A while ago you said it was a rumour.

—No, it is not a rumour. Certainly, these moves are having disconcerting effects on our relations with overseas countries. I imagine that if indeed the Opposition wants to express a clear view about that it will have an opportunity to do so tonight, or perhaps at some later time, in debating the Bill that is forthcoming in this Parliament on that very matter. We look forward to hearing clear statements from Opposition senators about their attitudes in relation to the ANZUS alliance. I hope they can clear up this very great concern about the attitudes of the Western Australian branch of the Labor Party.
—Mr President, I seek your assistance in having the Minister table the document from which he read because I think it is written on a Liberal Party letterhead.
—I have no document.

—I ask the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General whether the Treasurer, Mr Howard, announced yesterday that in the past few weeks the Government had received $171,000 from the shareholders of one company that would come within the ambit of foreshadowed legislation to recover tax avoided through use of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Are the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act now to be read as permitting the Treasurer to be acquainted with the details of the discharging of tax liability in one particular case? Has the Attorney-General or the Crown Solicitor given any legal opinion to the Australian Taxation Office or the Treasurer as to the legality of this revelation to the Treasurer of the discharge of a particular tax liability rather than, as hitherto, the aggregating of a number of unnamed cases to reveal some trend or the gravity of a particular problem?

—I have seen, I believe, a summary of a newspaper report suggesting something along the lines of the matters raised by the honourable senator. I have not spoken with the Treasurer, and no direct advice has been given to me that I have seen. I have not considered whether there is any conflict there with the secrecy provisions of the taxation legislation. I will refer the question to the Acting Attorney-General and get a considered reply for the honourable senator.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Are we to take it, then, that no opinion is presently available to the Government, including himself as the Minister representing the Acting Attorney in this place, on the question of whether the particularities of a tax liability in one individual case can be revealed by the Australian Taxation Office to the Treasurer?

—I am grateful for the supplementary question if there was something in what I said that would have given rise to any inference at all. What I said to the honourable senator in responding to the question was that I would refer it to the Acting Attorney-General and get a reply. I meant no inference one way or the other.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELIMINATION OF WATER HYACINTH, WAREHOUSE BEETLE AND BLUE-GREEN SPOTTED APHID

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Also, Mr President, I refer to your welcome to former Senator Webster and the spontaneous response by honourable senators, mostly opposite, who perhaps saw the possibility of a Websterian answer during Question Time. Accordingly, I ask what progress has been made with regard to the elimination of water hyacinth, the warehouse beetle and the blue-green spotted aphid?

—I am very disappointed to get that question. I feel like a novice tap dancer who is asked to perform in front of Nureyev in responding to that sort of question with former Senator Webster in the gallery. I had hoped to be able to assure him that since he left the Senate the standard of questions being asked had improved. I now feel that I cannot assert that to him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, said on the television program Sunday and later in his electorate radio talk that, although no Liberal liked retrospectivity, it was even more important to demonstrate the Liberal Party's commitment to a fair tax system and that it is the Government's intention to collect the tax that has been evaded. He stated also that the Liberal Party was founded to govern fairly, in the interests of all Australians, and he did not want to lead or be part of any party which failed to stand by that principle. Keeping in mind that the great majority of Australians are honest taxpayers and have had to pay on an average between $30 and $35 a family per week, or approximately $3,000, extra because a group has evaded paying all or most of its taxes and that an honest government could not and would not want to keep those evaded taxes when collected but would want to pay them back to the honest taxpayers, I ask: When and how is the Government planning to do that following collection of the taxes? Will those taxes be paid back weekly or monthly, or will they be paid back in a lump sum?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the Prime Minister's television and radio talks, I understand that he said that a number of taxpayers in Australia-the pay-as-you -earn taxpayers-had borne an unfair burden of tax over the past 10 years because some people had evaded taxes by using schemes such as the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. When one is considering principles, especially the principle of equity, one has to consider that there is a very real principle of equity in regard to the PAYE people who have been unduly carrying the burden of taxation as against those who have been dodging it. That is the principle that has been weighed up. In the recoupment provisions that will come before the Senate the Government will pursue the liabilities for company tax that were liable at the time when the vendor shareholders sold their shares and the companies were subsequently stripped. That is perfectly clear and it was in that context and in the knowledge that there is a need to be fair to all Australians that the Prime Minister pointed out that his political party, which the people of Australia have accepted over the years as being the government of their choice, governs in the interests of all.

ANSWER.PARA: Within the very Budget before the Parliament at the moment is a significant amount of money to be recovered from such schemes. That money will help to provide tax cuts, increases in family allowances, increases in student assistance, increases in spouse allowances and the interest rebates on housing. All those things, taken together, will mean for an average family with children something between $17 and $20 a week in the course of this year. That is a very significant distribution towards the lower and lower middle income families of Australia. Senator Elstob has referred to some figures. He alleges that the tax evaders have robbed taxpayers of $35 a week. There is absolutely no basis at all for such a figure. The evidence before us is that it is considerably lower. It is the intention of the Commonwealth Government to pursue these tax evasion schemes and to outlaw them, to collect the revenue and to apply that revenue to all those items of welfare in the Budget-education, defence et cetera-for all Australians to share in. We intend to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. What precautions are taken by the Commonwealth Employment Service to ensure that advertised jobs are filled by suitable local applicants and that the advertisements to which I refer are not used as a mechanism to allow prearranged entry for overseas persons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no information on whether particular safeguards are used in that regard. I have experience, as I suspect many honourable senators have, of direct personal representations being made in circumstances in which people are seeking to get admission of people from overseas and are putting forward in support of that the fact that they are able to obtain employment for them in Australia. Often in the course of that letters are produced from potential employers saying that they are prepared to employ the person who is seeking immigration. I suppose that it is one of the oddities of our situation that, at a time when there is very great concern about unemployment, one still gets people trying to come to Australia because they see it as a land of considerable opportunity-which, of course, it is-and one finds that there are employers prepared to say that they are unable to obtain suitable employees on the local market.

ANSWER.PARA: I mention that in response to the question because it suggests a state of affairs rather different from the one implied, I think, in the question asked by Senator Watson, which is that there may be some effectively fictitious advertising which is really being used to provide a facility for the entry of immigrants rather than offering jobs to local people. If that were occurring, it would be a matter of concern to the Government and, I am sure, to the Minister, Mr Macphee. I shall ensure that it is referred to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hearn raised the matter some time ago.

—By interjection it has been suggested that the matter has already been raised in the Senate. That is a reference of which I have no recollection. I do not deny that it may have occurred. In any event, I shall refer the matter to the Minister and see whether some information can be obtained which will enable me to give a more informative answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: MR JOHN McLEAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to a statement of claim lodged in the last few days in the Supreme Court of South Australia by Mr Mount, the official liquidator of Clinton Credits Pty Ltd, wherein he states that a Mr John McLeay, together with members of his family, as directors of Clinton Credits, acted dishonestly in the transfer of property from Clinton Credits in March 1980; that $18,000 was paid by one McLeay family company to another McLeay family company for land valued at $250,000; and that John McLeay breached the Companies Act of South Australia as a director of this company. Is it not a fact that Mr John McLeay was, in March 1980, a Minister of this Government and, secondly, that the same person is currently luxuriating in Los Angeles as the Australian Consul-General and has been there since December 1980? In view of the aforementioned, I ask the Leader of the Government: Was the Prime Minister advised by his then Minister of his dealings with the family companies, and did the Prime Minister know this when he appointed Mr McLeay as Australian Consul-General? In view of the allegations of the official liquidator , and on the basis that Mr McLeay represents Australia and not the Fraser Government, I ask that Mr McLeay be recalled from Los Angeles.

—I should have thought that even Senator Bolkus would understand that allegations made before a court are not matters of any proof and are not matters on which one-even he-would assert any kind of culpability. Indeed, I would also think that if any honourable senator were aware that there was an action before a court, he would know that it is not for this Senate, in any sense, to sit in judgment on what the final resolution of those court proceedings would be. I should have thought that that would be elementary. As to the question about whether a Mr John McLeay was a member of this Parliament and a Minister, the answer is yes. As to the next question, rather melodramatically asked, I remind the Senate that Mr McLeay is indeed the Consul-General in Los Angeles at present, and no doubt he is doing a first class job for Australia in that capacity. I am not equipped to comment upon any of the company transactions of Mr McLeay, but I have an awareness that Mr McLeay made a statement quite some time ago in which he indicated that he was not connected with particular companies at the time of transactions. Not having any knowledge of the details before the courts I suggest to all honourable senators that the ordinary proceedings of the law should take place and that this Senate should observe them.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to that part of my question in which I mentioned the knowledge of the Prime Minister. I ask the Leader of the Government to inquire of the Prime Minister what facts were known to the Government at the time of the appointment of Mr McLeay? Secondly, I ask for a response to that part of my question which referred to Mr McLeay's current status representing Australia.

—It is well known to the Parliament that the Prime Minister demands of his Ministers a statement of their pecuniary interests. That statement would have been available to the Prime Minister. I will direct that portion of the question to the Prime Minister for his study. As to the remainder of the question, the Prime Minister at this moment has every reason to believe that Mr McLeay is a person of integrity and is carrying out his duties in Los Angeles as effectively and with as much dedication as when he was a Minister.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I refer him to mining industry concern that the diesel levy rebate might not apply to dieselene used to power mining towns, for heat generation in smelters and refineries and for the off-road transport of mine and smelter products to ports and refineries over private and State railways and in coastal vessels. Can the Minister clarify the intent of the legislation in terms of whether the rebate applies in those circumstances and advise whether the legislation requires amendment to ensure that there is no misinterpretation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice on this matter is that the Diesel Fuel Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill which was introduced on Budget night provides for a rebate of excise paid on diesel fuel in mining operations otherwise than for the purpose of propelling a vehicle on a public road. In the Bill the definition of mining operations includes:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) exploration, prospecting or mining for minerals; or
(b) the dressing or beneficiation (at the mining site or elsewhere) of minerals , or ores bearing minerals, as an integral part of operations for their recovery .
and includes-

(c) other operations connected with exploration, prospecting or mining for minerals that are carried out in, or at a place adjacent to, the area in which the exploration, prospecting or mining occurs;

(d) where minerals, or ores bearing minerals, are dressed or beneficiated, at a place other than the mining site, as an integral part of operations for their recovery-the transporting of the minerals or ores from the mining site to the place where they are dressed or beneficiated:

Whether the rebate applies in a particular mining operation depends on the circumstances of the case. However, rebate is not payable on diesel fuel used in smelting or refining activities which are not an integral part of the mining operation. Off-road transport of minerals to a place where beneficiation of minerals would occur would be eligible for rebate. In other words, there are specific areas where the rebate is applicable; outside those areas it is not. I will, however, check the point raised by the honourable senator, but I do not think that any further change is likely.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the answer he gave to Senator Bolkus, in which he said that it is well known that Ministers inform the Prime Minister of any directorships or shareholdings which they have in companies. I ask: Is that the rule? Is it not a fact that the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, had not informed the Prime Minister of his shareholdings in the Murray Goulburn Co- operative Co. Ltd until such time as he was found out and the matter was exposed in the Press?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rule, of course, follows from the fact that the Government has adopted the recommendations of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest, which recommended on pecuniary interest. All the recommendations of that Committee of Inquiry which relate to Ministers have been adopted and are in force. I invite Senator Button to study that document. He would then realise that it contains some very detailed matters relating not only to private declarations to the Prime Minister but also to declarations of interest in a variety of ways. I am not aware whether the Minister for Primary Industry in his report to the Prime Minister indicated his shareholding in the Murray Goulburn Co-operative Co. Ltd.
—Everybody else is.

—The fact is that that register is known only to two people-the head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Prime Minster. I take it that Senator Button is saying that he also knows what is on the register. The fact is that the shareholding in the Murray Goulburn Co- operative if put into perspective is that--
—You cannot put it in perspective. You either have rules or you don't.

—If indeed we are to have some second reading speeches in this place then let them be made at the proper time. I was asked a question but because Senator Button does not like the answer he attempts to divert the answer. The public of Australia can judge the reasons. The fact is that everybody who is in primary industry in Australia understands that many farmers, in fact most farmers, belong to co-operatives; that shareholdings in co- operatives are nominal shareholdings; that they are in fact the membership establishments of those people in the co-operatives; and they are not, in the sense, shareholdings for pecuniary interests such as the ordinary shareholdings in private or public companies. Even the Labor Party ought to understand this. I suspect that it does but it wants to distort it. There is no way in the world that one would want--
—You would be the chief distorter in the whole Parliament.
—Order! Senator Gietzelt, that was a very marginal comment. I suggest that you do not make further comments like that.
—He distorts a lot of questions and answers, Mr President.
—Order!

—Again, honourable senators opposite do not like what I am saying. I repeat that the fact of the matter is that a membership of rural industry co-operatives is in itself a shareholding membership simply to become a co-partner in an industry which distributes the produce of primary industry. It is not in its sense something from which the shareholders make a major pecuniary gain. Everybody knows that Mr Nixon is a farmer and he, of course, has declared that. He has declared his interests. It would be an utter distortion of the facts to try to draw any kind of conclusion that there was any attempt by Mr Nixon to gain anything by way of pecuniary interest out of that shareholding. Indeed, what Senator Button fails to say is that in his actions with regard to Murray Goulburn Co-operative, Mr Nixon, as the Minister, made a ruling which was considerably adverse to the very co-operative to which he belongs.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. I refer Senator Carrick to his answer to me. He said at the beginning of his answer that the rules were quite clear and that they were laid down in the report of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. If the rules were laid down in the Bowen report and are quite clear, will he tell the Senate whether any exceptions are made in the Bowen recommendations about farmers who happen to produce dairy cattle, or anybody else in this Government, or whether the rules are in fact as he says, quite clear? Are there any exceptions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that I invited Senator Button to study the Bowen Committee report, which has been adopted by the Government with regard to Ministers.

—My question is to the Minister for Education and it is about the Hawthorn Institute of Education. I refer the Minister to the reference in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled 'Australia and ASEAN' concerning the need for expansion of educational work and to the Government's response of 9 April 1981 stating that the work of non- governmental organisations continues to be supported by the Government in response to the needs indicated by countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations. I ask: Is the Minister aware that the Hawthorn Institute of Education is participating in a joint venture tendering arrangement for the establishment of a number of skills and training centres in Indonesia? Will the Government support the initiative of this college?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember when the report of the Senate Standing Committee was brought down. I remember what it looked like but I must confess that I did not read it and cannot acknowledge whether that particular recommendation was made. However, I accept what the honourable senator says and I certainly accept the merit of the recommendation that was made and of the response to it.

ANSWER.PARA: I can confirm that the Hawthorn Institute of Education is very active in seeking tenders and in offering its educational services in quite a number of areas. It has a quite notable entrepreneurial record. I am aware that it is part of a joint tendering operation as set out by Senator Lewis. The amount involved could be very large and there could be a great amount of activity involved in Indonesia. It could earn significant money for the college and, of course, could have significant benefits for Australia in terms of our relations with our largest near neighbour.

I understand that the Commonwealth Government has indicated its readiness to support the venture through the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation and that the Government, through appropriate channels, has indicated its support for the concept. I wish the Hawthorn Institute well in what it is doing. I wish its Principal, Mr Gordon Bail, well in the work that he is doing with the Institute. I hope that the joint tendering venture can be successful on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Over two years ago the Government removed the limits on electoral spending. At the same time it promised that it would inquire into what the limits should be. Could the Minister indicate where the inquiry has got and when the Senate is likely to have a report on the inquiry as promised?
—I will undertake to address that question to the Minister and obtain an early reply.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security as the Minister responsible for the implementation of the Homes Deposit Assistance Scheme. When the Treasurer announced the changes to the old Homes Savings Grant Scheme on 18 March he stated that a certain period would be available for prospective users of the scheme to apply for it before it was removed. Is the Minister aware that many people who had undertaken to purchase their first home were unaware of the changes to the legislation and unaware that if they did not apply almost immediately they would lose out under the old scheme and be precluded from participating in the new scheme? If so, what arrangements is he prepared to make to enable these people to take advantage of the scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will remember that as part of the Government' s housing package announced earlier this year and before I assumed responsibilities in this area, we indicated that among the changes which we were making to assist the promotion of home ownership in Australia we would be discontinuing the old Homes Savings Grant Scheme, paying off the backlog of claims under that scheme and introducing a new Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. That latter scheme had an easier savings requirement. It provided some additional benefit and it was, I think, income tested and had a number of changes which were thought to be beneficial. One of the principal changes was that we were seeking to ensure that the subsidy available from the taxpayer would be made available at a time when it would assist home purchasers to bridge the deposit gap.

ANSWER.PARA: Inevitably when one changes from one scheme to another it is necessary to have a cut off date for one scheme and a commencement date for the other. In the case of the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme and the Homes Savings Grant Scheme there was in fact an overlap period. An announcement was made and I think 2 June was given ultimately as the cut off date for assistance under the old Homes Savings Grant Scheme. Because there was a cut off date and because there was the problem of letting people know about the scheme and the fact that if they did not apply they would lose their rights, the Government undertook a quite extensive advertising campaign. There was advertising in all the major Press and on radio. A very large number of letters was sent out by the then Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr McVeigh, to those bodies which dealt with home buyers. So, a great effort was made to ensure that those who might benefit from the scheme should learn about the fact that the scheme was coming to an end and was being replaced by the new scheme.

Inevitably, some people have not caught up with the fact that the scheme was changed. One might say that it is the counsel of despair for Ministers to say that is inevitable, but, when one looks at the utilisation rate of the Homes Savings Grant Scheme, it becomes clear that at all times during the life of that scheme it has never caught 100 per cent of home buyers. Again I am speaking from memory, but my recollection is that the participation rate among home buyers was something like 60 per cent to 70 per cent. There has always been a significant number of home buyers who might have qualified but have not come forward. In any event, a special effort was made. Notwithstanding that special effort, some people have missed out, through either inadvertence or lack of knowledge. I do not propose to put before the Government any proposal that there should be a further period of having the two schemes operating. It is unfortunate, but the Government did what it could at the time to ensure that the scheme was widely understood. I do not believe anything can be done to pick up those cases which are the subject of the question by Senator Robertson.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In the light of increased slaughterings due to the drought, weak Japanese demand for our beef and increased competition from traditional exporters, what assurances has the Government been able to obtain from the United States Government with respect to Australian beef quotas in the immediate future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated in the honourable senator's question, the matter of beef exports to the United States is important given current Australian seasonal conditions and the general state of the industry. I can advise the Senate that action has been taken in the area raised by Senator MacGibbon. Because of the high level of shipments by major supplying countries, it was thought likely that imports of beef into the United States in 1982 would be limited under the United States meat import law. Australia, New Zealand and Canada were, therefore, approached by the United States to restrain the level of their exports for the remainder of this year. The figure proposed for Australia is 676.9 million lb, which corresponds with the minimum access level to which Australia is entitled under the meat import law. However, this may be increased if there are shortfalls in supplies from other countries. An understanding of the United States along these lines is in the process of being finalised.

ANSWER.PARA: Forecasts indicate that our shipments for entry into the United States are likely to reach the proposed restraint level in about mid-October. The Minister has directed the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to implement the necessary arrangements to ensure that the proposed restraint level for Australia is not exceeded. The access assurances which we received from the United States are of particular value to the industry, which is currently going through one of the severest droughts on record. I am sure that exporters will recognise that these and the related measures being implemented by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation will remove much of the uncertainty in respect of the United States market which has been facing them over recent weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the system of tax incentives for the film industry brought in by the Fraser Government is being bypassed by investors in favour of other more lucrative provisions of the tax legislation that do not require the films to have any Australian content? Is this system having the effect of putting Australian actors and technicians out of work while using Australian taxpayers' money to subsidise the use of overseas personnel and facilities to fund overseas films, such as the film Arthur? What action will the Government take to eliminate this method of massive tax avoidance that is also destroying the prospects of thousands of people in the Australian film industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government introduced tax arrangements for the film industry to assist that industry and did so in consultation with the industry. I understood that those concessions were now working to the benefit of the industry. The fact that they may not be providing the employment hoped for Australians is not something of which I am aware. I know that the Treasurer has had a number of consultations about the legislation with representatives of that industry to ensure that the intent of the Government in giving assistance to the film industry results from it. —There have been enough points of order.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Matter of Urgency

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 15 September 1982, from Senator Chipp:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64 I give notice that today I propose to move-That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Federal Government to fulfil its legislative responsibilities in relation to the Franklin and Gordon Rivers in Tasmania by legislating immediately to guarantee that the environment of the Franklin and Gordon Rivers is not destroyed by any development in the wilderness regions of South-West Tasmania, and to urgently discuss with the Government of Tasmania adequate and reasonable compensation for any lost development opportunities.
Yours sincerely, DON CHIPP Leader of the Australian Democrats
More then the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Federal Government to fulfil its legislative responsibilities in relation to the Franklin and Gordon Rivers in Tasmania by legislating immediately to guarantee that the environment of the Franklin and Gordon Rivers is not destroyed by any development in the wilderness regions of South West Tasmania, and to urgently discuss with the Government of Tasmania adequate and reasonable compensation for any lost development opportunities.

The issue of the Franklin River has been Australia's greatest conservation issue since the battle to save Lake Pedder. It is no coincidence that these two battles have been over area of Tasmania, areas of a State which contains some of the world's most outstanding beauty. I was fortunate enough to experience this beauty in a rafting trip down the Franklin in February 1981. It is one of the most unforgettable experiences I have had. The essence of the debate that the Australian Democrats raise today is that the Federal Government has the authority to prevent the environmental destruction of the Franklin River. No political points will be made by me or by members of my party today. I hope that this motion will give all members of the Senate an opportunity to participate on a non-party basis to do two things: Firstly, to save one of the world's most beautiful places from destruction; and, secondly, to compensate the Tasmanian Government for any losses it might sustain because of such a federal decision.

I make the point that although I am a member of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania I am also the leader of a party and therefore have always reserved the right to move such a matter as a matter of urgency, ensuring of course that no evidence given in confidence to me or to other members of the Committee is disclosed. I made it perfectly clear to the Chairman of the Committee at the beginning that I had to wear two hats-one as a member of the Committee and one as the leader of a party. He graciously accepted that position .

The controversy over the Franklin River is very much a national issue. I put this analogy to the Senate: Letting Tasmanians alone-that is, about half the voting population of Tasmania-decide on the Franklin River is about the same as allowing the population of Alice Springs and Darwin to vote by referendum to have Ayers Rock crushed by bulldozers to make gravel for a road in the middle of the Northern Territory. It is the same as allowing the populations of Townsville , Cairns and Mackay decide that the Great Barrier Reef ought to be mined for oil . The proposition is absolutely absurd.

This is not a Tasmanian issue; it is a national and even international issue. The fact that the people of Australia have recognised that can be seen by a meeting in Melbourne on a recent sunny Sunday afternoon. Over 2,500 people gave up their Sunday afternoon to protest about the damming of the Franklin. The significance of that, Mr Acting Deputy President, ought to come to you, as a Queenslander, in a flash. You would know, and God knows, that Melbourne has very few sunny Sunday afternoons. Notwithstanding that, 2,500 people turned out. Last Thursday night in Canberra something like 500 people turned out for a similar meeting which the Australian Labor Party spokesman, Mr Stewart West, and myself addressed.

I can understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is in a very difficult position on this issue. I do not want to make political capital of that. With the Tasmanian Liberal Government opposing any federal intervention and the fate of five House of Representatives seats possibly in the balance, the pressures on him must be enormous. It is at least pleasing to note that the Young Liberals fully support moves to save the Franklin. Difficult though it might be, this is an opportunity for the Prime Minister to adopt a statesman- like policy. It could also be a political plus for him if he were to pay compensation to Tasmania in the form of direct grants for alternatives or for subsidies. It is also an opportunity to act on a very clear obligation that has existed since the very first days of the Fraser Government in December 1975.

It is a matter of urgency that the Federal Government act now. The bulldozers of the Hydro-Electric Commission are already widening an old bush track, gouging an access road into the wilderness. I wish Hansard could incorporate photographs . Any member of the Senate can inspect the photograph I have of Lake Pedder, where a road gouged into the mountain has absolutely desecrated the beauty of the site. Roads are now being gouged into the mountains surrounding the Franklin River. I am informed by my Democrat colleague in the Legislative Assembly in Tasmania, Dr Norman Sanders, that the rate of destruction around this access road has already been substantial. During the recent setting up of a large camp a fire was started which burnt out of control. The threat of fire makes this subject a matter of extreme urgency. One must remember that, as far as we know, there has been no fire in that area for 3,000 years. The human species gets in there and a fire starts within three months. Fire could obliterate this wilderness. The longer the Federal Government waits the more wilderness will be destroyed.

The Federal Government has unequivocally recognised the great wilderness value of South West Tasmania. In July 1980 it put South West Tasmania on the register of the National Estate and in November 1981-I commend the Prime Minister for this-it forwarded the nomination of South West Tasmania to the World Heritage Committee. This is the significance of why this debate is urgent. The World Heritage Committee is due to meet in one or two months time to consider the Australian nomination. It is time to act to ensure that this recognition is not merely window dressing.

What can happen to this motion of mine? It is a significant opportunity for the Senate to send something down to the House of Representatives. It would be unthinkable for any honourable senator to be a party to the gagging of this debate. I tell every person listening in to this debate that Standing Orders facilitate a vote on this question. If any senator, particularly a Government senator, suggests that the business of the Senate be called upon, let every listener to this debate know that that is a gag. If any Labor senator votes for that motion, that Labor senator is also voting for a gag of the debate.
We go further. I quote from Mr Stewart West, the Labor Party spokesman, who has done a marvellous job around Australia addressing meetings on this question. He said in a Press release of 6 September:
The Federal Government must acknowledge its responsibility under the World Heritage Convention and protect the Franklin and Gordon Rivers.
He went on to say:
The recent Federal Conference of the ALP decided to oppose the Franklin Dam and to extend financial assistance to Tasmania. The Federal Opposition is working on the details of any such assistance.

I am informed-I hope that I do not do him a discredit-that my friend, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Button, moved that resolution at the Federal Conference with a most eloquent and moving speech. Therefore, one would hope that the Labor Party would support the Australian Democrats today, because not only can we have the Senate resolving such a question but, if the Senate passes the motion-I would hope that a Tasmanian, Senator Harradine, would also see his way clear to supporting it-I would move, pursuant to Standing Order 336, that the resolution passed today by the Senate be communicated to the House of Representatives by message. That would mean that we could force every member of the House of Representatives to stand up and be counted on this question.

If this debate is gagged today, that opportunity is lost. I give warning: If this debate is gagged, if Senator Hamer, who is the last on the list to speak for the Government, does that or someone else on the Government benches jumps up after him and moves that the business of the day be called upon, we shall oppose that motion, we shall divide the House, and we shall then move the suspension of Standing Orders and that a vote be held on this question, and divide the House again.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not using this for political purposes!
—We would give Senator Jessop the opportunity to stand up and be counted, along with other Liberals, on this question.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has a number of sources of authority that would enable it to save the Franklin and Gordon Rivers and the surrounding environment. Over the last two or three weeks, a number of legal opinions has been furnished that clearly demonstrate that the Federal Government has not only the power but also a strong obligation to act. Even the Attorney-General's Department has prepared an opinion that clearly shows this. Despite the fact that the Attorney-General's office classifies the opinion as an 'internal document' some details were recently disclosed in the Age newspaper. The President of the Australian Conservation Foundation, Mr Murray Wilcox, Q.C., has written an opinion and, along with the Tasmanian Wilderness Society lawyers, he has confirmed the Attorney-Generals, view.

The basis for the Federal Government's obligation is the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation's Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural heritage. This convention has the full force under international law of a treaty between nations. Australia has ratified that convention. Under article 4 of the convention we have recognised that protecting the heritage of our territory is the nation's duty-and is not to be left to a State government. The whole purpose of this convention is to give the primary responsibility of protecting cultural and natural heritage to sovereign States which are signatories to that convention. Australia is the signatory to that convention, not the State of Tasmania, and it is the Federal Government that has that responsibility. Article 4 of the UNESCO convention says :
The State will do all it can to this end, to the utmost of its own resources.

The responsibility is clear and all embracing. The Federal Government should do all it can to protect and conserve our natural heritage to the utmost of its own resources. I should have thought that the language is very plain and very clear.

Article 5 of the convention specifies the steps that each State party shall endeavour to undertake to protect and conserve its heritage. The course of action that the Federal Government needs to take is thus clearly set out. There is a number of sources of authority in the Constitution that the Federal Government can invoke to live up to its international obligations. If there is a relevant source of authority in section 51 of the Constitution that can be applied to the wilderness of South West Tasmania, the Federal Government has the constitutional authority to legislate, and that legislation overrides any inconsistent legislation of a State-as dictated by section 109 of the Constitution. It was that section, section 109, that the Prime Minister recently invoked, quick as a flash, to override John Cain's legislation on nuclear warships entering the port of Melbourne, an action with which the Democrats immediately concurred.

The best example of constitutional authority relates to the Federal Government' s external affairs power. However, the Federal Government may not need to go to the lengths of introducing new legislation. As Mr Wilcox, Q.C., says in his opinion:
As the UNESCO convention is now in force it would appear that regulations could be made to implement the convention and thus protect South West Tasmania.

The avenues to implement the responsibilities undeniably exist. Nothing excuses the fact that nothing has been done to save the Franklin by the Fraser Government. It there is any legal doubt, let the High Court determine the validity of such regulations or such legislation. This is the course that the Federal Government followed and won with the Racial Discrimination Act. Again I pay great tribute to Mr Fraser and to the Liberal Government for forcing that situation to the High Court. Let them do the same on this matter.

It must be stressed that there is no suggestion in this controversy that Tasmanians should suffer in any way. Adequate financial compensation must be offered to assist Tasmania to develop one of the alternatives, be that alternative other hydro-electric schemes in the non-wilderness areas, thermal schemes, connection to a grid, or the many other options that can be opened. Personally, I would prefer to see the maximum amount of available funds to Tasmania devoted to the development and promotion of its magnificent tourist attractions. As far as my affection for Tasmania goes, I doubt whether, even if it goes to extraordinary lengths to provide cheap electricity to attract industry, its future lies in competing as an industrial base with the mainland because of that inevitable stretch of water that exists between it and the mainland; rather, it lies in its magnificent potential as a tourist area.

Yet here we have a petty little government intent on destroying one of the most beautiful areas not just in Tasmania and not just in Australia but in the world. As the letters from 24 of the world's most eminent archeologists have recently shown, the Franklin is not only a national asset but also an international asset . We shall be submerging, I believe, an area two or three times that of Sydney Harbour, or even more. That is the magnitude of what will be devastated in this proposed act of vandalism. And to provide what? It is to provide 170 megawatts or 180 megawatts of power-mere chicken feed! Yet that area is going to be destroyed. But this is also an international asset. As such, the responsibility for saving the Franklin and providing reasonable compensation to Tasmania must fall on Australia as a whole. Compensation is a small price to pay-it is only money-for preserving this magnificent area in accordance with Australia's international obligations.

I conclude by recognising Mr Fraser's problems and the Liberal Party's problems . The Labor Party has overcome its original problems. I could have understood those as well. There is a Federal resolution on this question along the very lines of this motion. I commend the Government to act. But before I do that, I commend the Senate to act because this is a unique opportunity where a vote on a question of national and international significance can be accepted by this Senate on a non-party basis. It can come to a vote. I should have thought that this Senate chamber would be rendered a farce if any person here today engineered a situation in which this debate was gagged and no vote was taken. The time allowed for this debate is two hours. Let this issue be debated. In those two hours let speak any honourable senator who wishes to speak, but at the end of the two hours provided for by Standing Orders let us have a vote. If that vote is taken and it is a positive vote, I will immediately move that the vote of the Senate be communicated to the House of Repesentatives. That would lift the status of the Senate chamber to a new height. It would force the members of constituencies in the House of Represenatives-this is a national issue, so it should force not just the five members from Tasmania, but all the members of the House, particularly Government members-to be exposed to the groundswell of opinion on the mainland of people who desperately want this beautiful part of the world conserved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the motion of urgency being debated today Senator Chipp raised two series of questions. It is necessary to address each of those questions. One goes to the substance of his motion and to the matters which he raised, the other to procedural matters. Senator Chipp raised the procedural matters for the consideration of the Senate. He pointed out that he is a member of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania which is considering this matter. He might have added that the motion to establish that Committee was moved by Senator Macklin on his behalf in September last year. The urgency motion which has been moved by Senator Chipp clearly sets out to cover some of the very same matters which this Senate referred to the Select Committee on South West Tasmania and which it asked that Committee to consider. The terms of reference of the Committee might be of interest to honourable senators . I ask honourable senators to look at the present motion of urgency as I read part (b) of the terms of reference:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal responsibilities in assisting Tasmania to preserve its wilderness areas of national and international importance, including appropriate financial assistance consistent with the State's development needs and options for the State's energy requirements.

The Senate Select Committee has before it the same kinds of considerations as those which we are being asked to address today. The purpose of the Senate Select Committee, as for all other select committees, is to consider all the available information, to digest that information, to collate it, to organise it , to reach conclusions on it and to report to the Senate what it believes to be in the best interests of all Australians. Today the Senate is being asked, without the benefit of those inputs and that consideration, to give an opinion on the very matters which are presently before Senator Chipp's Committee. Senator Chipp sought the establishment of that Committee. The Senate in its wisdom saw fit last September to ask the Select Committee to put under considered judgment the matter of South West Tasmania. It is not as though the Committee has not had time to do some work.

There are appropriate and well established procedures in this chamber for the conduct of both matters of public importance and matters of urgency. We believe- Senator Chipp has confirmed our belief is correct-that it is Senator Chipp's deliberate wish that the matter should come to a vote today; that is to say, that the Senate should express its opinion on a matter before it is in receipt of the report from the Committee which it established to advise it on that matter. My response from this side of the chamber-I hope I speak also for other honourable senators-is that I see no merit in proceeding to a vote today. I see no merit for the Senate or for the committee system of the Senate. I see no merit particularly because of Senator Chipp's role in establishing the Committee , his membership of that Committee and his desire now to get a vote to pre-empt the work of that committee.
I remind the Senate that Senator Chipp appeared on the PM program on 17 May this year. In answer to a question from Huw Evans concerning the whole issue of South West Tasmania, he said:

But it would be a very brave or silly Government that proceeded to give what could be up to $4 billion to a State where 3 per cent of Australia's population reside against the wishes of a Select Committee--
I want honourable senators to note in particular these words-
or while a Select Committee is still sitting.

Those were Senator Chipp's words in May this year. They were right then and they are right now. It is not appropriate that this Senate should seek to proceed to vote on a matter which would pre-empt the work of some of its senators who have already spent a year working on this Committee.

I come now to the substance of the matters which have been raised. Government senators who will speak to this urgency motion will cover different parts of the issue. I open the debate from the Government side of the chamber by reminding the Senate that under the Australian Constitution land management, land use and the decisions about them in any State are largely matters for that State. I ask Senator Chipp whether he really meant to refer to the Government of Tasmania as a petty little government? Is that his opinion of a government of a State? Perhaps he has that opinion because it is a State with only a small population. I ask Tasmanians to take on board this appreciation of the Government of their State by the Australian Democrats.

Decisions on South West Tasmania are primarily the responsibility of the Tasmanian Government. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth has in many instances taken an interest in major environmental issues. I think Senator Chipp drew attention to some of these. The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Country Party have had a longstanding interest in environmental matters. The parties which I represent have had a longstanding interest in South West Tasmania. The 1975 policy statement of our parties recognised the national importance of South West Tasmania. In that statement we said:
We will assist the Tasmanian Government-
I note here that we work with the Tasmanian Government-
in establishing a National Park of world significance in South-West Tasmania to include a substantial wilderness area.
That commitment has been reaffirmed many times since then. In a major address to the World Wilderness Congress in Cairns in 1980, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said:

I have recently advised the Tasmanian Government of the Commonwealth's willingness to provide further practical assistance should the Tasmanian Government decide to proceed with the establishment of a national park.

Between 1977 and 1980 the Commonwealth provided approximately $350,000 for the conduct of detailed resource surveys of the area. This was necessary to identify those attributes of the area which require reservation and management as a park. The report of that survey was tabled in the Commonwealth Parliament on 20 October 1981. South West Tasmania was entered on the register of the National Estate by the Federal Government, by Malcolm Fraser's Government, in April 1980. The register is of those places which have aesthetic, historical, social or scientific significance. We have been active in this matter. We continue to be active. In 1978 the then South West National Park was listed by this Government as a national biosphere reserve under the man and biosphere program of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. Further international recognition came in November 1981 when the Commonwealth, at the request of the Tasmanian Government-that petty little government, as my colleague referred to it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was said by Senator Chipp. As I was saying, the Commonwealth Government nominated significant areas of the South West for the World Heritage List. That nomination included the South West National Park, the Davey River extension, the Franklin-Lower Gordon Wild Rivers National Park and the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park. The nomination has been evaluated by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. That group has recommended the inclusion of the area in the World Heritage List. The nomination for inclusion will be considered at the meeting of the World Heritage Committee, probably in November.

SPEECH.PARA: I summarise the actions that we have carried out. The Commonwealth has had a long-standing concern about the wilderness of South West Tasmania. This concern is real. It is continuing and it has been demonstrated in practical action up to date. There has been a commitment to assist Tasmania in establishing a national park of world significance in the South West and that commitment stands. The South West has been entered in the register of the National Estate. It has been recognised by UNESCO. Substantial areas have been classified as State reserves by the Tasmanian Government and it has been nominated for the World Heritage List. The whole of the South West has been declared a conservation area under Tasmanian legislation. It is not as if the State is out to abandon the whole area and to desecrate it tomorrow.

The development of a plan of management is required for this massive area. I must say something that may not be appreciated by most people who do not live in Tasmania. The area we are talking about-this is a significant area of Tasmania- is not just a small national park in a large State; it is an area which is almost one-quarter of the total land area of Tasmania. Tasmanians, not unnaturally, want a major role in the management of this large part of their own State. As I have stated, the Commonwealth stands ready to assist Tasmania with this task. The question then arises whether we should move to use Commonwealth legislative powers. If we look at the words of the matter of urgency proposed by Senator Chipp we find that is in three parts. First, it states:
The need for the Federal Government to fulfil its legislative responsibilities-
That is fair enough. Governments must fulfil their legislative responsibilities. Senator Chipp then sets out how this should be done. He said:
. . . by legislating immediately to guarantee that the environment . . . is not destroyed by any development in the wilderness regions--

The third element deals with compensation matters. I come back to where I began: Those questions are properly before the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. If it is a matter of great urgency then I suggest to the members of that Senate Select Committee, including Senator Chipp, that it is within their capacity and it has been within their capacity all along to acquaint the Senate of such urgency, to give the Senate a committee view, to acquaint the Senate with what is recommended and to let the Senate work on the Committee report. There has been no such report. There has been no such action. I have enough faith in the people who make up that Committee to know that if there were a consensus, a shared view, about the urgency we would have heard from the Committee.

Senator Chipp said that the Government should legislate immediately. He is advocating in this matter of urgency specifically that we pre-empt by action all the work of that Select Committee, as if it were nought. The motion specifically calls for Commonwealth legislation, not for anything else. It is prescriptive even to the fact that the Government should intervene by passing a law, by making an Act of Parliament to achieve our goals. First of all it may not be necessary for the Commonwealth to exercise its legislative responsibilities by passing further legislation. It may be that within the existing legislation we can respond in every appropriate way. There was nothing in Senator Chipp's presentation to justify in any way why he thought it necessary to prescribe that we should introduce and pass further legislation. Perhaps that is just one of those small details which was not picked up in the drafting of the matter of urgency. Senator Chipp says specifically that we should pass legislation but we have not heard why that is necessary. If we proceeded to pass legislation then it would have implications not only for Tasmania-they are significant implications for Tasmania-and Tasmanians but also for all States and for the citizens of all States. Any Commonwealth law that is passed will have application across Australia.

Is Senator Chipp proposing that the Senate, in advance of the report which it is awaiting, should move to dictate terms to every State in Australia as to how it should proceed to conduct the management of its own land and how it should proceed to discharge the duties which are its under the Constitution? I remind Senator Chipp again that he chose to refer to the Government of Tasmania as a petty little government. It remains the Government's view-the Government does not share that description of course-that those closest to the land generally should be those who make the decisions. The proposition that we should, as a matter of choice, proceed to have control from Canberra is not a proposition which finds general acceptance among many Australians, particularly those in the outlying States among whom, of course, I would include Tasmanians. Many people in the outlying States have a distrust of Canberra which sometimes, I confess, is a little xenophobic. They want the control of their land held close to home.

Our preferred approach is to consult with the State to develop co-operative mechanisms to achieve the goals which we want. I have already set out what those goals are from our policies and commitments to action over a considerable period . Not only do we believe that consultation is the way to go but also consultations are underway. Talks have been planned between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Ministers to assess the situation. I advise the Senate that talks were set down for next Monday, 20 September. I must also advise the Senate that those talks set down for Monday, 20 September, have had to be deferred. The reason they have had to be deferred is that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is not able to take part in them because of his illness. The Minister for Communications (Mr Brown) who is standing in for the Attorney-General requires time to confer and to be briefed on this matter before those talks can occur. They will be carried out at a later date.

It seems quite inappropriate for the Commonwealth to be seeking to take heavy- handed unilateral action in advance of those talks, in advance of consultation and in advance of a whole range of activities which are presently underway. Surely consultation is preferable and surely consultation is the way to go. Further, there remains some doubt about the extent of Commonwealth legislative power. That extent is unclear. Senator Chipp alluded to that in the PM program of 17 May when, in response to a question, he said:
The Parliament itself would virtually have no power as I understand it.

I may be corrected on the context, but I think I am quoting the honourable senator correctly. He was suggesting in that PM program that there was some limitation on what the Commonwealth could seek to do by legislative power.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to the Loan Council.

—Senator Chipp says by way of interjection that he was referring to the Loan Council. I accept the interjection. There are several overriding concerns. We should protect the environment of this country. This Government has a record in a number of areas of active, effective intervention in the defence of the environment.
—Where?

—We have a record of intervention in relation to Fraser Island. We have worked on the problems associated with the Great Barrier Reef and we have worked considerably in South West Tasmania towards the protection of that area. My overriding concern comes back to what might be called parliamentary propriety. I put it to the Senate that it is unthinkable that the honourable senator who himself was instrumental in the setting up of a committee to examine one matter should now come to the Senate and prescribe what the committee's conclusions should be ahead of a report by the committee. He has attempted to pre-empt the kinds of actions which are appropriate and which might flow from that report, and to attempt to have the Senate and the Government take a view on what should be done ahead of the kind of information which the Senate wants from the Committee and for which we are waiting. It is our concern that in South West Tasmania this Government preserves and extends the protection of the wilderness and that we proceed with the listing on the World Heritage List. But we do not intend to do it by haste or in the way that is being suggested. While we acknowledge the importance which Senator Chipp places on this matter, we cannot agree to his urgency motion. We do not believe it is appropriate that it be moved at this time. We certainly do not believe that it is appropriate that the Senate should move to a vote on it today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

No one who lives in Tasmania, such as the Tasmanian senators in this place, are in doubt about that. The proposal which has been introduced into the Senate today as a matter of urgency is very serious. We treat it as a very serious matter and we accept that Senator Chipp and his colleagues have very strong views on it, although I might point out that during the last elections in Tasmania indeed there was a Democrat candidate who proclaimed himself in favour of the flooding of the Franklin. So it even divides the Democrats, although Senator Chipp and his colleagues would have us believe it divides the Democrats less than other parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I want to talk about is the manner in which this matter has been brought forward to the Senate today. TALK.START.PARA: —There is still room for more.

—It cannot be done in two hours, I suggest. It certainly cannot be done in light of the honourable senator's speech. On 23 September, 1981 the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania was established to examine the whole problem of what should be done in relation to the Franklin and Gordon rivers systems in Tasmania. I point out that it was a motion moved by Senator Macklin on behalf of Senator Chipp. In fact the terms of reference were amended by a motion moved by me. The Committee has yet to report, although I understand that it will be able to report soon. I refer the Senate to what Senator Mason, the then acting leader of the Australian Democrats, said about that committee on 23 September 1981. I quote from page 925 of the Hansard of that date. Senator Mason said:

SPEECH.PARA: We hope that it--
That is, the Committee-

will be a vehicle for tapping into and marshalling the many points of view which should come forward in an investigation of this matter. It is designed to be of assistance in practical ways to the people of Tasmania and the Government of Tasmania not only to allow reasonable points of view to be expressed but also to help in financial terms. I refer again to the second of the terms of reference we propose in our motion. It reads:
. . . federal responsibility in assisting Tasmania to preserve its wilderness areas of national and international importance, including appropriate financial assistance;
He went on later to say:

The question of how this assistance might be provided to Tasmania ought to be one of the major preoccupations of the select committee.
