We now have a Senate committee. It is in the process of conducting an extensive hearing, getting evidence from a wide variety of sources about the very problems which have arisen in consideration of this problem. I understand it is to report before long. If it is not to do so, I suggest that the Senate should take some action to hurry up that report, if that is needed. I suggest that the members of the Committee, including Senator Chipp, should do so. But the simple fact of the matter is that this matter is before a Senate select committee. I point out to the Senate that what this urgency motion does, at very short notice, is to ask the Senate this afternoon, within two hours of debate-I suggest a limited debate on such an important matter-to pre-empt the results of the hearings of this Committee. TALK.START.PARA: —You have had seven years to think about it.

—If the honourable senator has been considering it for seven years, I suggest he should not have set up that Committee. If he had made up his mind at the time, I suggest he should question whether he should be on the Committee. If he has been considering the matter for seven years, I suggest that he should give the rest of us more than a few hours notice that he intends to bring up a very serious proposal such as this, a proposal which should have a very serious impact on the Government and on the people. But the practicalities are that if we want to do that then we should present it as a notice of motion and have the debate at the proper time, not debate it as an urgency motion.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the start of my speech, this is a difficult issue. It is an extremely difficult issue for anyone who comes from Tasmania. The parties themselves are divided on the issue. In recent weeks we have had the Young Liberals again coming out very firmly against any proposal to establish any dam in the south-west of Tasmania. As Senator Chipp said, the national conference decision of the Federal Australian Labor Party was that it would prefer no dams in south-west Tasmania but that proper assistance be given to Tasmania if that occurred. None of the proposals, including the proposals of the Australian Democrats, has any real detail as yet. Nothing that Senator Chipp has said today has any real detail as to what form that assistance would be and what sorts of alternatives we can present to the people who will be employed and, therefore, concerned in the development of this dam.

I can understand Senator Chipp wanting some clarification of the issue by debate in the Senate in view of the confusing remarks we have had in recent times from the Government and government representatives. Mr Malcolm Fraser as far back as 1975 when he became the Leader of the Liberal Party said that he supported the policy proposals on Tasmania of the previous Leader, then Mr Snedden. He made it quite clear and quite specific at the time in a telegram to Senator Peter Rae that he supported the commitment to the Tasmanian policies announced by Mr Snedden. These included the protection of South West Tasmania and the preservation of the South West wilderness area. He went on to say that any subsidy required to make the cost of generating alternative electricity in Tasmania should be made available to the Tasmanian Government, that it should be part of Liberal Party policy and would remain part of Liberal Party policy. In recent times we have had no such certainty from the Liberal Party. We have had no such certainty largely because of the varying decisions and statements of senior people in the Liberal Party. The Canberra Times of 23 August this year stated:
The Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman has said the Federal Liberal Party supports the controversial intention of the Tasmanian Government to dam the Franklin River for hydro-electricity.
Mr Hodgman, has stated in a letter he would be ''less than honest'' if he ''did not refer to the fact that the Liberal Party does support the Lower Gordon power scheme''.

One can certainly say, from the remarks made by Senator Peter Rae and Senator Missen in this place, that Mr Hodgman is not referring to every member of the Federal Liberal Party in the Federal Parliament. From the statements of the Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume, I believe we are not quite clear even now about just where the Federal Liberal Party stands. We are certainly not clear from the many and varied responses of the Prime Minister in recent times. It was reported in the West Australian of 15 April this year that when speaking on an Australian Broadcasting Commission phone-in program in Western Australia the Prime Minister said that the decision on whether or not to build a hydro- electric dam in South West Tasmania was a matter for the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian Liberal Party. Perhaps he felt that that was the best thing to say in Western Australia. Perhaps he thought that he would not be reported or that it would not be noted in the eastern States. A little earlier than that we found out that according to Mr Gray, who is now the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Malcolm Fraser had promised him that the Federal Government would provide the finance for the construction of the dam. Yet a few weeks later on a talk back program in Victoria Mr Malcolm Fraser expressed some doubts as to whether the Federal Liberal Government would support the State Liberal Government in financing this dam.

To the extent that there is great confusion about the Federal Government's attitude and about what powers are available for a Federal government to intervene in this area, there needs to be further debate; but more than that there needs to be presented to this place the report of the Committee of which Senator Chipp is a member, the Committee which is asked and charged by this Senate to consider all the proposals and more that are in Senator Chipp's urgency motion. For us to come in here after a couple of hour's notice, to make up our minds after a truncated debate and to vote for a motion such as this which gives a firm direction to the Government I suggest is unreasonable. I hope that we continue the debate. I hope we continue to debate for much longer this serious issue and this serious economic problem for Tasmania. But I hope that we do it in a sensible way and not through the vehicle of a hurried urgency motion in the chamber on a Wednesday afternoon for what I suspect to be largely political purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This discussion today is about protecting a wilderness area. It is worth remembering how a wilderness area is defined. A wilderness area is one which is uninhabited, not cultivated or mined and free from permanent man-made works. Recognition that wilderness areas are something special and worthy of protection is gaining acceptance not only in Australia but around the world. It is urgent that wilderness areas should be protected because , with current trends, in a few years time there will be little wilderness area left of ecological, scientific or cultural importance. The South West Tasmania area is one of only three substantial temperate wilderness areas remaining in the world. For the information of honourable senators the other two are fjordland in the South Island of New Zealand and southern Chile. The trouble is that the South West Tasmania wilderness area is rapidly shrinking. Some say that it has been reduced by half in the last 20 years by the intrusion of other activities.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt at all that South West Tasmania is an area of unsurpassed beauty and that it needs to be protected. The Federal Government has taken an important step in this respect by offering to place it on the World Heritage List. I am sure that when the committee considers it in November it will be placed on that list because it is one of the few areas of its quality left in the world. One difficulty is that Australia has limited experience in managing major wilderness areas. South West Tasmania used to be protected by its difficulty of access and remoteness. That protection is no longer sufficient. Tighter controls are now urgent. A plan for its management is definitely needed. A typical management plan for a wilderness area would divide it up into a core area in which activities were strictly controlled and to which access was deliberately limited; a wilderness zone, which acts as a buffer for the core area, would be reserved for hiking with access only by walking tracks; and a third zone-a tourist and other activities zone-adjacent to the core and wilderness zone boundaries would provide for intensive recreation and additional buffer areas. With regard to the South West Tasmania wilderness area, a broad management plan on those lines was suggested by the report of the South West Tasmania Resources Survey.

There can be no dispute that the proposed developments of the Hydro-Electric Commission obviously affect the wilderness area of South West Tasmania. Recognising that this wilderness area represents a quarter of the land mass of Tasmania, we must look at this decision or desire by the Tasmanian Government and the Hydro-Electric Commission to generate power in this area. Can it be justified? We must address ourselves to three questions: Firstly, what are the non-power advantages of developing this area in the way suggested? Obviously it would damage part of the wilderness area, but there are compensating advantages that must be weighed in the balance such as tourism and the availability of access to a wider community. Those factors must be offset against any possible damage to the wilderness area. The second question to which we must address our minds is this: How much damage would actually be done to the wilderness area. Can it survive as a viable and useful wilderness area if these hydro-electric developments go on there? This is a matter we must look at and I hope that the Committee, as has been mentioned already, will do so. However, I must say that my own opinion is that I do not think the two can possibly be combined. The third question to which we must address our minds is: Does Tasmania really need additional electric power generating capacity?

These are all very complex issues and, as Senator Grimes said, they are very emotional questions in Tasmania. Because of the complexity and the emotional difficulties, on the motion of the Australian Democrats last September, just a year ago, we set up a Senate select committee to study these very matters. I understand that the Committee is due to report next month. The terms of reference of the Committee are worth thinking about. The Committee was charged to investigate:
(a) The natural values of South West Tasmania to Australia and the world; and

(b) Federal responsibility in assisting Tasmania to preserve its wilderness areas of national and international importance, including appropriate financial assistance consistent with the State's development needs and options for the State's energy requirements.

As Senator Peter Baume pointed out on behalf of the Government, this Committee has been sitting for a year. It has been within its power to report at any time with an interim report if necessary. Senator Chipp is a member of the Committee and I hope that, in view of his expressed urgency of this matter, he will press for the Committee to report promptly. I hope it will. I have been told that it will report next month. But the matters that are-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who told you that?
—I have heard that this is the position. If I am wrong, the honourable senator might be able to correct me. When will the Committee report?
—I am not at liberty to disclose that.
—As Senator Chipp is a member of the Committee I cannot correct him on that but I am told that it will report next month.
—Nor would anyone else on the Committee have told you.

—I hope it will be reporting next month. I now turn to the question of the power needs of Tasmania which are one of the key issues involved . The Hydro-Electric Commission's projections for the power needs of Tasmania have been disputed. Whether there really is a need for more power by 1990 has been questioned. Of course, one cannot without a great deal more information, which I hope the Select Committee is getting, possibly answer that.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to something that has happened in my own State of Victoria. Some years ago, people motivated by some of the same considerations questioned the power projection needs of Victoria and managed, among other things, to have the capacity of the power plant at Newport reduced from 1,000 megawatts to 500 megawatts. They were totally wrong and we would very much like those additional 500 megawatts right now. I am suspicious-not very suspicious but slightly suspicious-of people who denigrate the projections of power needs for the community. Anyway, the Senate Select Committee is investigating this very matter and it will, with deference to Senator Chipp, report soon, I hope. I have just been passed a Press release-and Senator Chipp as a member of the Committee might be interested-which reads:
The Committee is working towards tabling its first report on demand and supply options in the Senate in September.
Of course, that is this month and I hope the Committee will be able to meet that objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was by way of Press release.

—Yes. If it is accepted-and we cannot really judge until we have the report-that Tasmania does need the additional power and the development of the wilderness area to provide that power is unacceptable, what alternatives are there for Tasmania? We have to remember that we are talking about only 180 megawatts which means a very small power plant indeed. I think the size of the power plant rules out what to me is the most attractive option to Tasmanians- that is, the use of a nuclear power plant which is certainly the safest, the cheapest and the least polluting way to generate the power. Unfortunately, nuclear power plants are not economic below about 500 megawatts. I think the 180 megawatts required by the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission or the Tasmanian Government would not make that proposal such an economic option.

SPEECH.PARA: Another alternative is coal. Tasmania has extensive and largely untapped coal reserves but the mining of them is likely to be very expensive. Also I understand that they have a high ash and sulphur content. If these coal fields prove suitable, they might be sufficient not only for Tasmania's industrial needs and the conversion of Bell Bay oil-fired power station but also for another 200 megawatt coal-fired thermal station. But this is an option so far quite unproven. The Tasmanians have another problem. If they get into coal-fired generating stations, I think inevitably they will start to have industrial problems. One of the great attractions to the Hydro-Electric Commission is that it has to deal with only one trade union and the industry has been dispute-free. I think it would be very reluctant to take up an option that might involve it in substantial industrial disputes. Of course, I think all honourable senators know that power generated from oil or coal pollutes the atmosphere with large quantities of carbon dioxide which, of course, a hydro-electric scheme does not do.

Another option Tasmania must consider is the use of natural gas from Bass Strait. Victoria uses a 500 megawatt gas fired power station in Melbourne at the moment and that could be an option that might be attractive to Tasmania. Finally , there is the option of being connected to a national grid. This might be attractive but it will be a high cost option and it certainly would be using unproved technology. For all these reasons-and I touch only briefly on them-it is surely sensible for this Senate to wait for the report from the Committee which it has set up for this purpose, before it tries to come to any resolution on any of these problems.

Senator Chipp in the motion we are considering calls for immediate action and for the Federal Government to exercise its legislative responsibilities. He justifies this in part by saying that it is a national issue. It may be a national issue but that does not necessarily give us the power to do anything about it because we are bound by our Constitution and the protection of the environment and the generation of power are State responsibilities. In Tasmania in particular, judging by the result of the last election, both the Government and the Opposition were in favour of power generation by a hydro scheme. It may be-and Senator Chipp quoted one legal opinion on this matter; others have other views-that it is possible we could use our external affairs power to impose a solution on Tasmania. It could possibly be done, as Senator Chipp suggested, under the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention for the Protection of World Cultural and Natural Heritage. I think that would be thin grounds. I think we will have stronger grounds if and when this matter gets put on the World Heritage List. That should be done this November. At the moment I think we have to say that our powers are doubtful but that they will be much stronger after November.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General's Department thinks otherwise.

—There have been a number of differing views on this. It is a matter which is uncertain. I am not saying the honourable senator is wrong; I am saying it is uncertain. The alternative which has been urged on me by a number of people concerned about this problem is the use of our financial power. I think I should make quite clear that we have no power over the use of loan funds . The Loan Council, the decisions of which are binding on the Federal Government , has freed electricity authorities from any form of restriction on the raising of loans. That is an area in which we do not have control. I suppose we could use our section 96 power and direct that tax reimbursement funds be used in particular ways. But this would be a very serious precedent. I think that before we even consider such a draconian solution, we should wait for the report of the Senate Select Committee that we set up to study this matter on our behalf. I agree with Senator Chipp when he said on the PM program in May this year that it would be a very brave or silly Government that would do such a thing while a Senate select committee is still sitting.
—Who said that?

—Senator Chipp said that. This is an important issue; it could be a vital issue. We must not proceed on this matter until we are fully informed on these aspects. We must wait for our Select Committee which has been set up by us for this purpose to report and advise us. Then would be the time to have a full debate on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with great enthusiasm to support my leader, Senator Chipp, and the proposition of this motion, which seeks some action to protect the wilderness area of South West Tasmania before it is too late. I stress and emphasise the words 'before it is too late'. The point is that while the matter is being discussed-I agree that it is being reasonably discussed and debated-the Hydro-Electric Commission in Tasmania is not sitting in a state of suspended animation but is taking the opportunity to start the work of despoiling that wilderness area. That despoiling is being carried out and it cannot be cancelled or repaired by any later decisions that might be taken. This summer will see that work well under way. The Liberal Government in Tasmania has revoked the scenic park status, and therefore any protection provided by that status, for enough land around the Franklin and Gordon rivers to build access roads to begin construction. The Hydro-Electric Commission in Tasmania told the Tasmanian Parliament that it would build a small access road with minimal disruption to the environment. When it was told that it could do so , it went ahead and built a very large road, as we have photographs to indicate. It put up a campsite and burned off a large patch of bush.

SPEECH.PARA: This is only the beginning. This is what has happened already. A great deal of damage has been done to the South West Tasmania wilderness area and more is being done with every day that passes. I know very well that the whole question of the absolute preservation of the wilderness area of South West Tasmania for the world and for posterity is one of great concern to very large numbers of Australians; every day more and more become concerned about it. Very large meetings are being held in every capital city of Australia. Most of them are bigger than political meetings of any kind that have been held for some time. Every time those meetings are held larger numbers of people attend. It is a matter of concern to a very large number of Australians, particularly that special class of Australians, the Tasmanians themselves.

There is no doubt whatsoever that a substantial minority, if not the majority, of Tasmanian people now do not want a dam there. They want the wilderness area of South West Tasmania preserved. I would have thought that by now any government in Tasmania would have had the wit and sense to understand that that is the feeling of those people. At the very least, because of that feeling of so many Tasmanians, there is a very good case for the work to be delayed and deferred. Can it be delayed or deferred? I understand that there is public evidence to the Select Committee on South West Tasmania, so I am not speaking out of turn, from the Department of National Development and Energy that there is no reason in the world for that dam even to be considered before at least 1985. There is no urgency about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that evidence given to the Committee?

—That was public evidence to the Committee. Senator Baume can read it for himself. It might do him some good to see it and then he will understand. The Australian Democrats are acting today in a spirit of emergency, almost a spirit of desperation, because of our fear that any decisions taken by the Commonwealth Government will be too tardy, too late. So often that happens with government, for the very best of reasons, but it does not put Humpty Dumpty back together again, does it? Our fear is that by the time all the words have been said, all the decisions have been made and all the deliberations finished, it will be too late to avert what we see as a disaster for Tasmania, a disaster for Australia and a disaster for the world. As all honourable senators know, that is not just my opinion; it is the opinion of very many Australians, of very large public interest groups throughout the length and breadth of this land, and of the State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened very carefully to Senator Baume, Senator Grimes and Senator Hamer, who pointed to what they see as pre-empting the Senate Committee of which Senator Chipp is a member and which, of course, was set up at the instigation of the Australian Democrats. In this motion we seek-this point has to be made clear ; I have tried to make it already-to buy time to inject into the Commonwealth Government a feeling of urgency about the activities in this area, a feeling which the majority of Australian people already feel. The Australian people want action on this matter and, with the greatest respect to the Senate and to the Committee, I suggest that the fact that a large number of Australians want action on it shows that it might be something of importance and something that this chamber should take some account of. Yet those three speakers tended to make the point that somehow the activities of the Senate are more important than what the public might think. I may have misjudged them and perhaps a later speaker can address himself to that. With the greatest of seriousness, I put the point that we have a responsibility to the people who elected us here which transcends our responsibility to certain other things. It is 12 months since the Senate Select Committee was formed. I do not want to criticise this Committee. I have no intention of doing so and I have no basis for justification for doing so . But it must be said publicly that it is seven years since this matter was first considered and no decision has been reached.

To go back to the Committee, it was hoped that it would report last March. It has been said in debate recently that it may report in September. It may do so. Committees have said that they will report at a certain time and for the best of reasons have found that they were not able to. That may be the case here. Some fresh evidence may come up or another witness or some other matter may have to be taken account of. I do not see how anybody can say at this stage that that Committee can guarantee to report in September, but perhaps it will. I repeat that I have no criticism of that Committee-far from it-but we have a problem not only with this Committee but with a number of committees of this overworked House, the Senate. It is overworked because of the great surge of committee work it has taken on in recent years. One could almost describe it as a kind of log jam. No one will solve that problem easily. No blame can be laid in this place- far from it. I know that honourable senators have given a great deal of their time outside the normal requirements to work on committees and those committees are doing useful work. However, with respect to the committees and procedures of the Senate, great issues do not stand still in a state of suspended animation while we deliberate. For that reason the Australian Democrats see a necessity and urgency for this matter to be raised now. It is not raised in any small pious hope way and not as a debate that has no conclusion. It is raised as a debate which expresses a conscious opinion of this place.

I do not agree with Senator Grimes that this in any way inhibits further discussion of the matter. Of course it does not. It does not inhibit a further debate on the matter. It may even encourage it because a bit of urgency is put into it. In no way do we seek to inhibit that kind of debate. At this stage all we are saying is that the work has started and is going on; the damage is being done. For heaven's sake let us do something about it now. I cannot believe that that is an unreasonable point of view. If anybody perverts it to be an unreasonable point of view I will cast their views and mine to the judgment of the Australian people and see who they think is right on the matter of whether this place should consider the fate of South West Tasmania. It is one of the noteworthy parts of the world which is sought to be preserved not only by Australians but also by brilliant academics from all parts of the world who have spent their money taking out full page advertisements in Australian newspapers saying: 'For heaven's sake, whatever you do, do not destroy this'.

That is a matter of urgency, a matter of morality and a matter of reasonable major public demand for action by this Parliament. It is something which any of us here would scorn at our peril. I greatly urge that we should not take that course of action. Because of that I suggest that we should go ahead with the course of action that Senator Chipp has proposed. It is a reasonable point of view. It does not pre-empt the Committee's work and it does not pre-empt any further discussion of the matter.

I want to speak briefly on two aspects of the Gordon-below-Franklin dam. I refer, firstly, to the economics of hydro-electric power in Tasmania and, secondly, to the alternatives which exist to the use of hydro-electric power in that State. The capital cost of the proposed scheme is estimated by the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission to be $458m-almost half a billion dollars-to generate 180 megawatts of power. That in itself is an appallingly high figure. We are all aware of the effects of inflation, interest rates and unexpected escalations in prices on the eventual cost of things. It is almost certain that this one will cost a great deal more than that half a billion dollars bill. Indeed, if cost overruns are comparable to those already incurred in the Pieman scheme, which is a similar hydro-electric scheme in Tasmania, the project will increase to some three-quarters of a billion dollars, without taking into consideration high interest rates and inflation.

Where would this massive sum come from? Most of it would come from the pockets of all Australian taxpayers. In 1981-82 the Federal Government allocated $469m to the State electricity authorities. This amounted to an average of $31 per head of population for the mainland States but, I emphasise, $81 per head of population for Tasmania. If this dam is to be financed by the people of Australia, as it will if it goes ahead, I for one, object most strongly to my taxes being used to destroy an irreplaceable Australian asset, and I know that many hundreds of thousands, perhaps millions, of Australians share that view.

It is also clear from those figures that the adequate and reasonable compensation referred to in the Australian Democrats motion could easily be found from the funds that the Federal Government would no longer have to provide to the Tasmanian Government for the dam if indeed it were not built. But if the dam is built, what justification is there for this huge capital expenditure? The electricity is not sold for profit. Indeed, the 13 bulk users of electricity in Tasmania, who between them use about two-thirds of the State's electricity, are very heavily subsidised, for no apparent reason. They pay about one cent per kilowatt hour whereas residential users pay about 3c and commercial users about 5c. However, this does not make up the whole subsidy. The rest is obtained, of course, through the Premiers Conference and the Loan Council. Even now, I find myself, as do millions of other Australians, subsidising multinational companies to allow them to produce aluminium in Tasmania while employing only 7 per cent of the Tasmanian work force.

What are the alternatives? There are several possibilities, if indeed more power is needed in Tasmania, and I doubt that that will be the long term situation. The most obvious answer is a coal-fired thermal station which could be built for about half the cost of the hydro-electric scheme. Coal for it could be obtained from within Tasmania and also from the mainland. Continuous employment in a thermal station is much higher than that in a hydro-electric station and the production cost of electricity would be almost certainly lower. So, on that basis, there is certainly no economic justification for what is proposed. Wind power, which is already being used in the megawatt range in many parts of the world, could provide another alternative to the dam scheme. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation itself has estimated that 90 electricity-generating windmills, each of two megawatt capacity, such as are now being built all over the world, could be built in the pasture lands of north west Tasmania and would provide the same amount of electricity as the proposed dam. There would be no pollution or use of renewable resources.

Another factor that must be taken into account is a possible decrease in demand in Tasmania for electricity. The aluminium market is now dwindling. It is not growing at anywhere near the rate projected by the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission when it proposed the dam. That is something for which it must answer. Beside this, consideration must be given to new processes such as that being developed by Mitsui in Japan, which will be ready to go in ten years' time, when the dam is proposed to be completed. That would mean that there would be virtually no requirement at all for aluminium. Unlike the Bayer process, it is a smelting process and does not use much electric power at all. The final point that I want to make is that more electricity per head of population is used in Tasmania than is used anywhere else in the world with the single exception of Norway. That is not due to the fact that the people of Tasmania are wasteful or profligate in the use of electricity but because of the battening on that State of a large number of multinational organisations which, frankly, are exploiting it increasingly with every day that passes. Surely this suggests that the problem in Tasmania is not lack of electricity but inefficient management of the energy resources which exist there. Tasmania's most pressing need is certainly not a massive, expensive, hydro-electric scheme which is designed to destroy vast tracts of our most beautiful and irreplaceable heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in the debate on this urgency motion because, in common with every other Australian, I happen to be interested in the environment, which is an important subject for debate. However, it is a matter of disappointment to me that Senator Chipp has proposed this motion at a time when the Senate has not had the benefit of a report from the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania that the Australian Democrats were successful in establishing to deal with this problem. I remember that when we were discussing the question of forming the select committee, Senator Mason said:

SPEECH.PARA: Just because the Australian Democrats have moved for the establishment of a Senate select committee, such a committee would by no means be the property of the Australian Democrats. We hope that it will be a vehicle for tapping into and marshalling the many points of view which should come forward in an investigation of this matter. It is designed to be of assistance in practical ways to the people of Tasmania and the Government of Tasmania not only to allow reasonable points of view to be expressed but also to help in financial terms.

I agree with that statement. I believe that was a very sensible statement. It is a matter of regret that the Australian Democrats have chosen to deal with the matter prematurely, when the Senate has not before it recommendations that would have been tabled following the examination of a great deal of evidence on the subject. That makes me wonder whether Senator Chipp really understands the committee system of the Senate. Perhaps he spent too much time in the House of Representatives and does not understand how the Senate works.

It is clear that the Australian Democrats perhaps do not appreciate the volume of committee work that is undertaken by the Senate, although I must say that Senator Mason did say that the Senate was overworked because of the great upsurge of committee work that had been undertaken in recent years. Despite that , the Australian Democrats seem to come forward with monotonous regularity with proposals to establish select committees to deal with this, that and the other subject. I believe that that has happened in regard to some seven select committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —All urgent and necessary, I think you would agree.

—They may be necessary, but we have a committee structure that can deal with them quite effectively without overstraining the human resources of the Senate. One aspect that worries me is that we are tending to disregard the work load that is placed upon the shoulders of honourable senators and, equally importantly of course, the secretariats that serve those committees. I repeat, it is a matter of regret that we are now dealing with a subject without having the benefit of substantial facts that could be put before us by the select committee to which I have referred. I understand that a progress report is imminent, that indeed within the next few weeks the chairman of that committee will be presenting such a report to this chamber. I feel that I could debate the question much more intelligently if I had the benefit of the deliberations of that committee before me. Senator Chipp has also referred to the fact that he is a member of that Select Committee. I wonder what would happen if every other member of that Committee chose to take action with respect to this subject independently of the Committee. That could weaken quite effectively the impact of the report that we are looking forward to examining. One of the golden rules of the Senate's committee system is that public statements concerning the operation of a committee during an inquiry are left in the hands of the Chairman. The fact that Senator Chipp has launched this matter before the Senate today could detract considerably from the value of the Committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has stated-I think Senator Peter Baume made it quite clear-that land use and the preservation of natural wilderness areas is largely a matter that falls within State jurisdiction. The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment has recognised the importance of land use policy and is currently pursuing that course in order to provide guidelines to the States concerning the direction that should be taken in the preservation of natural forests and areas such as we are discussing under this urgency motion. Extreme sensitivity was displayed when I wrote to the Premiers of the various States to suggest that the Committee would like to have submissions from the State departments concerned with land use. I had to write to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory on two occasions. Although he was opposed to the idea of the Committee moving into what would appear to be entirely a State jurisdiction, in my second approach I explained to him that it might be of some use to the Northern Territory in regard to encouraging the Commonwealth Government to provide additional finance for certain projects that deal with appropriate land use management programs. I am glad to say that Mr Everingham responded to that and he is now giving considerable support in this matter, particularly on the constitutional side, which I think will be a quite important part of the Committee's report when it is eventually presented to the Senate.

I had a little bother with the Premier of Queensland. Despite my cajoling and suggestions that the States House is not an entirely biased institution and that it has regard to the welfare of the States, he chose to resist the proposition as far as Queensland was concerned. All the other States have come forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is his right to do that, though.

—Yes, we would not quarrel with that. The Committee will look at Queensland in any case because we think there are areas in Queensland that should come under attention, perhaps with the object of providing the Queensland Government with further encouragement in some way or another. I hope that what the Committee says will be of help to the Queensland Government. Certainly the other States have been co-operative in every way and some very interesting submissions have come from their departments. The State Government of Tasmania is co-operating as well. I have no doubt that the Committee will be anxious to receive the report of the Select Committee on South West Tasmania on the Franklin and Gordon rivers. That will be of great assistance to our Committee. I have no doubt that when the report is presented in its full context it will form part of the material under consideration in regard to the overall reference of land use planning that my Committee is dealing with at present.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate what the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) said earlier in the debate; that is, it should be re-emphasised that the Liberal and National Country Parties have had a long-standing interest in South West Tasmania. The policy statement of 1975 recognised its national importance. The Federal Government has given an assurance that it will assist the Tasmanian Government in establishing a national park of world significance in that part of Tasmania. Such a park would include a substantial wilderness area. The Minister also said that negotiations and consultations have been continuing for a long time. He mentioned that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in Cairns in 1980 said:

I have recently advised the Tasmanian Government of the Commonwealth's willingness to provide further practical assistance should the Tasmanian Government decide to proceed with the establishment of a national park.

The Minister also indicated that consultations are continuing, to the extent that it was planned to have further discussions on Monday on this particular subject. That has had to be postponed because the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N. A. Brown) has to be briefed thoroughly on the important question that will be discussed in the very near future. I do not think the Minister was able to say when that meeting will take place but I imagine it will take place within the next few days, or perhaps within a couple of weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know.

—The Minister does not know when that will happen. Having regard to the urgency of the matter, I am sure that the Minister will do all he can to encourage the earliest possible holding of that meeting. I believe that the whole question of the preservation of our environment is important. I would like to see any project of this character carried out with great care, with great regard for the public interest and the need for everything to be done to preserve as much as possible of the environment that we hold dear to us. When talking on this subject on PM Mr Chipp said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it would be a very brave or silly Government that proceeded to give what could be up to $4 billion to a State where 3 per cent of Australia's population reside against the wishes of a Select Committee or while a Senate Select Committee is still sitting.

That takes me back to what I said earlier-it is a great pity that this important matter is being debated prematurely and at a time when the Senate has not the benefit of the very sincere and genuine work that has been carried out by the Select Committee of which Senator Don Chipp is a member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that it is debating a motion of urgency moved by Senator Chipp, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Federal Government to fulfil its legislative responsibilities in relation to the Franklin and Gordon Rivers in Tasmania by legislating immediately to guarantee that the environment of the Franklin and Gordon Rivers is not destroyed by any development in the wilderness regions of South West Tasmania, and to urgently discuss with the Government of Tasmania adequate and reasonable compensation for any lost development opportunities.

As has been referred to a number of times already in the debate, a select committee of the Senate has been appointed to look into these very issues. I am a member of that Select Committee on South West Tasmania. For that reason I feel restrained from speaking about the substance of the motion. If I may say so, Senator Chipp should also have been so restrained. I was amazed this morning to hear about the motion proposed. The Committee sat last night and for two hours I sat next to Senator Chipp. He mentioned his intentions neither to me nor to the Committee as a whole. I hasten to say that I would not have expected it to be formally raised but it would have been courteous to give members of the Committee some mention of the proposal so that they could examine whether they should participate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, what would you have done? You would have run to your Whip straight away. Be reasonable and be honest, for goodness sake.
—I think it would have been courteous for us--
—Don't be a humbug. You know that is what you would have done.

—I would not have run to the Whip, as the honourable senator said . It would have been useful for the members of the Committee to know. We are charged by the Senate with the task of looking at this issue. It ought to be clear to everybody that a member of such a committee is in a difficult position in regard to public statements on matters under examination. That is because, for instance, members of the Committee have information which is perhaps not publicly available. Therefore, one must be careful to keep in one's mind what is publicly known and what has to be kept under one's hat because it is still privileged information. Perhaps a member of the Committee is able to assess the progress of the Committee's thinking, and one must be careful not to give that away. One particularly needs to avoid pre-empting the Committee's conclusions or , on the other hand, repudiating them in advance, knowing what those conclusions might be. In particular, members of the Committee need to show an open mind about the issue and the evidence which has come and which is yet to come and, in addition, they need to be seen to have an open mind about it. It is a matter of propriety, not so much a matter of Standing Orders. As I say, I believe that it is wrong for this matter to be dealt with in this way while a select committee of this Senate is dealing with it.
—Do you propose to allow destruction of the environment in the meantime?

—The Committee is charged with a task. At the very least, I believe that no member of the Committee should be forced to vote on this urgency motion, otherwise I think that it makes the Select Committee a farce.
—We will give you a pair.

—I could not be paired with you. I agree that the Committee's progress has been slow. I have been doing all I can to move it along. It has been frustrating that the Committee has been going for nearly a year without a report being tabled. But substantial progress is being made, and Senator Chipp knows that. Unfortunately, he wants to have it both ways.
—Do you really think that the Committee will report in September or October? Be honest!
—Order! Senator Coates has the floor.

—Senator Chipp is relying on my inability under the Standing Orders to talk about the Committee and about my role on it and his role on it. But let it be seen that the publicly announced position of the Committee is that its first task was to look at demand and supply in the electricity system in Tasmania. The Committee did not say that it must save the Franklin come what may , much as some of us might wish that that happened. The Committee said that it must do its task in an ordered fashion. But it is very difficult to debate this matter as a member of the Committee with both the Standing Orders and the moral obligations that are placed upon one.

SPEECH.PARA: I think, however, that one can refer specifically to the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department, which has been mentioned by Senator Chipp. Senator Chipp mentioned that many legal opinions have been floating around. Apparently, from newspaper reports, the Government has been supplied with an opinion from the Attorney-General's Department. That was leaked to the Age and published about a week or 10 days ago. The Committee ought to have the benefit of that legal advice. But it is a bit much to ask the Senate to vote on a legal opinion which it has not seen. At least one ought to give a few days for that opinion to appear. I would be the first to agree that, in the absence of the Government supplying it formally, we should call it to the barricade as if that was the opinion and let us see whether it can be substantiated. But we must give that a chance to happen. Those of us on the Committee, myself included, have our views and personal prejudices. I think that most people would like to see the Franklin saved, if at all possible. The Australian Labor Party has a platform to oppose the Gordon below Franklin dam.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is possible to save the Franklin.

—You can make that judgment, Senator Mason, but those of us on the Committee must go through the procedure of taking the evidence and hearing the witnesses, and we must be fair to the witnesses who have put in submissions and have not yet been heard. We must not pre-empt that position.
—I only said that it was possible to save the Franklin.

—The Australian Labor Party has a platform to oppose the Gordon below Franklin dam. But while the Select Committee is performing its functions, I have an obligation, as all of us have to some extent, to suspend these views while working as a member of that Committee.
—Who established that Committee?

—The Democrats moved the motion; the Labor Party supported it. We had been saying all along that the Government ought to have a full public inquiry into the issue, under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, to ensure that there was proper consideration from a federal level. The Government refused to do that. As a second best, the Labor Party supported the Democrats' proposal that there be a Senate Select Committee. As I say, because of that I cannot in all conscience talk about the substance of the issue, and I am not sure whether Senator Chipp or Senator Mason expect members of the Committee to vote on the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: On the specific matter of legislative responsibilities, let me make it clear that I am a centralist and I will support the grasping of any power which can legitimately be argued as belonging to the Commonwealth as opposed to the States , that power then to be used responsibly. But I should like to base that on firm legal advice, or even with lots of firm legal advice from non-government sources , and at least being able to read the Attorney-General's Department's contrary view, if it is a contrary view, so as to be able then to say because of that reason or the other reason, I disagree and accept the other legal advice.

The motion calls on the Government to legislate immediately. I would think that if the Democrats thought that immediate legislation were possible, they would not have introduced an urgency motion; they would have introduced a Bill stating the head of power--

TALK.START.PARA: —If we do that, will you support it?
—Of course I cannot say that we would support a Bill that we had not seen. The Democrats have not been able to draft a Bill, yet they are calling for immediate legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I could spend much time waxing lyrical on the beauty of South West Tasmania and on how sad it would be for it to be lost. I am perfectly willing and able to do that; but that is too easy. The motion before us calls for an opinion of the Senate at the same time as a select committee is looking at this issue. Perhaps it would have been more reasonable for Senator Chipp to move that the reference to the Committee, in view of the time that it has taken, be suspended so that whatever information is at present ready should be voted on by the Senate. That has not happened. The Committee is still proceeding. Senator Chipp is participating in it; I am participating in it. Together we are working to make sure that the report is tabled in this place as soon as possible. It ought to have been tabled months ago, but it is still to come. It will come as soon as Senator Chipp and I can help to make it happen. We have a responsibility to do that. Until that is so, we just have to wait for the Committee to operate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate has been ambushed by the Australian Democrats with a matter which has been brought forward only with notice from this morning; no notice of motion was given yesterday or last week. It is an ambush which has taken by surprise the Select Committee of this Senate that is inquiring into the matter of South West Tasmania. It has taken the Commonwealth Government by surprise. It is now being thrust upon us with all kinds of threats and innuendo from the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp). Senators in this chamber, after a brief and hasty debate of only two hours, are to make a decision and take a vote as to whether or not we should pre-empt the people of Tasmania and the Government of Tasmania-a worthy State government in this nation but one which the Democrats have described as a petty little government-in the decisions that they are making about energy supplies in that State and the best management of the resources in the wilderness area in South West Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: But the issue did not begin with this ambush earlier today and will not end with this brief debate in the Senate. It began some seven years ago when the energy priorities of Tasmania showed that there would be a shortfall in the supply of electricity and as the steps were taken to research the best options for supplying the shortfall. Over the last 12 months that issue developed into a major matter of debate in Tasmania, especially in the Parliament. It is now a matter of history that the Tasmanian Parliament was virtually unworkable because of the deadlock between the Houses and because of the differences of opinion between the parties. To resolve that deadlock, or in an attempt to resolve it, in December last year a referendum was put before the people of Tasmania. The referendum offered a choice between a big dam, a small dam and even if not explicitly, no dams at all. At least, that is how the people of Tasmania perceived that referendum because some wrote that third option on their ballot papers. They did not accept just the two options that the Australian Labor Party Government of Tasmania had determined would be put before the people of Tasmania .

It is now common knowledge that the referendum had three blocks of support. A fourth block can also be discerned-that of persons who were genuine informal voters. What was the result? It can be interpreted in various ways, but a number of journalists and other commentators have written about the result of the referendum held in December last year as being a 55 per cent vote for the large dam proposal, a 32 per cent vote for the no dams proposal and a 10 per cent vote for the small dam proposal. In addition, 3 per cent genuinely voted informal. Putting those figures together, a majority of Tasmanians, almost two-thirds, wanted a dam built in this region.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—About one-third of Tasmanians clearly signified that they wanted no dams. I know that Senator Rae will be trying to select alternative ways of interpreting the referendum, but I can only draw from what was written in, for example, the Australian Financial Review. Robert Kennedy, in an assessment of the referendum, wrote that that was the outcome. Clearly, the majority of Tasmanians supported the building of a dam in the Tasmanian wilderness area.

SPEECH.PARA: That was followed by further impasses in the Tasmanian Parliament. Indeed, this issue principally brought about the fall of the Tasmanian Government. The Labor Party Government was tossed out because it lost the confidence of the Tasmanian Parliament. In the election that ensued in May this year, the Liberal Party of Australia was returned to office overwhelmingly, with 48 per cent of the vote and with a clear, explicit proposal in this crucial issue that was before the people. That proposal was to build a large dam in the Franklin River area. Only 38 per cent voted for the Labor Party, which had advocated the small dam proposal. What was the vote for the Australian Democrats in the State elections in Tasmania? PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to allow deductions from assessable income in respect of election expenses incurred in elections for certain bodies.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this amendment Bill is to allow expenses incurred by candidates in local government elections to be tax deductible. The amendment will also cover the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island. The existing provisions of the income tax law with respect to deductions for election expenses are restricted to expenditure incurred by a taxpayer in being elected for membership, or in contesting an election for membership, of the Federal Parliament, or a parliament of a State, or of the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory. There is currently no provision to allow expenditure incurred by a taxpayer in being elected, or in seeking to be elected to local government, to be tax deductible.

This situation, undoubtedly, comes from a time when local government was treated as a convenient way of getting the dictates of State governments carried out in local areas. However, local government has acquired considerable status over the years by virtue of the fact that it is the level of government closest to the people. As part of this development, it has been necessary for central governments at both the Federal and State levels to acknowledge the role of local government as a crucial part of the governance of this country. The Australian Democrats see this Bill as a further step in that recognition and a step which is long overdue.

Candidates for local government incur considerable personal expense in seeking election. The Australian Democrats believe that the ability to represent Australian citizens should be decided upon the merits of the candidate and not on the candidate's wealth. It was for this reason that tax deductibility for Federal and State parliamentarians was introduced. It is for this reason that we believe that it ought to be extended to the third tier of government.

The Government when rejecting this reform in the past has argued that it is not practicable to amend the tax laws in the context of current budgetary circumstances. The Democrats reject such an approach. Obviously, in the Government's view, the time will never be right for such a taxation concession, but why is it acceptable for Federal and State parliamentary candidates to be able to receive this benefit under the current budgetary circumstances and not local government candidates?

The Australian Democrats argue that local government representatives perform a most valuable service in the community. This service is given not in return for a salary despite the fact it incurs a considerable personal expense in terms of time and money. It seems to us that in terms of equity and fairness that those standing for local government, which does not attract a salary, have a greater claim to a tax deduction than those standing for Federal or State parliaments which attract a most reasonable living.

Our argument is simply that those who are prepared to make considerable sacrifices in fulfilling their civic duty at the local government level are entitled, as a matter of equity, to have their election expenses tax deductible. To avoid doing so will be merely to perpetuate a view of local government as second class and to denigrate the extremely important role that local government representatives play in the life of this country. At present there are no limits -in local, State or Federal elections-as to the amount that can be claimed as a tax deduction. The Australian Democrats wish to signal that we intend to introduce amendments soon that will provide limits for all elections.

In respect to local government elections, local government associations, in their discussions on this topic, have suggested that a ceiling of $1,000 for tax deductibility should apply. At this stage, that seems a reasonable figure. The Australian Democrats urge all senators to join us in passing this amendment so that there can be no mistake about where this House stands in fostering citizens to undertake the heavy duties of serving in local governments throughout Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Siddons) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Sales Tax ( Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935 to provide exemption from sales tax for computer software.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to exempt all forms of Australian produced computer software from sales tax for a period of five years from 1 July 1983. The reasons for introducing this Bill are firstly to resolve a problem which has arisen in determining sales tax on computer software and secondly to encourage the development of the Australian software industry.

The computer software industry in Australia is at a crossroads. It is rapidly expanding, yet it is almost of a 'cottage industry' nature in structure. There are literally hundreds of small producers of computer software in this country. The industry shows promise of becoming a significant export earner in an industry which has a grossly unfavourable balance of trade. I am informed that for each dollar of high technology equipment and software exported, we import $ 14. That clearly is ridiculous. Turkey and Brazil can do five times better than that. We are a high-tech colony.

The industry has other features which commend it. Software development is both 'intellect' and labor intensive. Australia enjoys a comparative advantage in a field which is rapidly being overhauled by countries such as Singapore and Japan . Nonetheless, Australian software enjoys a high international reputation. The software industry is thus one that the Australian Democrats believe ought to be encouraged to the greatest possible extent without imposing tariff barriers or inhibiting the free flow of ideas which are essential to the industry's development. The imposition of such barriers would be a hindrance to its rapid development.

Has the industry been fostered? Unfortunately it has not. For at least 14 years it has had to fight for recognition as an industry. The Government seems to regard it as a service industry whose products are not generally sales taxable; but nor is the industry worthy of research grants and other forms of stimulation and assistance. It seems that the Government cannot recognise the value of an industry whose primary output is ideas rather than things in a tangible sense.

The catalyst for the introduction of this Bill was my discovery earlier this year that some firms were being asked for up to three years back sales tax after the Australian Taxation Office apparently re-interpreted the sales tax schedules . Unfortunately this re-interpretation was not made general and so we had the ridiculous situation of software companies in some States paying sales tax and others not paying sales tax. That manifestly is unfair. It seems that the Taxation office is having great difficulty adjusting to technological change. Interestingly, I have recently been informed that at least one company, namely De Forrest software, has won an appeal against the tax office for the repayment of retrospectively applied sales tax. In passing, I might say the tax office was unable to supply me with an estimate of the revenue which would be forgone if this Bill were enacted.

Lastly, I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators, particularly those on the Government side, to the importance of computer software. I believe programs for computer software should be viewed as mechanisms for information transfer, and thus analagous to books. Like books, they should be free of tax. Thus although a sunset clause has been inserted in this Bill, I hope the situation will be favourably reviewed when that time expires. I commend the Bill .

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages wfithout delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

On the 19th July the Prime Minister outlined the Government's decisions on industry and related policies which followed its consideration of IAC reports on industry assistance, protection and export incentives.
In a subsequent statement on 19 July, the Minister for Trade and Resources elaborated the decisions taken on export incentives. This Bill gives effect to those decisions.

The Government has decided that the Export Market Development Grants Act should be substantially amended so that it can more effectively stimulate the market development activities of Australian exporters and that the Export Expansion Grants scheme should be allowed to lapse on 30 June 1983. This decision should be seen in the context of the total package of industry assistance announced by the Prime Minister.

The Government's decision to terminate the EEG scheme and to increase benefits under the EMDG scheme reflects its view that the EMDG scheme provides a more cost effective means of stimulating the growth of exports. The majority of EMDG claimants are firms producing technologically advanced products which by their nature must rely heavily on innovative marketing and promotion to ensure success against international competition. The Government was also cognizant of international attitudes towards performance based export incentives and sees its decisions as being consistent with Australia's objective of achieving a multilateral reduction in subsidies to international trade.
I should now like to draw the attention of the House towards the specific measures aimed at further increasing the effectiveness of the Export Market Development Grants Act.

The EMDG scheme, which was introduced in 1974, provides financial incentives in the form of taxable grants based on eligible expenditure incurred in such activities as overseas market research and development, advertising, the cost of participating in overseas exhibitions, fares incurred in overseas travel and the cost of bringing agents or buyers to Australia where the promotion of export sales is the objective. The Act was subsequently amended in 1978 when a single grant rate of 70 per cent of eligible expenditure was introduced and benefits were extended to the tourist industry.

Taking into account the present difficult international trading climate, the Government is anxious to ensure that exporters are able to make use of the increased benefits as soon as possible. These benefits will therefore apply from the grant year commencing 1 July 1982 for a further six years. Exporters have therefore been provided with a stable base to plan long term marketing strategies.
The main changes now proposed for the legislation are as follows.

The maximum annual grant available to a claimant will be raised to $200,000, compared with the present level of $100,000, with an additional $25,000 for expenditure incurred in Government sponsored promotions. This latter provision will be deleted in line with the recommendation of the industries Assistance Commission. The Government has accepted the view of the Commission that deletion of the provision will improve the effectiveness of the scheme by allowing firms to determine for themselves the form of export promotion which would give the greatest returns in terms of export sales. The doubling of the basic $100,000 ceiling will restore the benefit to a real level commensurate with that existing at the commencement of the scheme in 1974.

Over the period of operation of the Export Market Development Grants scheme there have been changes in the relative importance of the different elements which make up the costs of market development. Expenditures on accommodation and sustenance are now significant charges which previously have been fully borne by the exporter. It has been decided that the Government will now make a contribution to these costs. This contribution will take the form of the payment of an amount of $50 for each full day of the visit up to a maximum of 10 days. This is a set figure and will not be subject to an application of the 70 per cent grant rate. The amount has been set at a level consistent with the 'shared cost' principle inherent in the scheme.

All claims for the payment of an amount under this provision will be subject to detailed scrutiny by the Export Development Grants Board in accordance with procedures developed by the Board in its examination of eligibility of overseas fares. Claimants will be obliged to substantiate to the Board's satisfaction that each visit was undertaken primarily and principally for the purpose of export market development.
Increased Benefits for the Tourism Industry

In its report the IAC drew attention to certain anomalies in relation to the treatment accorded to the tourist industry under the legislation. The Government has accepted the proposition that wherever possible benefits provided for tourism should be consistent with those offered to other industries and has therefore decided to extend certain benefits accordingly.
Regional tourist bodies will no longer be subject to incurring eligible expenditure only in relation to Government sponsored promotions.
The cost of tenders and quotations for the supply of special tourist tenders will now be eligible. A similar provision already exists in respect of the export of goods and services.

The Bill also provides that where discounts are offered to overseas tourist industry representatives as an inducement to buy Australian tourist services, one half of the amount of the discount may be admitted as eligible expenditure. This is also consistent with the treatment of free samples provided to overseas clients by manufacturers under the existing legislation.

The existing requirement that tourist industry claimants must spend at least $5 ,000 other than on fares to have a grant entitlement will be retained. Recognised tourist promotions as approved by the departments of Trade and Resources and Industry and Commerce will continue to be exempt from this provision even though the provision for Government sponsored promotions will be deleted.
The Construction Industry
A new provision has been introduced which takes into account the special problems encountered by the construction industry when contracting for overseas business.

Australian firms competing for overseas construction tenders are often obliged under the terms of the contracts to include certain inputs from local sources. At present the legislation generally results in claims being allowed only in the same proportion as the Australian inputs bear to the total contract value. The legislation has been liberalised to allow all tender/quotation costs to be admissible when Australian input is not less than 20 per cent of contract value and for a proportion of costs, according to a sliding scale value, to be eligible when Australian input falls below 20 per cent. Eligible expenditure will therefore reflect more satisfactorily the costs incurred in tendering for these contracts.
Other Amendments
The opportunity has also been taken to introduce certain amendments which will clarify the legislation and simplify the administration.

These include a redefinition of the eligibility requirements where two or more persons who are relatives travel outside Australia at the same time. In order to simplify administration and clarify the position a discretion previously exercised by the Export Development Grants Board will be removed. Because of this it is proposed that these amendments will not come into operation until the grant year commencing 1 July 1983.

Other changes include an extension of the concept of approved bodies to cover those associations promoting the export of services, industrial property rights and know-how and an extended power of delegation to all members of the Board.

It is estimated that the increased EMDG benefits made available to exporters will be of the order of $36m in the first grant year of operation. Their effects will be felt in the Budget from 1983-84 onwards.

The new EMDG scheme should provide a new impetus to develop export markets. Coupled with the other assistance measures being made available for industry, the means now exist to stimulate further expansion in Australia's international trade with resulting benefits for the economy as a whole. I commend the Bill to the honourable senators.

This Bill which is purely a machinery measure seeks to correct an error concerning references to the Secretary to the Department of Aviation arising from one of the orders made under the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 consequent upon changes in the machinery of government made on 7 May, 1982.
The circumstances I will now outline were brought to the Minister's attention during the last sitting week of August and have given rise to the need for this legislation.

Sub-section 19B (3) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that where reference is made in a provision of an Act to an office that is an office of Permanent Head of a Department and the office has been abolished, the Governor- General may, by order, direct that the provision shall have effect as if there were substituted for that reference a reference to such an office as is specified in the order made by the Governor-General.

The Department of Transport and the Office of Secretary to the Department of Transport were abolished on 7 May 1982. On that date an order was made pursuant to sub-section 19B (3). It provided that, where any provision of an Act, or an instrument (including rules, regulations, and by-laws) made, granted or issued under an Act, being a provision administered by the Minister for Aviation, contained a reference to the Office of Secretary to the Department of Transport, it shall have effect as if there were substituted a reference to the office of Secretary to the Department of Aviation.

Section 9 of the Air Navigation Act 1974 was excepted from this order because it contained provisions of a transitional and validating character in relation to past actions. However, this exception should not have been applied to sub- section 9 (3), which deals with future actions.

Sub-section 9 (3) provides inter alia that after the commencement of the section in the application of regulations or other instruments in force before 1 March 1975, any references to the Director-General of Civil Aviation or to the Secretary to the Department of Transport and Director-General of Civil Aviation shall be read as including a reference to the Secretary to the Department of Transport. Following the machinery of government changes made on 7 May 1982 a reference in that sub-section should have been altered so as to include a reference to the Secretary to the Department of Aviation.

While an order made by the Governor-General under sub-section 19B (3) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 on 26 August, 1982 altered those references as required, this latter order only applied prospectively. Validating legislation is required in relation to the exercise of the powers and functions by the Secretary to the Department of Aviation from 7 May, 1982.

This Bill also validates any act or thing done by any other person or body in reliance on, as a consequence of, or in relation to, the purported exercise of the abovementioned powers or the purported performance of the abovementioned functions by the Secretary to the Department of Aviation.

This Bill also provides for certain references now appearing in regulations or other instrument in force or subsisting under or for the purposes of the Air Navigation Act 1920 before 1 March, 1975 to include a reference to the Secretary to the Department of Aviation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
