TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose the Special Prosecutors Bill but we are very far from enthusiastically endorsing it. Our reluctance is not, of course, based on any unwillingness to see the successful prosecution of tax cheats and frauds-in that respect, our position could hardly have been made clearer in the excitements of recent weeks-but rather we believe that the Bill before us is a load of cosmetic legislative codswallop shovelled together in haste, not because of any need for a new statutory office, not because any such statutory office was recommended by Mr Costigan, but because the Government had the pathetic thought that to do so might divert public attention from its record of negligence and incompetence insofar as the prosecution of tax cheats is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: We take the view that the Bill before us is both unnecessary and inadequate. It is unnecessary for the specific purpose for which it is introduced, namely, the appointment-presumably from the private profession-of a prosecutor to spearhead a task force initiating and instituting both civil and criminal proceedings against tax cheats because the Government could have established such a position and appointed such a special prosecutor to proceed against bottom-of-the-harbour criminals and tax avoiders, or indeed others in the whole taxation area, simply by a wave of the Executive wand.

It is perfectly within the scope of the Commonwealth's Executive power under the Constitution to make such an appointment. It might of course be said that a mere stroke of the Executive wand cannot ensure any independence of the Executive so far as such a position is concerned in the same way that legislation can ensure that independence. As a technical matter, that is perfectly true. But, as I will point out later in the course of this debate, that independence has certainly not been secured by anything in the text of this legislation.

If it is unnecessary, why has the Government introduced it? The first and most obvious reason is simply for purposes of window dressing-to throw up a smokescreen, to lay out some diversionary tactics-to try to turn public and media attention away from the awful mess it has made of the business of exposing and proceeding against tax avoidance and evasion. More specifically though, perhaps, we have the legislation before us as a product of the Government's being obliged to make some concessions to the reality of its failure to perform effectively in the policy, administration and law enforcement machinery areas, and to be seen to be doing something about that manifest failure. The indictments made by Mr Costigan in his report against the quality of the Government's administration of the law in this area stand unanswered despite the pathetic attempts from various remnants of the back bench and the bureaucracy in recent days to throw the credibility of that report into doubt.

The most obvious thing about the Government's attitude remains the sheer obliviousness of its senior public officials as was most encapsulated by the remarks of Mr Neaves in the hearing of Estimates Committee A on Monday that he simply did not see the 1973 Perth case as a test case. Indeed, he failed to appreciate the possible meaning of the concept of a test case in the context of criminal proceedings. He perceived it simply as a routine matter and, as we all know, within the Attorney-General's Department routine matters are the kinds of things for which year long delays and multiple years of delay are the norm rather than the exception.

So there has been a failure of administration and nothing that this legislation contains can possibly serve to disguise that. Indeed, the second reading speech which introduced this legislation was thoroughly self-incriminating in this particular respect. The Government is bending over backwards to reassure us-to reassure an understandably sceptical public-that it really does now mean business. Thus in the first paragraph of the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) we have the assurance that the cases to be handled by the special prosecutor will be:

of such special character that the community should not be left in the slightest doubt that prosecutions will be handled with the highest professional competence with complete independence from any extraneous consideration.
Further down is the following additional statment:

therefore, a clear indication of the Government's intention to proceed with the utmost vigour in these cases regardless of all considerations other than the proper enforcement of the law and the protection of the revenue.

Of course, by those statements the Government is condemned out of its mouth. The very use of the words 'highest professional competence' in the first paragraph I quoted, and the phrase 'with the utmost vigour' in the latter paragraph, is the clearest possible admission that neither of those qualities has dignified the shameful performance of this Government in relation to tax avoidance and evasion over the past seven years. The record has been one rather of massive incompetence and culpable lack of vigour. The Special Prosecutors Bill is simply a straw for this drowning Government to clutch, but we know and the Australian public knows that it is much too late. Two senior Ministers are going down beneath the surface and this Government is going with them.

So much for the necessity of the Bill. What about its adequacy to perform the task that it sets for itself? I believe, and the Opposition believes, that the Bill is inadequate as a response to the more fundamental and important questions of how Commonwealth prosecutions in serious matters are in fact to be conducted in the future. It simply does not address itself to the question of whether an effective semi-independent Commonwealth prosecuting agency can be established, not just on an ad hoc basis but on an effective permanent basis, out of the wreckage of the Crown-Solicitor's Division of the Attorney-General's Department, which division has demonstrated its manifest incapacity to perform in that kind of role.

The vulgar haste which has accompanied the preparation and introduction of this legislation has really rendered quite impossible on behalf of the Government any consideration of the issues associated with the establishment in the longer term of such a semi-independent prosecuting agency. There is no indication that the Government, in the context of drafting the legislation, has turned its mind to this question. Indeed, in the course of the Estimates committee hearings last Monday there was again admission that the Government had not done so, in other than a desultory way, at any stage earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any parallel with the pursuit by Senator Bobby Kennedy, as United States Attorney-General, of Hoffa?

—I would have hoped that we would be likely to be more successful than Bobby Kennedy proved to be and that we could also avoid the retribution that was visited upon him by his ungrateful criminal clientele.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to address his remarks to the Chair.

—As always, my comrade Senator Mulvihill has made a pleasant, cheerful and helpful intervention in the debate and I hope that it will be treated by the Senate in that spirit. I wish later to say a little more about the kind of machinery model that might be appropriate for the longer term but for the moment I wish to spend a few minutes on the substance of this Bill and some of the claims that are made concerning it. First, there is the question of the functions to be performed by the special prosecutor, which are identified in clause 6 of the Bill. Those functions, so far as the Commonwealth is concerned, are to institute prosecutions under Commonwealth or Territory law, to carry on prosecutions under Commonwealth or Territory law, to take on or supervise actions for civil remedies on behalf of the Commonwealth and its authorities, and to perform, so far as the States are concerned, any functions that might be conferred on the special prosecutor by State legislation in relation to, again, the carrying on of institutional prosecutions for offences against State law.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the functions so far as the Commonwealth is concerned are only in respect of those matters in the first instance which the Attorney-General specifies as appropriate for the special prosecutor to take over. It is obvious that at the moment the Commonwealth has not thought beyond the immediate context of taxation prosecution. The primary function of the clause seems to me to exist as a kind of vehicle for such further and better thoughts in this area as the Commonwealth may later have. However, manifestly the primary functions that the special prosecutor will be performing-as much has been stated by the Government- will be in the area of taxation evasion and avoidance.

There is something of an incongruity-a matter to which the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills has drawn attention, and about which no doubt my colleague Senator Tate may wish to say something-in sub-clauses (2) and (3) of clause 6, to the extent that it is there stated that no objection can be taken to a particular proceeding on the ground that it does not relate to a matter which has been specified by the Attorney-General. Thus, even though the functions of the special prosecutor at the Commonwealth level are in the first instance to be only those which are defined or specified by the Attorney-General , if he chooses to branch out beyond those circumscribed functions apparently, by virtue of the operation of this clause, no legal redress can be resorted to against him. Therefore, as I say, there is an incongruity in those provisions. It may be something to which the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner ) will give his attention in reply, explaining precisely just what is the justification for taking away with a second hand what is, in this instance, given by the first hand.

However, a rather more important question that arises from the text of the Bill is just how much it does to secure the independence of the special prosecutors who may be appointed under it. Of course, much attention has been given, in the course of promoting this legislation, to that notion of independence. I have cited already one or two passages from the second reading speech which are redolent with that theme. Again, the very opening words of the second reading speech make the point thus:
The purpose of this Bill is to enable appointments to be made of Special Prosecutors with clear authority and independence to institute in exceptional cases and carry on necessary prosecutions.

Therefore, a lot of attention has been given to the question of independence. That theme was repeated by Mr N. A. Brown, who has acted for the last few weeks as surrogate Attorney-General in the other place--

TALK.START.PARA: —De facto.
—Both terms may do. At page 1289 of Hansard Mr Brown is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . above all, the means is a resort to an independent person. It is important that that point should be made.

Indeed, it has been made during the barrage of propaganda that has been associated with the Government's presentation of this legislation. But really, the assertion that independence is vested in these special prosecutors is laughable. The special prosecutor is so hedged about with controls and constraints that he is barely more than an arm of the Attorney-General's Department. I make it clear that I do not necessarily believe that to be wrong in principle, rather that humbug is to be avoided at all costs, and to say that a completely independent statutory set of conditions is created by the legislation is humbug of a very high order indeed, especially when one looks at the text of the Bill. As we have seen, clause 6 makes clear that the functions exercised by the special prosecutor are to be those defined by the Attorney- General, albeit, as I indicated a moment ago, the force of that particular constraint is somewhat mitigated by the following sub-clauses, which make it impossible for that limitation to be enforced.
More importantly, if we look at clause 7, we find that it provides:
The Attorney-General may . . . give directions or furnish guidelines to a Special prosecutor with respect to the performance of his functions.

Not, it is true, in relation to any particular case, but again there is the clear notion that, with respect to a class of matters and the way in which he deals with it, the special prosecutor can be thoroughly hedged around by the approach demanded of him by the Attorney-General of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I interject constructively to ask how you would suggest drafting that provision?

—I make clear that I am not saying specifically that it is inappropriate for a special prosecutor or, for that matter, any other authority created by statute to be subject to Government guidelines and directions. I will make very clear later that I believe a preferable model is provided by the Director of Public Prosecutions in the United Kingdom, who indeed operates, save in exceptional cases, under directions from the United Kingdom Attorney-General. I simply make the point that the question of total independence from the Executive, for better or worse, has been one of the most vaunted claims made on behalf of the Bill. I make the point that when one looks at the relevant provisions of the Bill one finds it very difficult to sustain an argument that there is indeed independence. I made clear before, and will again, that I do not necessarily think that there should be absolute independence. I just do not think that there should be humbug in respect of claiming independence when, in fact, it does not exist.

SPEECH.PARA: Under clause 11 (1) the Attorney-General determines the remuneration and allowances of the special prosecutor. As we all know-the point was made by Russell Schneider in the Australian not so long ago-in practice financial control can be one of the most powerful inducements to conformity that it is possible to imagine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again may I interject constructively to ask what you would propose, bearing in mind that the position is not intended to be permanent and that what is, in effect, happening is the briefing of counsel in specific cases.
—No one knows.

—As Senator Tate says, no one knows whether it is to be permanent. It may be perfectly appropriate for fees or remuneration to be set by the Attorney-General. Indeed, in the context of this legislation and from the assumptions on which it is drawn, it would be very difficult to frame that provision otherwise. I am only saying that this legislation is totally unnecessary because it merely wraps up in a legislative costume what is, in effect, a set of executive discretions of a thoroughly familiar and, for the most part, unexceptionable kind. My point is: Why in the hell are we wasting parliamentary time in debating a piece of thoroughly unnecessary legislation? Answer: Because it represents a cosmetic enterprise designed as a diversionary tactic by a government that is in a hole and wants to be seen to be doing something, however unnecessary in practice that might be.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the nub of the criticism. I do not want any of the remarks I make about particular clauses to be taken in any other context than that. They are simply parts of the case I am making, that we are not here talking about an independent statutory authority free of any influence either of a transitory or of a potentially permanent kind. That is exactly the same answer as the answer to the previous question. Similarly, the same point can be made in relation to clause 17 (1). The Attorney-General must approve those whom the special prosecutor employs. Under clause 17 (2), the Attorney-General must approve the engagement by the special prosecutor of consultants. Clause 18 makes provision for other services to be made available to the special prosecutor from the Australian Federal Police, the Public Service Board and so on. Again, that is if the Government chooses in the exercise of its executive discretion to make those services available. In practice, of course, the effectiveness with which this outfit, this authority, will operate, will be entirely dependent on what resources the Government chooses, under these various provisions, to make available to it at any time. The special prosecutor is then in all these different ways simply a creature of the executive government. He is established by statute but he may as well not be; he may as well be simply counsel briefed by the Commonwealth in the way that counsel, consultants and people who assist counsel, so often are in the conduct of ordinary prosecutions. The thing, as I said, is just a load of cosmetic codswallop to the extent that it purports to be anything more than the dressing up in legislative form of a straightforward, familiar set of Executive appointment discretions. I repeat-it seems to be necessary to repeat it-that we do not make any great argument for the necessary independence of the special prosecutor. We do think it is appropriate, in the interests of ministerial responsibility, if that concept has not been totally denuded of content in recent times, and in the interests of political accountability, that there be a degree of control of whoever is running Commonwealth prosecutions and that that control be to a significant extent retained at the ministerial level by the Atorney-General. We do not dissent from that. We simply make the point yet again that claims of the kind that have been made about the independence of the office are quite spurious in the context of this particular legislation because there is no such independence.

I finish on a more constructive note, as I hope I foreshadowed I would, by making some suggestions as to what may be the way out of the mess that the Commonwealth has got itself into with its conduct of prosecutions and because of the manifest failure of the Crown Solicitor's Division to be a credible outfit in this respect. It is important that a more professional, aggressive, lively and effective approach be adopted to Commonwealth prosecutions generally, not just in the taxation area but across the whole spectrum. With the morale in the Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney-General's Department in its present debilitated condition I believe that it may now be almost impossible to create such an effective agency within that environment. There is, after all, a fundamental difference between the two basic functions that the Crown Solicitor' s Division performs. On the one hand it operates, and always has operated, with a mixed degree of success, as a solicitor to the Commonwealth and to the departments and agencies of the Commonwealth. It is a 'firm of solicitors' engaged in drawing up agreements and contracts, giving advice on relatively routine matters, including some of some complexity, giving representation to those Commonwealth agencies and departments when they are proceeded against in civil actions by outsiders for injury or anything else-the familiar run of solicitors' functions. That is an identifiable role and one which, as I say, the Crown Solicitor's Division has performed with mixed success over the years.

The other part of its role is a very distinct one. It is the conduct of prosecutions in matters of significance. It has not traditionally conducted prosecutions in every case in which the Commonwealth has sought the recovery of debts or wanted to take action of other kinds-there are many areas in which departments and agencies conduct their own prosecutions-but it has been traditional certainly for matters of any significance for the Crown Solicitor's Division to play that role.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you foreshadowing any change based on this distinction?
—Yes. The honourable senator should hold his horses; all will be revealed.
—Just wait another half an hour or so and we will get there.

—No, three minutes. If the honourable senator does not want me to contribute constructively or in any other way to this debate, if he is impatient to go and have his pre-dinner whisky and settle down for the evening, I would be only too delighted if he left the chamber. I hope that anyone interested in a more thoughtful contribution to this public policy issue that has been revealed in the approach of the Government to this legislation will stay around for just another minute or two more.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, when I was interrupted in such an untimely fashion by the dinner bell, I was in the middle of saying that I believed there was a case for separating the two basic functions of the Crown Solicitor's Division-that of a general solicitor for the Commonwealth and its agencies, and that of a prosecuting body-and creating a separate agency with prosecution functions, an agency which may well develop as a result of separate establishment a whole new esprit de corps and professionalism, which is conspicuously lacking in the present Crown Solicitor's Division. It appears to the Opposition that the model for such an agency, a prosecuting authority independent or semi-independent of government, may well lie in the very long- established United Kingdom Directorate of Public Prosecutions, which has provided the foundation for the new approach to prosecutions and the machinery of prosecutions now being considered by the Cain Government in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: In the United Kingdom the Director of Public Prosecutions acts under the superintendence of the British Attorney-General and is responsible to him. It is a semi-independent agency in the sense that there are some crimes for which the DPP has sole discretion to prosecute, whereas there are others concerning which he acts on instructions of the Attorney-General. In the Australian context, it might be thought that the most appropriate system-my inclination is to believe this-is one in which the DPP has the primary discretion in all matters but is capable of being overruled by the public direction of the Attorney-General in circumstances where the Attorney-General is prepared to put that direction on record and take the political risks of doing so.

The DPP in Britain is not the prosecuting agency for all crimes; rather, it is for the more serious crimes in the country, with the police prosecutors being the prosecuting agencies for less serious crimes-apart from those initiated by private individuals. A succinct description of what the DPP is about appears in the official British Government publication 'Criminal Justice in Britain' from which I read the following short extracts:

The Director is under a duty to prosecute crimes such as treason and murder. The police have to report to him a further list of offences, including serious offences against the person, sedition, criminal offences by police officers and offences relating to obscene or indecent publications. The Director does not prosecute all such cases referred to him by the police but may do so in any one that appears to be important or where he thinks intervention is necessary, otherwise the proceedings are conducted by solicitors employed by the police. The Director also considers whether proceedings should be taken in cases reported to him by Government Departments. In addition, he advises the police and others concerned with the administration of the criminal law.

There is a reference to the review of the functions of the DPP and the various prosecuting agencies around the country run by the police forces now being conducted in the aftermath of the Phillips Royal Commission on Criminal Investigation. The account goes on as follows to describe those who actually do the work:

The professional officers of the Director's Department are barristers or solicitors. Although the former have a right of audience in the higher courts, they do not in practice appear except in magistrates' courts where they and their solicitor colleagues conduct summary and commital proceedings. When cases go to trial counsel in private practice are instructed to appear on the Director 's behalf. At the Central Criminal Court in London these are drawn from a panel of 'Treasury Counsel' appointed by the Attorney-General.

I imagine that those Treasury counsel, in the Australian context, would be very similar to the sort of persons who are anticipated as being special prosecutors, in effect, under this legislation. It is that melding of a semi-independent permanent agency with the tapping of specialist resources for specialist cases that I believe might provide an appropriate model for Australia, not in absolute terms but one which would at least give us food for thought. The Opposition believes that that justifies more attention than, on the evidence of recent public statements from the Attorney-General's Department, it has so far received . We believe that what is needed to efficiently conduct prosecutions of tax cheats and other major Commonwealth criminal defendants is not just an ad hoc system of special prosecutors of the kind provided for in this Bill.

We do not oppose the Bill, because it does not do any particular harm; but nor does it do any particular good. As we see it, it does not do anything by way of meeting the longer-term need for an effective semi-independent Commonwealth prosecuting agency. It is just an obviously political solution to what is very obviously the Government's present political problem-the Government's need to drastically refurbish the image that it now so deservedly enjoys, as a government soft on tax cheats, soft on tax evaders, soft on business and professional tax avoiders, but hard as nails on the ordinary pay-as-you-earn income earners who, because of this Government's neglect and incompetence, and in some instances even its corruption, have been subsidising tax cheats to the tune of about $30 a week over the last seven years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans has, both before the dinner break and for the past seven minutes, given us one of the more pathetic attempts to belittle a major measure taken by a government expressing its concern and its preparedness to act in relation to a national problem. SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is a positive, forward-moving piece of legislative and administrative action by an Attorney-General who, until yesterday when unfortunately and unavoidably he commenced his sick leave, has been extremely active in taking action to prevent what has become a national pastime. Let us look at the matter with objectivity instead of with party political particularity. From the speech that Senator Evans made, what he and the Opposition mean is that they agree with the legislation but they are not prepared to say so. They agree that it is a development but are not prepared to say so. They agree, but are too small-minded to acknowledge that the present Government has made a forward step.

I am disappointed to find that Senator Evans has not had the decency and courtesy even to remain to hear some of the remarks which I propose to make shortly about other aspects of what is apparently the shadow Attorney-General's major attack. A major attack? We have listened for 30 minutes to what is a pathetic bottom-of-the-barrel scheme attempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very shallow now.

—It is a very shadowy exercise on the part of the shadow Attorney-General. I pass on to some of the other points which can be made. The first point is that people should realise and be prepared to acknowledge that since 1977 the present Government has introduced more than 30 measures, successfully guided through the Parliament, to overcome some of the legislative shortcomings and the ingenuity of tax avoiders and tax evaders. I refer to a few introduced during this period.

SPEECH.PARA: General anti-avoidance provisions were introduced in 1981. Trading stock schemes were legislated against in 1977, 1978, 1979 and 1981. Legislation in relation to the misuse of gifts was introdced in 1978 and 1982. Legislation in relation to trusts being misused was introduced in 1978, 1979, 1980, 1981 and 1982. The avoidance of tax in relation to dividends was legislated against in 1978. Legislation was introduced against trafficking in current year loss companies in 1978. Legislation against sales tax avoidance was introduced in 1978. Pre-payment schemes were legislated against in 1979. Legislation against carry forward of losses generated under tax avoidance schemes was introduced in 1979 and 1981 and more is about to be introduced in 1982. Legislation was introduced in relation to depreciation problems in 1979. Straw companies and trusts were legislated against in 1980. Legislation to remove problems which arose in relation to the definition of ' public company' and in the effective collection of taxes were legislated against in 1977. Legislation introduced in 1980 in relation to royalties received by non -residents. In 1981 legislation was introduced with regard to payments to employees. The diverting of income through tax exempt bodies was legislated against in 1981. Transfer pricing was legislated against in 1982. Tonight we have before this chamber a further measure by this Government- conscious of the industry which has been created, conscious of the problems of the individual pay-as-you-earn taxpayer, and conscious of the problem that some people were avoiding tax while others were having to pay it-designed to overcome these problems. For Opposition members to come here tonight and attempt to belittle what is being done effectively and conscientiously by this Government is, I think, unworthy of them. Let me refer to what has happened. The Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act was passed in 1980.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get your tongue out of your cheek.

—Since that time not even Senator Grimes would find it possible to allege that a tax avoidance industry is flourishing in Australia. As I said in this chamber on one of the other occasions when we had been rather monotonously going through what has been happening in relation to this matter, the tax avoidance industry is so dead that one of the chief promoters of one of the major schemes bounced a few cheques the other day. I do not think anything can be any more dead than that.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators of who it was who established the inquiries that produced the results that have been the subject matter of debate in this and the other chamber. The present Federal Government established the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan inquiries were established by Liberal governments. They established them, supported them and gave them every assistance that can be given by a government determined to take steps to overcome a major problem. Those inquiries have revealed information which could not have been revealed unless either a parliamentary committee, with the flexibility, opportunity and powers it has, or a royal commission had been established for the purpose. Those inquiries have revealed matters of serious concern to Australia. But what have we had as a result of the publication of these Liberal-National Country Party inspired inquiries? We have had small, mean objection and an attempt to take advantage of and to blame the very people whose concern has led to the establishment of the inquiries and the subsequent revelations.

This is what is a matter of concern to the people of Australia: Why is it that the Australian Labor Party is endeavouring to make small-time party political mileage out of the honest attempt of a government to get to the bottom of what is happening in this country and the defects of the legislation and the advantages which are being obtained by some of the people who, I believe, could be described only as the crooks of this country-the tax avoiders, the people who are not prepared to play their part in looking after the interests of our country? I can only say that I believe that for this Government to be criticised by the Opposition for having achieved the greatest breakthrough in ascertaining the nature of tax avoidance in this country and for having achieved the greatest breakthrough in taking the legislative steps necessary to overcome tax avoidance is only small, petty party politics. I cannot understand why Opposition members are not prepared, with a greater degree of concern for the best interests of this country, to give credit where credit is due. With the knowledge that neither this Government nor any other government is perfect, I say that if ever there has been an example of a government prepared to take every necessary step and to cop the political flak that can come from small minded opposition, this Government has provided it on this matter of tax avoidance. I compliment both Mr Howard, the Treasurer, and Senator Durack, the Attorney-General, for having withstood all that and pursued a course of action notwithstanding the fact that many people may have been put off by the way in which it has been twisted against them.

I pass now to the detail of the Bill we are debating. The Bill proposes to create positions of special prosecutors. It is entitled the Special Prosecutors Bill 1982. One of its most important parts deals with independence. The appointment for at least the duration of a prosecution of a prosecutor who knows that he will, without fear or favour, be able to pursue as he sees it objectively and professionally the responsibility which he has been given is, I think, an extremely important provision. There have been troubles with this type of appointment in some countries. I do not believe that there is an Australian example of this, but one could point to the position of Special Prosecutor Cox in the Watergate affair in the United States. He, having got hot, having got to the heart of what was going to hurt the government of the day, had his commission withdrawn. That is the sort of situation that this Bill is designed to prevent.

I felt that Senator Evans tried very hard to belittle an important piece of proposed legislation without making any real point as to why it was not an advance on the present situation. Members of the Labor Party have made this whole issue of the persecution of tax offences a highly political one. They have created the necessity for this very piece of legislation to ensure that we are in a situation in which a person or a group of people appointed to prosecute individuals in society can feel free to do so without the fear of being subjected to political interference. That is the fear I have following certain actions which took place during the term of the last Labor Government from 1972 to 1975. I need refer to no more than the dawn raids on the offices of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to provide an example. The speech of Senator Evans tonight is a further example of the importance of the sort of independence and protection which the prosecution, on behalf of the public of Australia, will be able to obtain as a result of the legislation which we have before us.

It seemed that the main argument of Senator Evans was that the special prosecutor is not really independent and that the Bill does not really represent a departure from existing arrangements. He suggested, therefore, that it is unnecessary. This was the attempt to which I referred earlier to belittle an important piece of anti-tax avoidance legislation. However, the contrary appears when one examines the position of a special prosecutor as opposed to the position of a barrister briefed to prosecute. The brief to prosecute can be withdrawn at any time. While it is virtually unthinkable in this country-I hope it will continue to be unthinkable-that there would be a situation where that action was taken, the fear, the prospect, the possibility and particularly the smear of innuendo and twisting campagin of the past few weeks mean that there is a need to give an assurance, a protection, to any person who engages in the important public role on behalf of the people of prosecuting to the end, successful or otherwise, people who are alleged to have been engaged in major activities of what I would describe as an un-Australian kind-people who have avoided their fair share of tax, people who have their responsibilities as citizens of this country.

Whilst it may be unthinkable that that could happen, I believe that the events of the past few weeks have made it appear that it is a real prospect that prosecutors will be treated as have the very objective and efficient officers of the Attorney-General's Department such as Mr Neaves, the Secretary of that Department, and Mr O'Donovan, the Crown Solicitor, who on Monday were examined at great length but with little success. On Monday they had their opportunity, through the operation of the Senate Estimates committees system, to tell their side of the story for the first time. I believe that that was one of the most telling parts of the whole debate that has taken place. That was the only opportunity those officers had to tell their side of the story. The shadow Attorney-General who is an extremely competent cross-examiner attempted throughout the day to examine them and find defect but he failed to do so. That examination was the greatest justification of the Attorney-General and the Attorney-General's Department. There are certainly problems and action has been taken in relation to particular problems. When there are a few thousand officers in a department I cannot imagine that one would not find possibly one or two officers who are less than perfect. Even within the Labor Party, that could happen. As perfect as members of the Labor Party are, there may be one or two who are less than perfect.

The position that is proposed by this legislation is that a special prosecutor will be able to have the certainty of appointment, protection and independence to pursue through to the end the task of prosecution without the risk of the withdrawal of a brief as could happen and as did happen in the case that I mentioned earlier of special prosecutor Cox in the United States in the Watergate affair. The objective of the legislation is to provide a complete assurance to the community that in exceptional cases where a special prosecutor is appointed he has security of appointment and can pursue his duty without the slightest risk that there will be political interference with his capacity to do just that. I believe that that alone is sufficient justification for the piece of legislation.

I should like to pass to a couple of other points that arise in relation to this matter. I refer to the question of independence and accountability. This is a vexed question and a question which needs more consideration and far more debate than has been given to it by this Parliament, academia, the media or the general public of Australia. The question of accountability is interrelated with the question of independence. The greater the independence that is given, the greater the degree and the requirement for specific types of accountability. I am appalled at times to hear some of the comments made by people in some areas of some industries. I refer particularly to some of the people interested in marketing authorities in Australia who put forward the view that the Parliament should legislate to give them an advantage but should not require the slightest degree of accountability out of the advantage given. That to me is an untenable situation. If one uses legislative power to give people a task and independence- -

TALK.START.PARA: —And a monopoly.

—And sometimes a monopoly, the very essential ingredient that follows is that there must be both accountability and timeliness in the accountability. That is one thing that I think is an important feature of this legislation. Here we are creating a position whereby we give to the special prosecutor an independence. The quid pro quo for that independence is that he must be accountable to the Parliament. Therefore, I warmly support clause 20 of the Bill which requires that form of accountability. I refer briefly to clause 7 which relates to the giving of directions by a Minister. I think again it is important to see this in its proper perspective. Senator Evans gave one perspective; I should like to give another. Clause 7 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General may, by notice in writing, give directions or furnish guidelines to a Special Prosecutor with respect to the performance of the functions of that Special Prosecutor but the Attorney-General is not entitled to give directions or furnish guidelines in relation to a particular case.
Senator Evans referred to that. Let me refer to sub-clause (2) which states:
Where the Attorney-General gives any directions or furnishes any guidelines to a Special Prosecutor under sub-section (1),--
I have just read that sub-section-
the Attorney-General shall cause a copy of the directions or guidelines to be published in the Gazette.

If ever there were a basis for the complaints made by Senator Evans about the lack of independence of a special prosecutor, it could be destroyed by the very proper requirement which I totally support that directions be published as soon as possible. One of the matters that has concerned me for a long time is the capacity of a government to interfere with supposedly independent authorities. One thing that I believe is extremely important is that there should be, on any occasion when there is political intervention with the operation of an independent authority of one sort or another, a disclosure of that political intervention for all members of the public to know and judge. That is what this Bill provides in Clause 7 (2).

Remuneration is another matter about which Senator Evans made complaint. I agree that there is a matter for concern in relation to remuneration. I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to pay particular attention to the point I am going to make. I do not like and I do not support the general idea that the salaries, allowances and entitlements of people appointed to positions such as this should be subject to Executive whim. I believe that this sort of position on a permanent basis ought to be subject either to the Remuneration Tribunal or to specific legislation which then has to survive the scrutiny of the Parliament. The position with regard to this proposal, is however, acceptable I think provided what I understand to be the situation proves to be the situation, that is, that special prosecutors will be appointed from time to time for the purpose of pursuing one or a number of prosecutions. If it turns out that an appointment or position is permanent, I ask the Government to give an undertaking to review the provisions of this Act to ensure that the appointee comes within the purview of the Remuneration Tribunal as a permanent appointee. If it is a matter of the equivalent of briefing counsel for particular cases or a series of cases, I think the only practical way to go about it is to do it by negotiation. Therefore, the provision in the Bill is reasonable. But if it becomes a permanent position, I cannot see any reason why it should not be--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a five-year position is it not?

—It is not necessarily. It is limited to a maximum of five years I understand, and I am subject to correction, that it is likely that the special prosecutor will be appointed for the purpose of pursuing particular pieces of prosecution and it may be that another appropriate expert will be appointed for another series of prosecutions. In that case, I think flexibility is required in relation to the question of remuneration. But if it becomes a permanent position, I cannot see why it should not be subject to the normal permanent position provision of the Remuneration Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: I warmly support the introduction of this legislation as part of an ongoing attack, a vigorous attack, by this Government to overcome something which is a disgrace to our country, a disgrace which has developed with the introduction of the idea that it was fair game to rip off other citizens. I warmly support this legislation as an important part in achieving the restoration of credibility in the honest citizens of this country and the repudiation of the dishonest practices which have crept in and led to 30 separate measures of tax reform to which I have referred and which have been necessary since 1977. This legislation is a further example of the determination of this Government to stamp out tax avoidance in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a Bill for an Act to provide for special prosecutors. Senator Peter Rae, in his contribution, tried to present this legislation as the last in a noble saga of hard hitting and effective laws which this Government has passed from time to time in the past four or five years to overcome tax avoidance. It is not the last in a series of laws to deal with tax avoidance. In fact, this is a novel piece of legislation for the national Parliament.
—Are you in favour of it?

—I am in favour of it because it overcomes the failure of this Government to prosecute successfully those who defrauded the revenue of hundreds of millions of dollars. It is novel legislation, it is new, for the national legal environment. A special prosecutor is required because this Government has failed to prosecute successfully those who have defrauded the revenue of hundreds of millions of dollars, those who over the years in a quite subversive fashion have undermined the whole equity and fairness of our tax system, particularly by their use of so-called bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is in fact the most candid confession yet by this Government of its failure to pursue tax avoidance as vigorously and as robustly as it should have in the years preceding tonight. After all, today is Wednesday, 15 September 1982. It is seven or eight years since the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes were first detected by the Australian Taxation Office. It is seven years since that Office sought the assistance of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth, Western Australia, to launch a prosecution in relation to one of these schemes. In other words, it is seven years since the Government first became aware that it ought to prosecute these bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. It failed to do so. The enormity of the loss to revenue can only be wondered at or guessed at. Tonight, 15 September 1982, we are debating the presentation of this Bill. Far from being the last in a noble saga of hard hitting exercises by this Government to curtail tax avoidance, it is an abject confession of failure.

I must say that I am delighted that it has come into the Parliament in this form. Whilst it is true, as my learned colleague Senator Evans has pointed out, that much of what is in the Bill could have been achieved by Executive fiat, I think it is appropriate, as we are adopting this novel office in Australia's public life, for it to come before this Parliament. I think it is important that the Parliament deal with the matter. I must say that I was surprised-I will deal with this later-at Senator Peter Rae's acceptance of what I see as some deficiencies in the possibility of Parliament scrutinising and carrying out a surveillance function without an interference function in regard to the operations of the office of special prosecutor.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I have missed something, I would be grateful if you told me.

—I will come to that more specific point in a moment. This Bill is telling the people of Australia that there can be no confidence at all in the capacity of Mr Howard's Taxation Office or Senator Durack's Attorney-General's Department to pursue these matters. We need a completely new office, a break with the past which has failed us so manifestly. The vigour that is required is not contained within the present structures of government established by the Fraser Administration and the Ministers-Howard and Durack-who have been responsible conjointly for it. I must bring into the picture the Public Service Board, which has also neglected its proper responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Estimates Committee A, which met on Monday, did uncover the fact-Senator Peter Rae would not expect me to agree in toto with his interpretation of the events of last Monday but I think he would acknowledge this point-that a joint management review committee report was available to the Government in June 1980 concerning the operations of the Crown Solicitor's Office, a report which advocated strongly that tax expertise be built up in the Central Office of the Crown Solicitor's Office in order to deal with the defrauding of revenue that had been established and was going on in Australia. Despite that, it was only three weeks ago that the Public Service Board indicated its preparedness to accept a submission from the Attorney-General's Department for the appointment of a First Assistant Crown Solicitor to carry out litigation in this field, and only three weeks ago that the submission for the establishment of a special revenue section within the Crown Solicitor's Office was accepted by the Public Service Board.

Two years after the joint management review committee said that that tax expertise needed to be built up, and only in the atmosphere of the political climate that has built up around Australia in the last three or four weeks, the Public Service Board has come to the party in that regard. That comes out of the evidence of Estimates Committee A. That, I think, demonstrates the weakness, the dilatory nature, the almost culpable negligence of the present structures of government in dealing with these tax avoidance prosecutions. Therefore, I am not surprised-indeed, I am pleased-to see the emergence of the proposal for this office of special prosecutor.

I am not entirely clear whether his brief will be restricted to following up those who entered into bottom-of-the-harbour schemes before the passage of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980. It is another surprising fact that no prosecutions have as yet been launched under that Act. Once again it emerged in evidence that the Crown Solicitor himself had felt constrained to telephone the Australian Taxation Office over the last few weeks and ask whether any prosecutions were forthcoming under the Act. He got two different answers. One was that five prosecutions were pending, perhaps nine were in some stage of preparation. The next time he telephoned the answer was that nine prosecutions were more or less ready to go and there were five waiting in the background. There has been complete confusion in relation to prosecutions under the Act. I hope the special prosecutor has a role in relation to them and not merely those schemes which were entered into prior to the passage of the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that you would agree that the evidence was that in no case have there been any instructions given to the Attorney-General's Department to prosecute so that, wherever fault lies, it does not lie with the Attorney-General's Department.

—I acknowledge that the evidence was quite clear that no request has been made or instructions for prosecutions issued by the Taxation Office to the Crown Solicitor in relation to prosecutions under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980. My purpose was to point to the confusion as evidenced in a conversation between the Crown Solicitor and the Australian Taxation Office. That is perhaps an indication why it is that no successful prosecutions have been launched to this point. I believe that the Ministers responsible have to take their share of political responsibility for the fact that their departments are in that state. We do need this new office of a special prosecutor.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose one of the features which it is necessary to find in such a Bill is that independence of the Executive which so commended itself to Senator Peter Rae and to the Opposition. It is important that this office not be subject to political interference. But I wonder whether, in removing scope for ministerial control over the office of special prosecutor, there has not also been a failure to sufficiently empower the Parliament to scrutinise the activities of the special prosecutor. I am referring to clause 6 of the Bill which provides that the Minister, who is the Attorney-General, by instrument in writing published in the Gazette, from time to time specifies those matters or classes of matters in relation to which the special prosecutor may institute prosecutions or undertake civil remedies on behalf of the Commonwealth. In other words, it is intended to establish the special prosecutor's initial jurisdiction by means-I am sure that Senator Peter Rae will be extremely interested in this point-of an instrument in writing published in the Gazette. Clause 7, as was properly pointed out in debate, concerns directions and guidelines to special prosecutors which, once again, are to be published in the Gazette-I am not sure whether by instrument in writing; as I understand it they are simply to be published.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the honourable senator's attention to the fact that clause 7 (1) states that the Attorney-General may, by notice in writing.

—We will call it an instrument in writing. Whether it be the guidelines or the initial determining of the jurisdiction of the special prosecutor, it is phrased in such a way that it does not go before the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. What I am saying is that if this initial jurisdiction or the guidelines had been prescribed by way of regulation, then the jurisdiction of the prosecutor and the guidelines could come before this Parliament and, in the normal processes of 15 days, we could determine for ourselves whether we thought them suitable for the ambit and guidance to the exercise of his powers.
—What about tabling the Gazette in the case of the publication in the Gazette of any such directions? That would give the Parliament a similar opportunity, would it not?

—It would give us an opportunity for debate, if not for disallowance. I think that is quite a good suggestion but I do not want to get involved in debate across the chamber to too great an extent. I am greatly indebted to Senator Peter Rae for acknowledging the point I am making that some further thought ought to be given, since tonight we are being given the responsibility for the creation of this office rather than by way of Executive fiat, and we need to take responsibility for its proper operation. Further, there is the surprising and difficult point that the special prosecutor is not constrained, fettered or hindered by the limitation of matters or classes of matters which the Attorney-General may set out by instrument in writing in the Gazette. He can go beyond them without ministerial hindrance and legal challenge because clause 6 (3) states that his going beyond that jurisdiction set out in the Gazette:

SPEECH.PARA: shall not be challenged or called in question in any court . . .

It seems to me that there especially we need to try to establish some mechanism by which the Parliament can be made aware of the special prosecutor's travelling beyond that ground initially set out for him in the Gazette. Whilst it is true, as Senator Peter Rae has said and as I think Senator Evans has also pointed out, that there is a requirement in the special prosecutor that he provide the Attorney-General with an annual report which is then laid before each House of the Parliament by the Attorney-General within 15 sitting days of the report being furnished to him, it seems to me that the opportunity for debate to which the tabling of the annual report gives rise may well be too late. It would seem to me that if the special prosecutor felt that he needed to go beyond the grounds of jurisdiction or the matters or classes of matters which were assigned to him, then he ought immediately by way of special report to the Parliament- indeed the Ombudsman may make a special report to the Parliament from time to time; he is not required merely to make an annual report to the Parliament- indicate that he is travelling beyond those classes of matters which were assigned to him.

I can understand why the clause is there. No doubt it is precisely to prevent the sort of political interference that Senator Peter Rae and those on this side of the chamber fear which would so define the classes of matters or purport to define them in a way which constrained, fettered, hindered or narrowed the ability of the special prosecutor to carry out his task. He must be able to go beyond those despite the fact that the Minister may not be prepared to alter those matters or classes of matters by a new instrument in writing in the Gazette. That is the whole point. In those instances where the special prosecutor has to go beyond those grounds, it must be because he has been unable to get the Minister to agree to extend those grounds by instrument in writing in the Gazette. Surely in that instance the Parliament ought to be informed that the special prosecutor and the Minister have been unable to agree on an extension of grounds or the matters or the classes of matters to which he can have regard and the matter ought to be brought into this chamber for debate. I hope that Senator Peter Rae, as a protector and great champion of the parliamentary institution, will see that although I might not have come up with any perfect solution there is some need, given the responsibility which is upon us tonight, to assert the ultimate sovereignty of the Parliament over its creation. I hope that some notice will be taken of that point in the Minister's reply.

As I say, the Opposition fully supports the concept of this Bill. It regards it as absolutely necessary despite some of the deficiencies in parliamentary surveillance which I have noted. The Opposition does recognise the total inadequacy of the existing machinery of government and even perhaps its unwillingness to deliver the goods. In this case the goods are those hundreds of millions of dollars which have been defrauded or denied to the Treasury of this country for many years by those who have sought to subvert our system to their own ends or those, by the perverting of the best legal and accounting brains in the country, have served their own greed than to provide those sinews of government which are so essential. Speaking of sinews of government, it seems to me that although we have had assurances-this is an important point-that the special prosecutors will be provided with such expert staff as is necessary for them to undertake their task, I would say that the Parliament would want to have a look at the staff resources made available to special prosecutors quite early in the piece and not merely at the time the special prosecutor makes his annual report. We have had instances before in this Parliament when the Government has not provided the sinews of law to the Taxation Office for it to carry out its function. Only a very short time ago during debate in this chamber I had occasion to point out that very fact. From memory, an estimates committee had determined that whereas the Government was engaging in great rhetoric about the fight against tax avoidance, it was proposing to deny to the Taxation Office, because of its obsession with staff ceilings, well over 100 people in the tax recovery area. It was proved by that Estimates committee chaired by Senator Austin Lewis, which reported I think in October 1981, that whilst the Government might save some $15,000, $18,000 or $20,000 per employee in the Tax Office by not employing that person's services, it was thereby denying itself $250,000 in revenue which each of those persons could recover. In other words, it was a question of tens of millions of dollars of revenue not being recovered by this Government because of its failure to provide the sinews of war.

I make the point that it is essential that this special prosecutor be sent into battle with sufficient staff, whether they be experts in the area of law or accounting, to enable him successfuly to bring prosecution to fruition. I think one of the problems-this came out during the deliberations of Estimates Committee A, as I think Senator Peter Rae will acknowledge-in the time between 1975 and 1978 was a fear in the Crown Solicitor's Office that if an unsuccessful prosecution were brought perhaps more damage would be done to efforts to recover revenue than if it were just not brought at all. It is essential that the special prosecutor have the staff available to him to bring successful prosecutions early in his operations because if he is to fail in some of those early cases and if that failure can be traced to a lack of expert backup, I think we will be in an extremely sorry state.

As I said, the Opposition supports this Bill. It is a completely novel step in the Government's attempt to recover revenue which has been denied to the Treasury over many years. I say it is a step by the Government. However, I think the fact that we as a parliament are now debating the matter really means that the office is being established by the Parliament rather than by Executive fiat. I think that that contrast needs to be emphasised. I think we as a chamber take some responsibility for the creation of this office but that brings with it the attendant need to ensure that it functions effectively. From time to time-not merely at the time an annual report is presented-we should take the opportunity to gauge the effectiveness of its performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a particular problem which relates to the power of the special prosecutor. It is a problem raised quite recently by both the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Attorney-General in defence of themselves, and also by Crown Law officers before Estimates Committee A on Monday of this week in defence of the current situation. Section 16 (2) of the Income Tax Assessment Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this section, an officer shall not either directly or indirectly, except in the performance of any duty as an officer, and either while he is, or after he ceases to be an officer, make a record of, or divulge or communicate to any person any such information so acquired by him.

The operative words are 'except in the performance of any duty as an officer'. My point is that unless those terms are met it is possible that the Commissioner of Taxation could be barred from conveying information to the special prosecutor . There are two ways of interpreting 'any duty'. One is by looking at section 8 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which is a general administration section under which the Taxation Commissioner has a duty to administer the Act. But under those general duties there is a specific duty in section 233 of the Income Tax Assessment Act which enables prosecutions in the name of the Taxation Commissioner. It can be argued that this particular area of duty of an officer could be limited only to divulging information in cases where that information is briefed to Crown Law officers and only Crown Law officers. The other aspect of interpreting section 16 (2) could well come under section 245 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. In part, that section reads:
In any action, prosecution or other proceeding . . . by the Commissioner or a Deputy Commissioner-
That is in any court-
he may appear either personally or by a barrister or solicitor, or by some officer of the public service of the Commonwealth or a State.

In those instances the information may be divulged. The point I raise first is that there is a particular problem with section 245, and that is that it refers only to those cases that are prosecuted in the name of the Commissioner of Taxation or the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation. As such any prosecutions started by the special prosecutor in his own name as is provided by the Special Prosecutors Bill, may not cover that exemption from section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The other problem I raise, also in respect of section 16, is that under clause 6 (1) of the Special Prosecutors Bill the Attorney-General decides what matters may be prosecuted. From my interpretation of the Income Tax Assessment Act the Taxation Commissioner then has the responsibility of prosecuting and also deciding what is within his duty as an officer for the purpose of section 16 (2) . So it may very well be that the Attorney-General and the Taxation Commissioner may not coincide in their assessment of what matters may or may not be prosecuted.

They are the minor problems I can foresee from my reading of these provisions. The major problem-it arises when section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act is read as widely as Ministers have read it in recent weeks-is that section 16 was passed in much earlier days when prosecuting was done in-house by the Government by way of the Crown Law Office in a major matter and within the Australian Taxation Office when matters were not major. It may well be, given the interpretations that we get from the High Court, that section 16 will be read stringently and will not be read down and that a reading of section 16 will prohibit any divulging of information by the Taxation Commissioner.

I raise these problems because I think that the Government, in its haste in preparing the legislation, has not obtained an opinion from the Crown Law Office as to the ambit of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. That is information which Estimates Committee A received on Monday of this week. In the absence of such advice it could well be that the problem the Government is claiming has existed in recent years will persist under the Special Prosecutors Act. The Government should give some consideration to looking at that with a view to amending either the Income Tax Assessment Act or this Bill.
