TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President-(Quorum formed). We are continuing the debate on plant variety rights. The purpose of the Bill is to provide for plant breeders, if they so desire-in other words, it is entirely voluntary-to apply for registration to an authority to obtain sole rights or ownership rights for a limited period over new varieties. In 1938 a group of breeders from Denmark, France, Germany and the Netherlands, founded the International Association of Plant Breeders for plant variety protection. By 1977 the Australian Agricultural Council had approved the setting up of plant variety rights. By 1982 we find that about 25 countries have introduced provisions for the granting of property rights in plant varieties.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is reasonably simple, but it grants rights only in relation to a new plant variety. That means that the variety must firstly be homogeneous having regard to the particular features of its sexual reproduction or vegetative propagation. It must be stable. It must have been originated by a person. It must be distinguishable by one or more morphological-in other words, features relating to its form-or physiological or other characteristics, from all other plant varieties whose existence was a matter of common knowledge when the variety was originated. In other words, it does not cover varieties that have been introduced from overseas even though they might as such be new to Australia. It does not cover items that were, as such, growing in the wild. But it provides a protection to breeders who develop a new variety.

The legislation is somewhat similar in the plant field to protection in the form of a patent type of right in the industrial sphere. For a given period, ownership bestows upon a particular person. He sells a seed and gets a certain royalty in payment for that. It is important to recognise that there is nothing in the Bill that would prevent farmers or gardeners retaining the seed of protected varieties for the sowing of crops. In other words, they can keep their own seed for growing purposes. They can sell it for human or animal consumption. Provision is made that the protected varieties will be freely available for research purposes.

The Bill is particularly important to Australia because we are an agricultural nation. We derive significant exports from agricultural products. Coming from Tasmania, where horticulture is one of the few potential growth areas, I think that all Tasmanians and all Australians true to their country must be concerned about Australia having available to it the best varieties. As I mentioned last night, all too often we condemn some people in the manufacturing field for not keeping up to date with the latest techniques, the latest varieties. What this Bill is seeking to do is to make sure that the Australian farmer has available to him all the varieties that have been developed overseas. Unfortunately, we have found that new varieties have been refused release to Australia because of a lack of plant variety rights legislation. Some common items that have been excluded until now are: Grapes, cherries, grape seed, barley, perennial rye grass, peaches, nectarines, strawberries and pome fruit. There is quite a formidable list of items. Why should Australian agriculturalists and horticulturalists be deprived of the new varieties that have been developed overseas?

I recognise that there will be certain problems. Maybe it is in the home garden area that the advertising men should seek to extol a lot of the virtues as to colour, size, yield and so on. But maybe some of the problems, such as susceptibility to disease, are not balanced out. The commercial man will not buy a new variety without testing it himself. Although there is no provision for a testing authority, farmers are fairly conservative in their approach-they will not spend hundreds of thousands of dollars putting in a completely new crop without testing or having advance knowledge of the suitability of that crop for their soil types and so on because all those sorts of things are important.

Another problem I raise rests more in the international sphere. Plant variety rights will indeed be good for Australia. It is true that some of the seed may cost a little more, but it is the net benefit that will be gained from the extra yields that is important. A cost-benefit analysis would indicate that farmers might buy the newly developed seeds if there were a net overall gain in doing so . But I sometimes wonder what might apply in the Third World. The developing world has a little share-unfortunately, it is too small a share-in the global seed industry. We have to recognise that when we create a benefit through introducing legislation certain people may tend to gain excessively from that benefit.

A lot of gene pools have developed in the Third World countries. They do not always have the resources necessary to buy those new seeds. So it is the old story: As the Western societies or the developed world move to improve their position, in the long term that can prove somewhat detrimental to the Third World. No greater challenge to man exists at present than the challenge to eliminate starvation from the world and to help the mass of rural people to escape from dire poverty. The basic challenge is to provide a breakthrough in this area of need. We must improve our yields. We must provide an incentive to plant breeders to plant better strains, to get better yields. We have to recognise the overall net benefit to be derived by mankind.

As I mentioned, there will be problems. When benefits are created I believe there is a possibility that some of the smaller seed organisations will be taken over by some of the larger corporations. We saw that happen in the United Kingdom when, within one week of legislation being passed, the Rank Hovis McDougall company bought out 84 small country seed suppliers or organisations. I believe that is somewhat inevitable. We have to recognise that sort of thing when we pass this sort of legislation. But the net benefit will indeed be good for Australia.

I raise another benefit that will be derived from this legislation. Why are we going to have patent legislation in respect of plant varieties? This legislation will encourage investment in plant research by private companies. Another benefit is that it will lead to a policing and raising of the quality of seeds developed by plant breeding because there will be added interest in that. I believe that a combination of those two benefits will lead to advances in agriculture. I foresee one problem; that is, that as the private companies develop their own plant breeding laboratories and apply moneys to research in this area, we must not overlook the significant contribution made by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to rural Australia in the propagation of needed varieties. I think it would be a tragedy if CSIRO research in this area were allowed to decline as an offset to the increased interest and activity of and the increased research funds spent by the private sector. The role of the CSIRO has indeed been very significant. I trust that with the passing of this legislation the contribution by the CSIRO will not diminish but, in fact, will improve.

This Bill has lain on the table for public discussion since 7 May 1981. I think it has been there for ample time. I do not believe that anything could be gained by sending this Bill to a committee stage. I think that the sooner Australian farmers can gain the benefits that will be derived from the new varieties the better it will be for the economy of Australia. Therefore, I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment, moved by Senator Walsh on behalf of the Opposition, to the motion for the second reading of the Plant Variety Rights Bill. I would like to express my concern about certain effects that the introduction of plant breeding legislation in Australia will have and, in particular, its effect in relation to the Third World. We know that poverty and famine go hand in hand. There is no doubt that this legislation will deliberately and decisively prevent the underdeveloped countries from feeding themselves at the lowest possible cost. This has happened in other parts of the world. In 1977 in the Philippines the Esso company developed a network of 100 ' agroservice centres'-a small monopoly-where farmers could purchase seeds, pesticides and farm implements as well as fertilisers through the Esso dealer. That information is taken from the book entitled Farming for Profit in a Hungry World, published in the United States of America in 1977. In 1978 the Farmers Assistance Board in the Philippines stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In less than three years alone, the cost of certified high-yielding seeds here has gone up almost 100%
After a series of some 400 meetings on land issues, bishops of the Catholic Church, representing 43 dioceses of 12 mid-western States of the United States of America issued the following statement:
. . . stewardship of land and life itself are both symbolically and naturally joined in the life generating capacity of the seed.

We must preserve for ourselves and for future generations the genetic variety of plants necessary to protect humanity . . . We are also disturbed by the acquisition of seed companies and patents by multinational corporations, the control of seed seeds, because it implies also the control of food production, and indeed of life itself, should not be appropriated to itself by any company or nation. We therefore urge a careful review of pending seed patent legislation .
The Presidential Commission on World Hunger has also noted the ethical question raised by seed patent legislation. It stated:

. . . at the very least there should be a thorough and careful review of this proposed legislation and all related laws currently on the books. Establishing laws to patent forms of life raises serious ethical questions and may establish dangerous precedents. Appropriate federal agencies should be directed to do long range reviews of these laws in light of world food security, conservation, and diversity. Appropriate policies and legislative remedies would hopefully follow-

Life form patenting raises moral and ethical issues. I think we have to question whether we can or should put life forms which are owned and which are the common heritage of mankind into the hands of certain companies which are motivated by economic profit. The North-South report on world hunger says:

Only major efforts of investment, planning and research can make enough food available for the six billion people the world will probably hold by the year 2000. But not only must the food be there; people who need it must be able to buy it.

I would suggest that once the seeds get into the hands of multinational companies the price of seed and food will be beyond the means of Third World countries. We have to ask: Should the Third World countries pay royalties for varieties, the germ plasma of which originated in their own countries? A number of Third World countries have asked the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development to begin a study of the effects of the spread of PVR-type laws on agricultural development. It is known that much research and development of species is done for high yield without sufficient consideration of the food value. The protein content of wheat over the last 20 years has been greatly reduced. It is not quantity alone but the quality of the food and the protein value which will best feed a hungry world.

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation at its special session in Rome in November 1981 passed a resolution calling for a special review to consider the problems raised in Third World countries by the plant variety rights legislation in various parts of the world. The resolution requests the Food and Agriculture Organisation to produce a document including legal provisions designed to ensure that global plant genetic resources will be conserved and used without restricted practices that limit their availability or exchange, whatever the sort practices. It is quite clear from the transcripts of the debates surrounding the resolution that it was promoted by concerns held by large numbers of countries that international exchange of plant genetic material , and therefore plant breeding, was being greatly hindered by the spread of PVR- type legislation. It is also clear that a majority of the nations represented at the Food and Agriculture Organisation see the answer lying in overcoming the monopoly provisions of the plant patenting system rather than a world-wide adoption of such schemes. The resolution was supported by all Third World nations.

We have to consider seriously whether famine in the Third World will result from the greed of multinational companies. It seems quite obvious that multinational companies will be taking over the seed companies of the world and resources of the world if PVR falls into their hands. Seed patenting obstructs effective plant breeding for pest and disease resistance since the requirement of distinctness, uniformity and stability do not encourage plant breeders to introduce exotic germ plasma into their programs, thus seed patenting further encourages the breeding of plants based on a limited genetic base. The Food and Agriculture Organisation is particularly concerned about this aspect of seed patenting. It states:

. . . it may be noted that the commercialisation and subsequent commercial competitiveness resulting from the system of plant breeding . . . has led to the intensive breeding of new varieties on a limited genetic base resulting on several occasions in widespread disease epidemics.
So far as research is concerned, Sir Otto Frankel, in Canberra in 1969 said:

We have met with constant difficulties because of a marked lack of financial support. The financial resources that we require are of an order that is infinitesimally small compared with sums that mankind devotes to far less constructive purposes.

I think that mention has been made tonight of the very good work that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is doing in the development of species in Australia. I think we should perhaps ask why, if more money were not put into that area, we would not have an even greater seed resource in this country. Transnationals have a very insidious way of acting and carrying out their policies before the public is often aware of them. I turn now to the transnationals' control of food in Australia. In Multinationals Take Over Australia by Len Fox, it is stated:

In some Australian industries, overseas investment may have been needed to supply the risk capital or the technology. But in the food industry this was hardly so. There had been some British investment, but by 1940, and even as late as 1950, our food industry had largely been built on Australian capital, with no reason why it should not become more so.
However, by 1963 the Sydney Morning Herald financial editor was writing:
It would take an expert dietitian now to show us how to keep body and soul together without helping to send dividends abroad, and especially to the United States.

Since then the United States invasion has intensified, particularly in the fast food area. In 1975 the Australian Financial Review carried the headline ' Australia target of big United States fast food expansion plans'. By 4 March 1978 the National Times reported:

The multi-million-dollar fast food industry has wrought a quiet revolution in Australian eating habits that worries dietitians, supermarket proprietors and milk-bar owners . . . . the Australian consumer has become a convert to the fast food, eat-out society, spending $6.36 or 20 per cent of the average family's weekly grocery bill on take-away food and meals eaten out of the house-

Most local fast food groups, except the Perth-based Red Rooster Foods were pushed out by the United States big three, Kentucky Fried Chicken Pty Ltd, McDonald's Family Restaurants and Hartee's Family Restaurant. The latter, owned by the Kellogg organisation, closed down in 1975; but Kentucky Fried Chicken lifted its Australian profit in 1976 to just on $2m. Hartee's place was taken by Pizza Hut Australia Pty Ltd owned by Pepsico of the United States. This chain has its own hamburger university in the United States and in Australia it is expanding rapidly, with many new sites alongside cinema complexes. What this illustrates to us is that, when Australia was in charge of its own food, the profits were staying in Australia. We must question where the profits will be going if the seed industry gets into the hands of overseas companies.

Patenting will allow market control by a small number of companies and seed prices will then rise. According to the United States Department of Agriculture, since PVR legislation was introduced there in 1970, there has been 143.4 per cent increase in the cost of seeds. Overseas experience suggests that, on a crop basis, a few firms may ultimately control a high proportion of patents. Statistics from the United States Plant Protection Office show that, in December 1979, four companies controlled 79 per cent of beans, four companies controlled 44 per cent of cotton, six companies controlled 66 per cent of lettuce and two companies controlled 43 per cent of peas. There is also the unpleasant fact of the green revolution in Third World countries. Mr W. David Hopper provided a devastating analysis of the impact of the green revolution in Third World politics when, in 1977, he concluded a speech on the Politics of Food by saying:
The politics of the control of wealth is always an unseemly affair . . . a particularly inelegant diplomacy.
This probably sums up very clearly the impact of multinationals controlling food in Third World countries.

There is another aspect of the entry of multinationals into Third World countries and into food organisation. Dr L. W. Crowder of Ithaca, New York, has pointed out a major shortcoming of the revolution often overlooked by critics. He says:

Small landholders usually practise a system of multi-cropping. For example, a mixture of corn and beans where they are adapted. Unfortunately, plant breeders have not taken into consideration the plant characteristics that favour growing crops together. Thus, new varieties of corn and bean do not grow well in combination. Other experts have calculated that such companion-planting can increase both yield and profitability by more than 50 per cent. Beyond yield, companion-planting makes a major contribution to the protein production of subsistence farmers. Legume crops, cultivated in this way, are often kept by the family while the cereal crop is sold.
Under the multinational green revolution, this system has been abolished.

There has been critisism by speakers on the Government benches that some organisations have approached this legislation in an emotional way. I would suggest that, if we are discussing part of our life support system, which the plant kingdom is, it is perfectly legitimate to be emotional. The sad fact is, I think, that in the system under which we live, economic values are put at a much greater level than human values. If we consider that both the animal kingdom and humans are dependent on the plant kingdom for their very survival and health, I think we should be looking at values other than economic values when we consider this Bill.

If we look at the Middle Ages, when plants were beginning to be developed, we find that they were not being developed for profit. Many monasteries developed herbs and plants out of their concern for the need of people for better food. This is often spoken of as the romance of plants. I think we should consider what that means. Throughout history the development of plants, whether they be herbs for medicine or vegetables for food, roses or fruit, much the greater part of development has been by people who have had a concern for developing the plant itself. In fact, the romance of plants has been the developing of plants for the sheer love of the plant.

In considering the amendments to the Bill, I think we have to remember that if democracy is to work all information and facts must be available to people so that they can make an informed judgment. During the debate on this Bill much information has been put forward by the Opposition which has not been made available to people. I am considering the kit which the Government put out. That was very light on in relation to much of the material that has been used in the debate against this legislation.

I think that seeds must remain a public resource. I think we must consider all aspects of their value, not only the aspect of profit. I would suggest that, if this Bill goes to a standing committee for consideration, there be no haste to resolve the situation until the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation has come down with a resolution, with guidelines for the control of seeds throughout the world, and the flow of food to mankind. I think we must therefore ask whether control of our most basic need, which is food, should pass out of our hands, the people's hands, into the hands of people and companies who are concerned only with economic gain. I commend the amendment moved by Senator Walsh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this legislation, the Plant Variety Rights Bill, which introduces plant variety rights into this country. I do so with considerable enthusiasm, in spite of the comments of Senator Hearn, whose concern-and a very proper concern for poverty and famine around the world-has been expressed. But the very objectives of plant variety rights legislation are to increase yield capacity and to reduce the damage of insects and other matters in the production of food, in the production of the very crops that are the basis and the objective of this legislation. Indeed, Australia's stance in the area of community aid abroad has been a very significant one. Her contribution in providing food and all of those things that tend to obviate famine and poverty has been considerable. At one moment I seemed to gain the impression that Senator Hearn was concerned more with the problems, if indeed they are problems, of Kentucky Fried Chicken than of the matters that are relevant to plant variety legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It arouses in me a measure of surprise that this legislation should be opposed by the Opposition and, I presume, by the Australian Democrats, because it has been lying on the table of the Senate for consideration by the Senate for many months. The legislation represents a period of in-depth consultation and examination by producer organisations, seed merchants and a whole range of people who are directly involved in the development and breeding of plant varieties. That long and intensive examination has produced a circumstance in which there is virtually general and complete agreement that the proposition is worthwhile and can only be seen to make a real contribution to the productivity of Australian agriculture and plant breeding across a very wide range of involvement.

I wish to take just a moment to make a comment or two in relation to Australia' s agricultural and pastoral industries. Those industries are confronted with a harsh climate and harsh soil which, in many cases, lacks fertility and many of the qualities that aid productivity. Consequently, in the face of that sort of competition from climate and soil together, Australian agriculture has developed a measure of adaptability and a capacity of which Australians should be intensely proud. Australian agriculture, in the form of the Australian farmer, has the highest level of productivity on a per capita basis of any agricultural country around the world. Indeed, its adaptability has brought about a level of research, development and breeding in plant varieties and stock that is rated very highly. It has seen the development of a wide range of machinery and cultivation methods that are, in many cases, the envy of the world in which we live. It has seen the development of agricultural chemicals which, in terms of both their nature and the method of application, have made a significant contribution to the productivity of agriculture in this country and in many places around the world.

Only a few weeks ago a well known Australian agricultural chemicals applier spent some time in China looking at the circumstances of chemical control in agriculture in that country and demonstrating the capacity for aerial application of chemicals in new agricultural areas in China. Australia has made very great contributions in relation to cultivation methods, research, the application and nature of chemicals, and plant and animal breeding. If plant variety rights are introduced in Australia at this time they will only open up new opportunities to an already great industry, an industry that rates highly around the world by whatever standards one may like to judge. It is worth remembering that even today, in spite of the advent of a gradually growing and significant manufacturing industry and the enormous potential Australia has in the minerals and resources field, the agriculture, livestock, meat and wool production industries still provide virtually 50 per cent of Australia's overseas earning capacity.

Plant variety rights, which we have discussed on a number of occasions over a few days, are not something new. Plant variety rights have been introduced in 22 or more countries around the world, mostly developed countries. The United Kingdom introduced plant variety rights in 1964, so they have been in operation there for almost 20 years. If we are to avail ourselves of the benefits of plant variety rights we will need to go into this field quite soon. Plant breeding is a relatively slow process. We are looking at anything from between five years and 15 years for the process to take place. The sooner we become participants in something which has become common-place in the developed countries of the world the sooner we will improve the productivity of our great agricultural and pastoral industries.

Interestingly enough, in the United Kingdom where plant breeding through PVR has been in operation for some 18 or 19 years, both public and private enterprise play very significant parts. In some fields only private enterprise is involved. There are 100 full time plant breeders and 1,500 associated staff employed at public institutions in the United Kingdom. They cover an enormous range of plant breeding under the umbrella of plant variety rights. No fewer than six private companies are involved in cereal breeding alone. One of these vast consortiums in the private field has no fewer than 100 breeders in 66 countries around the world. Obviously Australia, not being a participant in plant variety rights, is not one of those 66 countries and consequently does not have the capacity to involve itself in the knowledge and the results of research in that very significant area. In some fields, such as ornamental grasses, only private breeders are involved in the United Kingdom. In other fields, such as the development of rye grasses, there are nine public breeders and nine private breeders. In the area of red clover there are four government breeders and seven private breeders. It is clear that there is a reasonable and responsible combination of private and government involvement in plant breeding in countries where PVR is in existence.

It seems strange that the Australian Democrats should oppose this sort of legislation. I have always imagined them to be greatly concerned with conservation. Indeed, most of us are, as we should be. We live in an age in which, because of the availability of plants and knowledge, our capacity to re- establish, maintain and stabilise the environment is greater than it has ever been in the history of mankind. We have the machinery, the engineering capacity and the knowledge to maintain and develop the environment to a greater degree than ever before in our history. The consequences of plant variety rights have been, at least to this point, the capacity to breed types of plants that have a great contribution to make and have made a great contribution in containing erosion, in sealing off old mining areas and in maintaining a stable environment . Consequently, I would have thought that genuine conservationists would support this sort of legislation and enterprise as do conservationists in the United Kingdom.

It is unfortunately true that the rate of increase of plant productivity in Australia is significantly slower than that in many parts of the developed world . It is a fascinating and somewhat ironical circumstance that New Zealand fruit bred from an American based product is competing successfully with Australian fruit in Sydney today. We should be aware of that circumstance and take the necessary steps to obviate its continuance.

Let me refer to one or two things which are quite exciting in respect of plant variety rights. I refer to the results of plant breeding and production in a number of places around the world. The yield of wheat in the United Kingdom has increased in the last 10 years by one tonne per hectare. This very largely has been the result of the growing of varieties that have been developed following participation by the United Kingdom in plant variety rights. Maize, which was not even grown in the United Kingdom 30 years ago, today is the most significant and productive forage crop. The perimeter of maize production in the United Kingdom moves north today at the rate of five to 10 miles annually. This crop is making a significant contribution in that country. In 1950 it took about 445 manhours to produce a hectare of beet sugar. Twenty-five years later, because of the introduction of a monogerm variety of beet it takes 80 manhours. This represents an increase in efficiency of something like 600 per cent. On the other hand, in Australia Beecher barley is still a recommended variety although it was introduced to this country from America 42 years ago.

Australia's enormous range of soil and climatic conditions must make this country a natural place to benefit from world-wide breeding research. We must benefit from research carried out in those parts of the world which have climates and soils similar to our own. This research is carried out at no real cost to the taxpayer. For instance, the royalty on wheat is estimated to increase the total cost of production of wheat by about half of one per cent. Of course, we can benefit significantly in respect of royalties if we are able to produce and sell Australian varieties to many places around the world which are in great need of them. Indeed, in the Middle East and in many other arid and semi-arid parts of the world there is a real need for some of the plant varieties which are natural to this country. We should be there providing those varieties and, in a real sense, helping what are in many cases undeveloped countries, to control their environment and become productive. I believe that the plant breeding industry will be a boom industry in the remaining part of this century and certainly in the twenty-first century. It has been said that the plant breeding industry could in fact be to the twenty-first century what the engineering industry has been to the twentieth century. From a conservationist's point of view, for people who are concerned with the environment, plant breeding is a clean and non-pollutant industry. Its growth and development are directly relevant to the productivity of some of the most important industries in this country or any other country. These industries have a very great contribution to make to the problems of famine and poverty to which Senator Hearn referred.

The advent of plant variety rights must give this country an opportunity in industries in which we have a natural strength, a strong background and a capacity for making a shrewd judgment. As I have said, Australian have had to develop their own industries in a harsh climate and in many cases with poor soils. They have had to develop the machinery, the cultivation methods and the chemical applications that have made us significant leaders around the world on a productivity-per capita basis. Australians who have overcome those circumstances are extremely shrewd judges of what is likely to be a better and more productive plant variety.

I say in concluding my remarks that the introduction of plant variety rights to Australia will do a number of things. In the first place it will involve, as it has in every country in which it exists, a greater investment in the plant breeding industries and that investment will naturally contribute to a greater rate of progress. It is a fact that where plant variety rights have existed for the longest period, the greatest productivity of the plant variety is to be found. None of the 22 or 23 countries which have been involved in this legislation-even Hungary, a Communist country in Eastern Europe-have seen fit under any circumstances to step back from this type of plant breeding advance.

I want to stress the point again that the concept of plant variety rights covers a total range of plant breeding. It covers not only plants that are conducive to the pastoral industries but also it maintains and stabilises the world in which we live by overcoming the problems associated with moving soils, and water and wind erosion. Plant variety rights will help to overcome so many of the problems that are involved in the instability of the environment in which we live. It is clear, as I demonstrated earlier tonight, that plant variety rights, and the breeding that stems from it, will improve yields. it will not greatly increase the cost through royalties. It will enable Australian breeders to receive royalties from other parts of the world. It will enable Australia to contribute significantly to the development of other parts of the world. Indeed, it will see Australia move from a country which still holds to the hybrid wheat breeding program. It will see us capable of moving into the open-pollinated varieties which have advanced at such an increasing rate over recent years.

There can be no doubt that the overall gains from the introduction of plant variety rights are very significant in a whole range of areas. If there is one proviso that might be worth considering it is that as time goes by the States, with appropriate membership should establish a form of merit testing organisation. But basically, this legislation can only increase Australia's productive capacity, its potential for its people and for contribution to other countries. I strongly recommend the legislation before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1982. An amendment has been moved proposing that this Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. I am in a cleft stick on this matter because I have been informed that if the amendment is not carried, if the Bill is not sent to the Committee, it will be defeated at the second reading stage. I would have thought that that would not be beneficial from the point of view of supporters of the legislation. I know there are still a number of people in the Opposition who in fact recognise the principle that the people who put considerable effort and money into the development of plant varieties ought in some way to be compensated more than they are at present for that effort and for that money.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of other valid principles behind this piece of legislation. Nevertheless there are some problems in the legislation, one of which-namely, merit testing-was adverted to by Senator Scott. I had hoped that the Bill would go into the Committee stage and that appropriate amendments could be moved to the Bill to overcome some of the problems that some of us foresee occurring after the legislation becomes law.

Nevertheless I come back to the clear point that if this Bill is not sent to a committee it is lost. What then does the Government do on behalf of the large number of people throughout Australia who consider that the Bill has merit? The Government has an option, once the notification that the legislation has been rejected goes back to the House of Representatives, of taking action to return the Bill to the Senate. Furthermore, if the Government considers that the legislation is of vast importance to the people of Australia, it can proceed under section 57 of the Constitution; namely, after a lapse of three months it can reintroduce the Bill in the House of Representatives and send it on to us. The Government could not do this until the first sitting week of the session next year. That would probably be about 17, 18, 24 or 25 February, depending upon when the Parliament is called together.

I have consulted with Opposition members on the Standing Committee on National Resources and with the Australian Democrats Whip. I have been assured that they would not oppose a rapid meeting of the National Resources Committee so as to ensure that consideration of this matter is at an advanced stage by that date. We hope that a report could be made by February of next year. As I see it, the Government has nothing to lose at the present moment by the Bill going to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. Incidentally, that Committee has reported only recently on its past reference. It has been given another reference, I think, during this week, but I am told that that reference will be supplanted by this reference. In other words, this reference will take precedence over the reference that has already been given to the Committee.

In those circumstances, on the one hand the proponents and even the opponents of the legislative have everything to gain by sending this piece of legislation to the National Resources Committee. On the other hand, the proponents of the Bill have everything to lose if it does not go to a committee. I remind the Senate of what will happen. If the Bill does not go to a committee it will be defeated and the Government will lose this piece of legislation. There is no way out of that problem other than, at this stage, to send the Bill to the committee . It is my view that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources would be the appropriate committee to which the Bill should be referred. Under those circumstances I advocate reluctantly that the Bill be sent to the Standing Committee on National Resources. I will be supporting that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their participation in the debate tonight and on previous occasions on the Plant Variety Rights Bill. As my colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Scott have mentioned, it has been a long debate. It has been one of very considerable importance, and a number of points have been made. I think it is evident, though, that there are very clear philosophical differences in the approaches of those honourable senators who have spoken. Perhaps we ought to start by putting into perspective the arguments and straight away I address my remarks to the point of equity for breeders of new varieties of plants. Breeders or developers of new varieties are seeking similar rights to those which are available to inventors of new industrial processes or procucts under a patents Act. I believe that to be a reasonable proposition. The problem that arises is that existing legislation is simply not suitable for the protection of rights in respect of plants and new varieties of plants. The processes of developing and breeding new varieties are not capable of precise description and would be almost impossible to repeat. The end product, the new variety, is the object of protection, not the process of development in itself. The end product reproduces itself. The Plant Variety Rights Bill will enable breeders of new plant varieties to apply for the exclusive right to produce and sell the variety or to license others to produce it as well. The issues of consumer protection, public plant breeding, merit testing, et cetera, are important but, I believe, have been allowed to drift across the mainstream of the debate on this matter in the last few weeks. Indeed even tonight it has tended to cloud the main issue. Perhaps the fundamental question that the Senate and the Parliament need to address is: Should the Senate or the Parliament deny the right of breeders or developers of new plant varieties the protection that is already afforded industrial developers and inventors? Why should a breeder, after years of costly work to produce a new variety, be denied the right to apply for a patent? At present, the breeder loses control of the variety after its first commercial release on the market. Should we allow to develop a situation in which there is no control, despite the enormous commitment of time, energy and inventiveness expended by the breeder in producing a new product? I believe that is the fundamental question which, indeed, Senator Scott addressed very clearly during his contribution. It is the central issue of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Later I will come to one or two points that have been made by Senator Watson regarding public funding for plant breeding. It must be said that incentives will arise for the further development of new plant varieties as a result of this legislation, which provides encouragement and incentive for new private operators to develop products. If honourable senators generally believe, as I and other senators on this side certainly believe, that plant breeders should enjoy a fair and equitable return for their work and investment, the use of the present Patents Act must be regarded as totally unsuited to that purpose. The only alternative is that of introducing a plant variety rights scheme such as has been outlined in the Bill. If the Patents Act were suitable we certainly would not need to be here proposing new legislation in this form. Breeders would already have the protection that they are seeking. As I believe both Senator Watson and Senator Scott have mentioned, 25 other countries have found patents legislation unsuitable and have gone to the extent of enacting special legislation to extend equity to plant breeders.

Plant variety rights offers many advantages to the community. I mentioned earlier a most important one-the fact that if a fair return is made available to developers it must stimulate the efforts of private plant breeders. At present in Australia this is almost entirely a public effort. The State departments of agriculture are involved, as are the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the universities within the States and elsewhere. But, as Senator Watson has pointed out, it should not be the only area of activity. If we are keen to develop, as I believe Senator Hearn would like to happen, a greater availability of seeds on world markets to stimulate the growth of world food production, surely we must foster the development of better and more numerous varieties. The Bill makes a positive contribution in that direction.

Of course, some costs to the community will be involved. It is intended that the scheme will recover costs and, in time, become self-supporting. There will be income from registration fees and, in the longer run, costs could become zero . The monetary benefit that will flow to the community from what is proposed by this legislation could be many millions of dollars. I believe that Senator Scott referred to that aspect. For instance, in New Zealand where plant variety rights were introduced in 1974, the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research estimates that the national benefit of the new varieties released during the last five years can be put at $NZ10m a year. In Great Britain royalties from sales of new varieties bred by government breeders in 1978-79 brought in #3.3m on which the Government was paid a dividend of #650,000. That provides a return to the taxpayer on his public investment in plant breeding. That would not be available without a scheme such as that outlined in the legislation.

I was pleased to hear the Opposition parties agree with us on the irrelevance of many of the emotional and unsubstantiated arguments put forward against plant variety rights. Many of those have been mentioned tonight. I think both Senator Macklin and Senator Walsh, leading for the Opposition, have made the point that many of those arguments are irrelevant and that the major issues are those which need to be attacked in other ways and by serious consideration. Senator Scott during his remarks mentioned one of these issues-merit testing. That matter would of course require further examination. It is a very vexed question. I think Senator Scott would acknowledge that there are shortcomings to merit testing of particular plants in particular areas and that some products may be suitable in some areas and not in others, and matters of that kind. Nevertheless the point is acknowledged that there are perhaps a number of matters that would require examination as experience in the use of this legislation develops. The essential point is to get the legislation established so that we can have a useful system of plant variety rights in this country leading, I think, towards a greater quantity and variety and better quality of seeds being grown in this country.

Senator Harradine raised the question of whether the matter should be referred to a further committee for examination. This is the point of the amendment moved by Senator Walsh. Clearly, a great deal of time has been given to the consideration of this matter. I think it was pointed out by Senator Watson that the Bill has been around the Parliament now since May 1981. That gives us more than 15 months in which to have considered the Bill. We all know as members of the Parliament the very considerable volume of representations made by various organisations of all shapes, colour and sizes on these matters. We know that members of parliament have applied their minds in great detail to those points. It is doubtful that there could be any further use in going over those further representations and perhaps further information in the form of a committee. The Government has the view that it is time to act, that the legislation has had considerable airing not only of course in the last 15 months but also over almost the last decade with the development of the legislation. There is the advantage of considerable experience overseas in relation to legislation of this kind. That experience has been drawn upon by our advisers.

I believe that the essential need we face right at the moment is to get on with the job. We realise that there is the question of how the Opposition will vote. We realise that Senator Macklin's colleagues are opposed to the Bill. We implore that Senate to pass the Bill at the second reading stage so that we can proceed with the legislation, get the scheme in force and ensure that we proceed to a system which will be of greater benefit not only to Australia but also indeed, in the longer run, to the world. Along those lines I draw my remarks to a close. I make the point simply that this legislation is important to all of us as Australians. I draw the attention of honourable senators to that fact. I hope the Bill will pass in the next few moments.

That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Walsh's amendment) be left out.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Sand Mining: Moreton Island, Queensland
Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the hour is late, but I want to take advantage of the adjournment debate to bring a matter to the attention of the Senate this evening. To preface my remarks I would like to read from an article which appeared in yesterday's Courier-Mail.
—Who believes the Courier-Mail?

—My colleague wants to know who believes the Courier-Mail. I do, for one. It is my local paper and I have great faith in it. But that is beside the point. The report concerns a very close colleague and very good friend of mine, Mr Col Miller, Liberal Member of the Legislative Assembly for a Brisbane metropolitan electorate called Ithaca. Some time ago Mr Miller, because he was concerned about a particular place in Queensland, decided that he would take a survey amongst his constituents. Mind you, not all of his constituents responded , but 1,000-odd of his constitutents did respond. The survey shows that 87 per cent of the people who responded were against mining on a place called Fraser Island, 12 per cent were for it and 86 per cent wanted the island declared a national park.
—Moreton Island.
—Moreton Island; I am sorry. Mr Miller was asked whether he would continue his fight against sand mining.
—Which island are you talking about?
—Moreton Island. Mr Miller said:

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly shall, even if I have to cross the floor of the House to do it. And I think a lot of Liberals, and even some National Party people, will come across with me.

This evening I stand in total support of my colleague, Mr Col Miller. As I said earlier, he is a colleague and a very close friend of mine and I totally support what he is saying. Moreton Island is a beautiful sand island, still in its natural state, situated on the doorstep of Australia's third city. If one goes east by boat from Brisbane, it takes just two hours to reach this 19,000-hectare island. It is unique in that it is the last major sand island in the Moreton region in its pristine state. It has high forested sand dunes. In fact, Mount Tempest is the highest sand dune in the world. The perched lakes of Moreton Island are rare on any Australian scale. The island has unique vegetation and animals. The wildflower heathlands support prolific birdlife and the forests harbour many native animals, such as possums and sugar gliders.

Moreton Island is now the only wallum area free of both cane toads, which are fairly prevalent in Queensland, and introduced rats. The island contains a rich history of Aboriginal settlement still largely undisturbed. It is unique in South-east Queensland, and it is important to the Aboriginal population of my State and, I would think, Aborigines throughout Australia. Because Moreton Island is beautiful and so close to Brisbane, it is very valuable as a natural place for people to go for any kind of recreation. The island is a virtual wilderness and is of inestimable value because of that alone. The island is also important for education and scientific studies. Many of my colleagues from Queensland who have visited that place will agree with what I am saying.

After a careful assessment of all the points I have just stated, the Australian Heritage Commission decided to officially list Moreton Island on the register of the National Estate. This means that Moreton Island is one of Australia's very special natural areas. It is a very special part of our heritage as Australians. In the Australian Heritage Commission Act it is stated:
No Federal Minister shall take any action that would adversely affect the heritage value of a listed area unless-
This is very important-
there is no feasible and prudent alternative.
Because of export licences, I believe that this Government is responsible for the future of Moreton Island and must act in the best interests of all Australians now and in the future.

An environmental study looking at the future of Moreton Island was carried out in 1975 under the direction of the Queensland Government. I stress that this was not an environmental impact study. It recommended two alternatives for Moreton Island-the first was no mining; the second was 6.41 per cent mining. But a public inquiry chaired by two Queensland public servants in 1976 recommended that 6.4 per cent of Moreton Island be mined. This was adopted by the Queensland Government in 1981 even though-I stress this point-there was a massive public outcry against any mining on Moreton Island.

To support all that, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation recommended, after receiving numerous public submissions and carrying out an inspection, that a full public inquiry should be carried out into the question of sand mining on Moreton Island. To date, this full public inquiry has never been carried out. The Queensland Government has not seen fit to do anything about the recommendation of a joint committee of this Federal Parliament. The recommendation has still not been listened to or carried out by the Queensland Government. The Queensland mining decision is now outdated and wrong. This Government needs to take urgent corrective action on behalf of all the Australian people. In the last few years new light has been shed on the importance of Moreton Island as a natural area.

I now wish to speak about the Aboriginal history on Moreton Island. It is important to the Aboriginal people and I believe, because of what I will be saying later in this debate, it is surely important to every Australian. Moreton Island has a rich archaeological heritage. Recent studies have shown that hundreds of sites have been found on this island. There sites range from dinner camps to extensive village sites. They include shell middens and tool making camps. Evidence so far shows that Moreton Island was occupied for at least 2,000 years by members of my race. All the different sites and the distribution of sites can tell us stories. For example, there were different summer and winter camps and different foods were eaten at different times of the year. The foods included vegetables, pandanus, berries, animals from the island and a great variety of seafoods. Something unique seems to have happened on Moreton Island. Apparently fish were often caught with the aid of porpoises which would on command herd the fish towards the shore where the waiting islanders would net and spear them. That is something that has never been followed on. Here we find evidence that this unique way of fishing was used by the Aboriginal people thousands of years ago.

Honourable senators might ask: Why is Moreton Island's Aboriginal history unique? Let me tell them. Firstly I should say that only a little over 20 per cent of the island has been properly surveyed. Yet what we know already points to the importance of the archaeological heritage of Moreton Island. Current research indicates that south-east Queensland may be an archaeologically unique region. Because Moreton Island has been relatively undisturbed by the hands of the so-called settlers to this country all of the sites in the tribal area of the Ngugi people still remain. Because of the integrity of the archaeological history of Moreton Island much can be learned and is still to be learned about the culture of members of my race. If this is not important to Australians then I wonder what is. This sort of knowledge exists nowhere else in south-east Queensland because of the land clearing, sand mining and other developments that have taken place. Moreton Island is the only undisturbed island left on the coast of Queensland. So it follows that only on Moreton Island can scientists examine a relatively complete record of past lifestyles and changes in these lifestyles. As far as we can ascertain at the moment those lifestyles may go back 5,000 to 6,000 years.

I should point out that it is not just individual sites that are important. The relationship between sites and the relationship between sites and their surrounding environments enable us partly to reconstruct the culture of this group of members of my race. The value of this knowledge and the archaeological material is of direct relevance to the living descendants of Moreton Island's Aboriginal inhabitants and, I believe, to Aboriginal people generally as a reflection on our heritage. A wonderful educational opportunity is presented on the island for all people to view at first-hand part of Australia's fascinating past. Eager's Swamp within the proposed mining area is ideal for an educational centre. It is close to Brisbane, two hours away by boat. There is a landing strip on the island which means that people can reach it by aircraft in about 15 minutes from Brisbane.

The archaeological heritage is of value to science because we can study the nature of people's adaptation to the environment. The sites contain information on the geological, zoological and botanical history of the Moreton Island region . This data is relevant to mainland and island research, not just in south-east Queensland but, I believe, elsewhere in Australia. The points I have stated have become apparent only in recent years through the research efforts of the Moreton region archaeological project. One independent consultant, Dr Rod Rogers, considered that they constituted 'as strong a reason as any other for including the island on the register of the National Estate'.

It is clear that much further detailed investigation is required to understand more about the archaeological heritage of Moreton Island. Sand mining is proposed on 1,200 hectares of Moreton Island. That area includes 16 kilometres of ocean beach which we know contains over 200 sites and the area has not yet been fully surveyed. It would be impossible to mine the area without losing sites and the important story they have to tell. It is not good enough to dig them up and store them in museums or write them up in books which will be stuck away in libraries. They are an important part of our living heritage and should remain undisturbed in this special case.

I have visited the island on a number of occasions. I have looked at some of the middens. It is not good enough for someone to say that we can take photographs of them, we can study them, we can write them up and put those writings in the archives. That is not good enough for future generations of Australians. If that were to happen future generations could read about those things and ask: 'Where can I see them?' It would be too late then; we would have allowed them to be destroyed, never again will they be there for future generations of Australians to look at or to study. If mining development goes ahead regardless, both the general public and the scientific community will lose forever irreplaceable cultural resources.

During the Queensland Government inquiry held in 1976 people were led to believe that small areas of bare sand dunes on the east coast of Moreton Island were degraded and that sand mining could fix them up. That was given as a major reason for allowing sand mining on Moreton Island. We have been fortunate in that detailed studies have been carried out by universities. Those studies now show that those dunes are natural and in fact are helping to build up the island and have helped to build up the island over thousands of years. One of the most valuable and increasingly rare resources in south-east Queensland is natural areas for people to visit, appreciate and enjoy. In the last six years, since the Queensland Government inquiry was conducted, the number of people visiting the island has increased not two-fold but 14-fold. All of those tens of thousands of new visitors, who love Moreton Island, to my knowledge have never had the chance to have a say in its future to preserve it, not just for their enjoyment, but for the enjoyment of tens of thousands of Australians and of future generations of Australians.

There is a very strong feeling, particularly in south-east Queensland, that sand mining should not be allowed on Moreton Island. An independent public opinion poll conducted in June 1981 indicated that almost 70 per cent of people were opposed to mining. As I have already said, two weeks ago a Liberal Party member of the Queensland Government conducted a public opinion poll in his electorate. I gave the results of that poll earlier, but I will repeat them. The survey showed that 87 per cent of people were opposed to any mining on Moreton Island and wanted all the island to be a national park. Most of the people had never had a proper public opportunity to participate in decisions about the future of Moreton Island.

To point out that Moreton Island is a prime example of a remaining unspoilt coastal area on the doorstep of Australia's third city is not to take an anti- mining stand, it is merely to state a fact. Many pro-sand mining people have supported the cause for a natural Moreton Island, believing that some areas in this country ought to be kept in their natural state. Moreton Island is of value to all Australians and admirably fits the description of a special place-a place that we have the responsibility to keep. Reafforestation does not restore an area to its former state. I defy anyone to argue that point. We cannot replace soils that are tens of thousands of years old; we cannot duplicate forests; we cannot do the things that nature has evolved over thousands of years, and we cannot replace archaeological heritage. It is not very comfortable, believe me, to camp beside a sand mining dredge. In areas of lesser environmental importance , these disturbances may be acceptable, but for one of Australia's special places, part of our national estate, these disturbances certainly are not.

We all know that jobs and money are important in the present economic climate. However, at present there is no sand mining on Moreton Island. Large sums of capital have not been invested and employment considerations can be offset by alternative, carefully managed recreational and educational uses. In fact, detailed studies by independent consultants to the Queensland Government show that no net national benefit may be gained by mining on Moreton Island.

I emphasise the fact that Moreton Island is listed on the Register of the National Estate and that under section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act no Federal Minister should take any action that would adversely affect the heritage value of Moreton Island unless there is no feasible or prudent alternative. I believe the Federal Government must decide the future of Moreton Island carefully and with wisdom. I belive there are many feasible and prudent alternatives to the sand mining of Moreton Island. I urge the Government and all my colleagues to reject any application for export licences for mineral sands taken from Moreton Island.

Earlier in the day there was a debate concerning South West Tasmania. It was a good debate; I do not think there was much difference between the opinions expressed by the speakers who indicated their support for the protection of that area of Australia. Senator Chipp, who introduced that debate here today, said that South West Tasmania does not belong to Tasmania, to the Government of Tasmania, to Australia-if I quote him correctly-but to the world. It is unique and it is something that should be preserved. I echo his words in relation to Moreton Island. It does not belong to the Queensland Government; it does not belong to Queensland; it belongs to Australia and I believe it must be preserved for future generations of Australians. I urge the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to take the same action as he took with respect to Fraser Island and to reject any applications for export licences for minerals found on the island. In that way we will certainly be able to preserve another one of Australia's very important areas for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Senator Bonner brought to our attention a most important issue in relation to Moreton Island-that of sand mining. It has been debated in this place from time to time and is of great concern to all of us. I am informed that Mr McVeigh , the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, recently visited Moreton Island and fully appreciates the recreational, archaeological and other features of the island as outlined by Senator Bonner during his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that it was a colourful speech and it was very interesting in relation to a number of aspects of life especially affecting Aboriginal people. However, the Minister is also aware that the Queensland Government has adopted the recommendation of the Cook report for future land use. The recommendation was to the effect that sand mining be limited to 6.4 per cent of the island's total area. The Commonwealth position is that any decision in relation to the granting of export licences, which was a key point raised by Senator Bonner, would be a matter for later consideration because obviously it would need to take into account the factors which Senator Bonner brought to our attention. It would certainly also need to take into account the broader aspects which have already been considered by the Minister; he considered them during his visit. In addition to that, any consideration by the Government would, of course, need to take into account the State's views and, in particular, the Cook report. I assure Senator Bonner that I will take forward his very substantial and considerable concerns to the Minister and with all due weight represent his views to the Minister on his behalf. I thank Senator Bonner for his very valuable contribution in this matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The most recent report from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority recorded that seven of 48 reefs carried such populations. (3) The basic biology of the starfish is now well understood. Current research effort is now concentrated on monitoring the occurrence of crown-of-thorns starfish populations. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has a program in which it is obtaining the collaboration of reef users such as divers , charter boat operators and scientists in reporting the presence or absence of starfish. TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1982, (Hansard, page 526) Senator Chipp asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following supplementary question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. First, may I have the indulgence of the Senate to say that I am bitterly disappointed with the answer that the Department has furnished to the Minister. My supplementary question is based on a confirmation that this document does exist by an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald. In that article Mr Weinberger, the United States Defense Secretary, conceded the existence of this document; that the United States has a plan to do this. One is filled with horror. I ask the Minister to bring this updated information to the Minister for Foreign Affairs or his Department and to being an equally updated reply to the Senate. Mr Weinberger made an extraordinary response when asked whether it was really possible to control nuclear forces in the confusion of battle and to make the calculated decisions of protracted nuclear war; he shook his head and said: 'I don't have any idea'.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

You referred to an article published in the Sydney Morning Herald on 26 August reporting claims regarding the preparation of a United States Government document dealing with United States nuclear doctrine and strategy. The Sydney Morning Herald report was based on American wire service reports which followed a letter written to a number of newspaper editors on 23 August 1982 by the United States Secretary of Defense, Mr Weinberger. For your information, I am attaching a copy of the text of Mr Weinberger's letter to editors.

The answer given by Senator Guilfoyle, on my behalf, made it clear that the Government is satisfied that the fundamental purpose of United States defence doctrine and strategy is to convince the Soviet Union that it would have no prospect of gaining its objectives through armed conflict with the United States and thus to deter it from initiating hostilities. This central feature of United States military strategy is not new. The Carter Administration re- affirmed in 1980 that the basic strategy of the United States is deterrence across the entire spectrum of conflict. It remains the objective of the United States to convince the USSR that it will be successfully opposed at any level of aggression it may choose.
The Reagan Administration's steps to reinforce United States deterrent capability must be viewed against the background of the massive Soviet build-up of arms, particularly of nuclear arms.

During the last 25 years the United States has continued to develop and maintain a strategic arsenal of a make-up and size specifically designed to deal with Soviet capabilities. The United States doctrine is designed to demonstrate to the USSR that any recourse by it to the use of nuclear weapons would result in unacceptable damage to the Soviet Union. The present strengthening of United States nuclear forces is intended to maintain the effectiveness of United States deterrence across the board. One particular requirement identified in recent years has been that of strengthening United States command, communications and control systems, and targeting doctrine, to demonstrate to the Soviet Union the futility of any concept of a limited, protracted or winnable nuclear war.

The Australian Government does not accept any scenario of limited or protracted nuclear war. Australia fully supports the concept of deterrence and United States Government policy directed to that end. The letter of 23 August from the United States Secretary of Defense made clear that the United States does not endorse the concept of protracted nuclear war or nuclear war-fighting. The Australian Government is convinced that nuclear war would be a catastrophe of unpredictable proportions from which neither side would emerge the victor. The United States has indicated that the notion of a 'winnable' war has no place in its strategy.

The Australian Government's policies in the field of arms control and disarmament are directed in particular, to support for an end to the nuclear arms race, strengthening of controls against the spread of nuclear weapons and the early negotiation of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty.
The following is the copy of the text of Mr Weinberger's letter to editors:
THE SECRETARY OF DEFENSEWASHINGTON, THE DISTICT OF COLUMBIA
August 23, 1982
Dear Sir

I am increasingly concerned with news accounts that portray this Administration as planning to wage protracted nuclear war, or seeking to acquire a nuclear ''warfighting'' capability. This is completely inaccurate, and these stories misrepresent the Administration's policies to the American public and to our allies and adversaries abroad.

It is the first and foremost goal of this Administration to take every step to ensure that nuclear weapons are never used again, for we do not believe there could be any 'winners' in a nuclear war. Our entire strategy aims to deter war of all kinds, but most particularly to deter nuclear war. To accomplish this objective, our forces must be able to respond in a measured and prudent manner to the threat posed by the Soviet Union. That will require the improvements in our strategic forces that the President has proposed. But it does not mean that we endorse the concept of protracted nuclear war, or nuclear ''warfighting''. It is the Soviet Union that appears to be building forces for a 'protracted' conflict (the Doctrine of Zatyazhnaya Voyna).

The policy of deterrence is difficult for some to grasp because it is based on a paradox. But this is quite simple: to make the cost of nuclear war much higher than any possible 'benefit' to the country starting it. If the Soviets know in advance that a nuclear attack on the United States could and would bring swift nuclear retaliation, they would never attack in the first place. They would be ''deterred'' from ever beginning a nuclear war.

There is nothing new about our policy. Since the awful age of nuclear weapons began, the United States has sought to prevent nuclear war through a policy of deterrence. This policy has been approved, through the political processes of the democratic nations it protects, since at least 1950. More important, it works. It has worked in the face of major international tensions involving the great powers and it has worked in the face of war itself.

But for deterrence to continue to be successful in the future we must take steps to offset the Soviet military build-up. If we do not modernize our arsenal now, as the Soviets have been doing for more than 20 years, we will, within a few years, no longer have the ability to retaliate. The Soviet Union would then be in a position to threaten or actually to attack us with the knowledge that we would be incapable of responding. We have seen in Poland, in Afganistan, in Eastern Europe and elsewhere that the Soviet Union does not hesitate to take advantage of a weaker adversary. We cannot allow the Soviet Union to think it could begin a nuclear war with us and win.

This is not just idle speculation. The Soviet Union has engaged in a frenzied military build-up, in spite of their economic difficulties. They have continued to build greater numbers of nuclear weapons far beyond those necessary for deterrence. They now have over 5,000 nuclear warheads on ICBMs compared to about 2,000 only five years ago. They have modified the design of these weapons and their launchers so that many of their land based missiles are now more accurate, more survivable, and more powerful than our own. They have also developed a refiring capability that will allow them to reload their delivery systems several times. They have elaborate plans for civil defence and air defence against any retaliation we might attempt. And finally, their writings and military doctrine emphasize a nuclear war-fighting scenario. Whatever they claim their intentions to be, the fact remains that they are designing their weapons in such a way and in sufficient numbers to indicate to us that they think they could begin, and ''win'', a nuclear war.

In the face of all this, it is my responsibility and duty as Secretary of Defense to make every effort to modernize our nuclear forces in such a way that the United States retains the capability to deter the Soviet Union from ever beginning a nuclear war. We must take the steps necessary to match the Soviet Union's greatly improved nuclear capability.

That is exactly why we must have a capability for a survivable and enduring response-to demonstrate that our strategic forces could survive Soviet strikes over an extended period. Thus we believe we could deter any attack. Otherwise we would be tempting them to employ nuclear weapons or try to blackmail us. In short, we cannot afford to place ourselves in the position where the survivability of our deterrent would force the President to choose between using our strategic forces before they were destroyed or surrendering.

Those who object to a policy that would strengthen our deterrent, then, would force us into a more dangerous, hairtriggered posture. Forces that must be used in the very first instant of any enemy attack are not the tools of a prudent strategy.

A posture that encourages Soviet nuclear adventurism is not the basis of an effective deterrent. Our entire strategic program, including the development of a response capability that has been so maligned in the press recently, has been developed with the express intention of assuring that nuclear war will never be fought.

I know this doctrine of deterrence is a difficult paradox to understand. It is an uncomfortable way to keep the peace. We understand deterrence and accept the fact that we must do much more in order to continue to keep the peace. It is my fervent hope that all can understand and accept this so that we can avoid the sort of sensationalist treatment of every mention of the word 'nuclear' that only serves to distort our policy and to frighten people all over the world. Our policy is peace, and we deeply believe that the best and surest road to peace is to secure and maintain an effective and credible deterrent.

The purpose of U.S. policy remains to prevent aggression through an effective policy of deterrence, the very goal which prompted the formation of the Northern Atlantic Alliance, an alliance which is as vital today as it was the day it was formed.
Respectfully,
CASPAR W. WEINBERGER
